questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of blurring of vision, severe headache, and ringing in the ears for 4 months. CT scan was done, and meningioma was diagnosed. While doing surgery for meningioma, the left paracentral lobule got injured. This will lead to paresis of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Right leg and perineum:

  • The paracentral lobule presents near the midline encroaching upon the medial surface of the hemisphere and is the continuation of the precentral and postcentral gyri.

  • The paracentral lobule is involved in controlling the motor and sensory innervations of the contralateral lower limb and part of the perineal region. It is involved in the control of the bladder and bowel (defecation and urination) function.
  • It also includes parts of the frontal and parietal lobes.
  • The anterior part of the paracentral lobule is a portion of the frontal lobe and contains a little portion of Brodmann's area 6.
  • The posterior part is considered a portion of the parietal lobe and deals with the somatosensory of the distal limbs.
  • Cerebral homunculus is a map along the cerebral cortex of where each part of the body is processed. The sensations occur all along the body. The impulses from the body will be sent into the spinal cord and eventually back to the brain to be processed.
  • Sensory Motor Homunculus: Representation of body on the cerebrum.
  • Upside-down representation in an oblique fashion [along the central sulcus].
  • Both motor & sensory.
  • Hand & face has more representation.
  • Lower & lateral: Face area.
  • Higher: Upper limb area.
  • Still higher: Pelvis perineum area.
  • On the medial surface: Lower limb area, part of pelvis & perineum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Left face:

  • The paracentral lobule governs sensory and motor sensations of the right limb and perineum.

Option B - Right neck and scapular region:

  • The paracentral lobule governs sensory and motor sensations of the right limb and perineum.

Option C - Right shoulder and trunk:

  • The paracentral lobule governs sensory and motor sensations of the right limb and perineum.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to OPD with c/o left leg pain that radiates to below the knee. He also c/o numbness in the lower part of the same leg. On performing straight leg test the pain increases.   Which specific dermatome is likely involved in sciatica?
questions.solution:
Option D: S2

  • The posterior calf and thigh region have S2 dermatome.
  • S2 extends from the buttocks to the posteromedial aspect of the thigh, popliteal region and leg. Anteriorly includes the penis and scrotum 
  • The dermatomes of the lower limbs are innervated by the spinal nerves L1-S5. Back pain caused by sciatica can radiate into any of these dermatomes but most commonly S2

Option A: L4

  • L4  anteriorly curves from the lateral aspect of the thigh to the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Includes the knee, medial surface of the big toe, and medial malleolus. It does not cover the posterior calf and posterior thigh region

Option B: L5

  • L5 covers the posterolateral aspect of the thigh, wrapping anteriorly at the knee level to cover the leg's anterolateral aspect. Includes the dorsal and plantar aspects of the foot, lateral surface of the big toe, and toes 2, 3, and 4. It does not cover the posterior thigh and posterior calf

Option C: S1

  • S1 extends to the posterolateral aspect of the thigh, popliteal region, and a leg to the lateral malleolus, lateral margin of foot, heel, and little toe. It does not cover the posterior thigh and calf

questions.text: The professor of anatomy discusses pelvic fascia and its attachments. He demonstrates procedure ‘X’ on a male corpse, encountering Buck's fascia within the dartos layer. Which structure does Buck's fascia relate to?
questions.solution:
Option D: Penis

  • The root of the penis constitutes three masses of erectile tissue called the right and left crura of the penis and the bulb of the penis.
  • The bulb is located in the midline and is traversed by the urethra. It is covered by the bulbospongiosus muscles and forms the corpus spongiosum.
  • The two crura converge anteriorly and form the corpora cavernosa.
  • The erectile tissue comprises two dorsally placed corpora cavernosa and a single corpus spongiosum.
  • The paired corpora cavernosa are surrounded by the tunica albuginea, a dense fibrous sheath of connective tissue.
  • The corpus spongiosum has a much thinner and more elastic tunica albuginea
  • The three erectile bodies are surrounded by deep penile fascia (Bucks fascia), the dartos fascia and the penile skin.
  • The Buck’s fascia is a strong deep fascial layer immediately superficial to the tunica albuginea. It contains the dorsal vessels and dorsal nerves.
    • It is in continuity with the deep fascia of the muscles covering the bulb of the penis and the crura, the ischiocavernosus and bulbospongiosus.
    • The Buck’s fascia encloses the structures of the penis and adheres them to the pubis, ischium and the urogenital diaphragm.
  • The subcutaneous connective tissue of the scrotum and the penis has abundant smooth muscle. It is called the dartos fascia, which continues into the perineum and fuses with the superficial perineal fascia.
  • The dartos fascia is freely attached to the skin and deep penile fascia and contains the superficial arteries, veins, and nerves of the penis.

Option A: Ischiorectal fossa

  • It is a wedge-shaped space with dense fat on each side of the anal canal.
  • The medial wall is formed by the levator ani muscle and the anal canal, while the obturator internus muscle forms the lateral wall.
  • It contains the pudendal canal (pudendal nerve, internal pudendal vessels), inferior rectal nerve, and vessels.

Option B: Thigh

  • The superficial fascia from the anterior abdominal wall extends into the thigh and has two layers:
  • The membranous layer that is attached to the deep fascia (fascia lata)
  • The fatty layer
  • The deep fascia (fascia lata) encloses the thigh with its upper end attached to the pelvis and the inguinal ligament.
    • Its lateral aspect is thickened to form the iliotibial tract.
    • It has a gap in the deep fascia, the saphenous opening, just below the inguinal ligament, which is filled with the cribriform fascia

Option C: Neck

  • The superficial fascia of the neck produces a layer that encloses the platysma muscle. The cutaneous nerves, superficial veins and lymph nodes are embedded in it.
  • The deep cervical fascia supports the muscles, the vessels, and the viscera of the neck. It is condensed to form well-defined fibrous sheets called the investing layer, the pre-tracheal, and the pre-vertebral layer. It is also condensed to form a carotid sheath.

questions.text: A first-year fresh surgical resident at his first rotation in the surgical ward was asked by a senior surgeon about the Houston valve. Keeping in mind Houston's valve anatomy, all of the following is false about the transverse folds of the rectum, also known as Houston’s valve, except?

choices.text: They contain all layers of the muscle layer
Middle valve is the most constant and folds towards the right side

questions.solution:
Option C: Placed transversely

  • The transverse folds of the rectum (or Houston's valves) are semi-lunar transverse folds of the rectal wall that protrude into the rectum, not the anal canal that lies below the rectum.

Option A: They disappear on distension

  •  Houston's valves do not disappear on distension.
  • They protrude in the rectum on distension.

Option B: They contain all layers of the muscle layer

  •  Houston's valves do not contain all layers of the muscle layers.
  • They contain only a circular muscle layer.

Option D: Middle valve is the most constant and folds towards the right side

  •  The middle valve of Houston's valves is constant but does not fold towards the right side.
  • The middle valve folds towards the left side.

questions.text: Which of the following gives branches to form arterial anastomosis around the shoulder?

choices.text: 1st part of subclavian and 1st part of axillary artery
1st part of subclavian and 3rd part of axillary artery
3rd part of subclavian and 2nd part of axillary artery
3rd part of subclavian and 3rd part of axillary artery

questions.solution:
Option B: 1st part of subclavian and 3rd part of axillary artery

  • Shoulder anastomosis occurs between branches of 1st part of the subclavian artery and 3rd part of the axillary artery.
  • There are two types of anastomosis around the shoulder:

1)Around the body of the scapula:

  • This type of anastomosis occurs between the Suprascapular artery (branch of the thyrocervical trunk from the first part of the subclavian artery), Circumflex scapular artery (branch of the subscapular artery from the third part of the axillary artery), and the Deep branch of the transverse cervical artery (branch of the thyrocervical trunk).

2)Over the acromion process:

  • This type of anastomosis occurs between the acromial branch of the thoracoacromial artery, the Acromial branch of the suprascapular artery, and the Acromial branch of the posterior circumflex humeral artery.

Option A: 1st part of subclavian and 1st part of axillary artery

  • The first part of the Axillary Artery is more is not involved in anastomosis.

Option C: 3rd part of subclavian and 2nd part of axillary artery

  • The first part of the subclavian artery is involved in anastomosis (not the third part).
  • The third part of the Axillary Artery is involved (not the second part).

Option D: 3rd part of subclavian and 3rd part of axillary artery

  • First part of the subclavian arteries is involved in anastomosis (not the 3rd part).

questions.text:
All of the following are false about Erb's paralysis except?

A) The forearm lies extended & supinated

B) Injury to lower trunk of Brachial Plexus

C) Inability to initiate abduction

D) Decreased sensation on the medial side of the hand
questions.solution:
Option C: C only.

Erb’s paralysis:

  • Also called waiter's tip palsy, is caused by traction or tear of the upper trunk (C5 to C6 roots).
  • Occurs in infants due to lateral traction on the neck during delivery; In adults, due to trauma leading to neck traction (e.g., falling on head and shoulder in a motorcycle accident).
  • Injury to the nerve causes paralysis of the deltoid, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and biceps brachii. 
  • The patient presents with loss of abduction (leading to arm hanging by the side), loss of lateral rotation (leading to arm medially rotated), and loss of flexion and supination (leading to an extended and pronated arm).
  • The resulting deformity is known as Policeman / Porter / Waiter’s tip hand
  • The affected arm hangs by the side, adducted & medially rotated; The forearm lies extended & pronated.
  • Disability: Loss of fall movements
    • Abduction & lateral rotation of the arm at the shoulder
    • Biceps with supinator jerk lost 
    • Sensory loss over a small area of the deltoid.

 

Option A: A only

  • Erb’s palsy causes loss of supination due to the involvement of C5 and C6 nerve roots supplying the supinator and biceps brachii.

Option B: B only

  • Erb's palsy occurs due to an injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus.

Option D: D only

  • Erb’s palsy causes sensory loss over a small area of the deltoid. Loss of sensation of the medial side of the hand is caused by the injury of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with small cell carcinoma in the right middle lobe, where the thoracic surgeon plans to remove the right middle (secondary) bronchus along with lung tissue. Which of the following bronchopulmonary segments must contain malignant tissue?
questions.solution:
A: Medial and lateral

  • The right middle lobar (secondary) bronchus leads to the medial and lateral bronchopulmonary segments in the middle lobe of the right lung.

B: Anterior and posterior

  • Right Lung
    • Upper lobe BPS
      • Apical
      • Anterior
      • Posterior

C & D: Anterior basal and medial basal & Anterior basal and posterior basal

  • Lower lobe BPS
    • 1 Apical
    • 4 Basal
      • Anterior basal,
      • Posterior basal,
      • Medial basal,
      • Lateral basal

Learning Objective

  • RIGHT lung contains two fissures and 3 lobes -Superior(upper), Middle, and Inferior (lower)

Lobes

Segments
Right upper lobe
  • Apical segment
  • Anterior segment
  • Posterior segment
Middle lobe
  • Lateral segment
  • Medial segment lower
Lower lobe
  • Apical segment
  • Anterior basal
  • Posterior basal
  • Medial basal
  • Lateral basal

questions.text: During thyroidectomy, one of the noted complications is hoarseness of voice due to damage to the laryngeal Nerve, making knowledge of its course important. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks around which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ductus arteriosus

  • Early in embryological development, both the right and left recurrent laryngeal nerves hook (recur) around the aortic arch 6.
  • The left aortic arch 6 persists as the ductus arteriosus(distal part) while the proximal part of it forms the pulmonary artery.

Learning Objective

  • 6TH pharyngeal arch derivatives
    • Nerve: Recurrent laryngeal nerve
    • Artery: Pulmonary artery (and ductus arteriosus)
    • Muscles: All muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid.

questions.text: Which muscle would not be affected in a 15-year-old boy who suffered an arrow injury in the suboccipital triangle?
questions.solution:
Option C: Splenius capitis

  • The splenius capitis is innervated by the dorsal primary rami of the middle and lower cervical nerves.
  • So, injuring the suboccipital nerve between the vertebral artery and the posterior arch of the atlas won't affect the splenius capitis.
  • Splenius capitis and splenius cervicis together form the spinotransversales muscles.
  • The two spinotransversales muscles run from the spinous processes and ligamentum nuchae upward and laterally.
  • The splenius capitis is a broad muscle.
  • It is attached to the mastoid process of the temporal bone.
  • It is also attached to the transverse process of the upper cervical vertebrae.
  • Together, both of these muscles draw the head backward, extending the neck. Individually, each muscle rotates its head to one side- the same side as the contracting muscle.

Option A: Rectus capitis posterior major

  • This muscle will be affected due to the injury to the suboccipital nerve.
  • The suboccipital nerve (primary dorsal ramus of the C1) supplies muscles of the suboccipital area, including
    • The rectus capitis posterior major
    • Obliquus capitis superior
    • The semispinalis capitis

Option B: Semispinalis capitis

  • This muscle will be affected due to the injury to the suboccipital nerve.
  • The suboccipital nerve supplies muscles of the suboccipital area, including
    • The rectus capitis posterior major
    • Obliquus capitis superior
    • The semispinalis capitis

Option D: Obliquus capitis superior

  • This muscle will be affected due to the injury to the suboccipital nerve.
  • The suboccipital nerve supplies muscles of the suboccipital area, including
    • The rectus capitis posterior major
    • Obliquus capitis superior
    • The semispinalis capitis

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for the vocal cord's abduction?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle

  • The only abductor of the vocal cords is the posterior cricoarytenoid.
  • It is essential in coughing, speaking, sniffing, and respiration.
  • As it is the only muscle that opens the vocal cords. Its paralysis can cause asphyxia.

Option A: Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle

  • Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle and Interarytenoid muscle are adductors of the vocal cords.

Option B: Vocalis muscle

  • Vocalis can tense the vocal cords and plays a role in changing the pitch of voice. It does not abduct the vocal cords.

Option D: Cricothyroid muscle

  • Cricothyroid muscle tenses the vocal cords.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the white matter?


	Fornix is the major afferent for the hippocampus.
	Tapetum connects temporal lobes.
	Internal capsule has association fibers.
	Arcuate fasciculus are association fibers.
questions.solution:
Option C: Only 2 and 4 are correct

Statement 2.tapetum connects temporal lobes.

  • The tapetum (part of corpus callosum) is the axons connecting the two opposite cerebral hemispheres' temporal lobes. The tapetum is one of the fiber tracts. The tapetum moves laterally to form the roof and lateral walls of the atrium, and temporal and occipital horns, which are closest to the ventricles ependymal.

 

Statement 4: Arcuate fasciculus are association fibers

  • Arcuate fasciculus is association fibers connecting Wernicke’s sensory speech area with Broca’s motor speech area. Association fibers connect cortical regions within the same cerebral hemisphere of the brain. The arcuate fasciculus is a bundle of axons connecting the temporal and inferior parietal cortex to parts of the frontal lobe. One of the key roles is producing and understanding language.
  • Other fibers are:
    • Projection fibers project from higher to lower centers (or vice versa) in CNS. Commissural fibers are transverse fibers that interconnect similar regions on the left and right sides of the CNS (cerebral hemisphere, brainstem, cerebellum, and spinal cord).

Option A: Only 1, 2, and 3 are correct

Statement 1: Fornix is the major afferent for the hippocampus.

  • The fornix is the major efferent tract for the hippocampus, not afferent.

Statement 3: Internal capsule has association fibers

  • The internal capsule has projection (not association) fibers connecting higher brain centers (like the cerebrum) with lower centers (like the brainstem and spinal cord).

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents with progressive weakness, exhaustion, and drooping upper eyelids. Examination reveals diminished motor strength in the upper extremities and bilateral expiratory wheezes. Which of the following is not associated with the structure involved in the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option D: Alport syndrome

  • This is a case of myasthenia gravis in which the patient classically presents with muscle weakness.
  • The gland indicated in the question is the thymus gland. Therefore, the thymus gland is associated with Good syndrome, pure red cell aplasia, and myasthenia gravis. It is not associated with Alport syndrome.
  • Alport syndrome triad consist of
    • Hematuria
    • SNHL
    • Anterior lenticonus

Option A: Myasthenia gravis

  • It is a disease of neuromuscular junction which results in muscular fatigue and weakness.
  • MG, when associated with thymoma, is termed a paraneoplastic disease

Option B: Pure red cell aplasia.

  • Pure red cell aplasia is one type of anemia that is rare.
  • Cause due to the absence of the RBC precursors.
  • It is associated with thymoma.

Option C: Good syndrome

  • Goods syndrome is also associated with thymoma.
  • It is thymoma with immunodeficiency.

questions.text: The capillary wall divides plasma and interstitial fluid. Substances exchange between plasma and interstitial fluid through the endothelial wall of capillaries. Which of the following substances cross capillary walls primarily through water-filled clefts between the endothelial cells?
questions.solution:
Option D: Glucose

Figure- glucose transport through capillaries

  • Intercellular clefts are the channel through which molecules may travel from blood serum to interstitium or vice versa.
  • Most commonly, they are found between epithelial cells and the endothelium of blood vessels.
  • They are water-filled and important for transporting fluids and small solute particles through the endothelium.
  • Glucose is water-soluble.
  • It cannot cross through the lipid component of the cell membrane.
  • It is restricted to the water-filled clefts, or pores, between the cells.

Option A: O2

  • O2 is lipophilic.
  • They can cross capillary walls primarily by diffusion through the endothelial cell membranes.

Option B: CO2

  • CO2 is lipophilic.
  • They can cross capillary walls primarily by diffusion through the endothelial cell membranes.
  • CO2 is 20 times as lipid-soluble as compared to O2.

Option C: CO

  • CO is lipophilic.
  • They cross capillary walls primarily by diffusion through the endothelial cell membranes.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a unilateral headache of pulsating nature associated with nausea and photophobia. She has been eating cheesecakes recently since she started attending baking classes. The physician gives her anti emetic with an NSAID to abort the pain. She demands something to avoid the pain in the future. The physician prescribes her a drug for prophylactic management of this pain. This drug is also used as an anticonvulsant medication to block receptors of a major excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain. Which of the following is the excitatory neurotransmitter?
questions.solution:
Option D: Glutamate

Topiramate:

  • This patient suffers from migraines due to tyramine-containing food consumption (cheesecakes).
  • Pulsating pain on one side associated with nausea and photophobia all points towards a diagnosis of migraine.
  • Migraine is due to irritation of the meninges, trigeminal nerve, or blood vessels.
  • Topiramate is an anticonvulsant that is also used in migraine prophylaxis
  • It binds and blocks glutamate receptors and sodium channels.
  • Hence glutamate is the correct choice.

Glutamate

  • Glutamate is the major excitatory neurotransmitter; 60% of brain synapses are glutamatergic.
  • Glutamate functions to regulate memory.
  • It is also associated with pain.
  • It is needed for the proper function of the brain.
  • Too much glutamate can cause excitotoxicity.

Option A: Acetylcholine

  • The major function of acetylcholine is muscle stimulation, including the gastrointestinal and autonomic nervous systems.
  • Furthermore, the scenario points toward topiramate blocking glutamate receptors; hence this is the incorrect choice.

Option B: Aspartate

  • Topiramate is used for migraine prophylaxis which is a glutamate receptor blocker.

Option C: GABA

  • GABA is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter.
  • Topiramate blocks glutamate receptors; hence this is not the right choice.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to your clinic for consultation. The main concern is bleeding gums. The mother states several episodes of excessive bleeding previously from minor injuries. You find out that the maternal grandfather has a clotting disorder. Physical examination of the child reveals slight tenderness over the knee with fluid accumulation in the knee joint. Which of the following coagulation factors is likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Factor VIII:

  • A young man with a bleeding disorder and a history of bleeding disorders in the males of his family would lead one to suspect hemophilia A, a deficiency of factor VIII (because it is an X-linked disorder)
  • The physical examination suggests bleeding into the knee joint (hemarthrosis), frequently seen in hemophilia A.
  • Hemophilia A or Classic hemophilia is caused by factor VIII deficiency.
  • About 15% of cases of hemophilia are caused by deficiency of factor IX (Christmas factor)- Hemophilia B or Christmas disease.

Option A: Prothrombin activator

  • A young man with a bleeding disorder and a history of bleeding disorders in the males of his family would lead one to suspect hemophilia A, a deficiency of factor VIII (because it is an X-linked disorder)

Option B: Factor II

  • A young man with a bleeding disorder and a history of bleeding disorders in the males of his family would lead one to suspect hemophilia A, a deficiency of factor VIII (because it is an X-linked disorder)

Option D: Factor X

  • Vitamin K is an essential factor in liver carboxylase that adds a carboxyl group to glutamic acid residues on five of the important clotting factors: prothrombin, Factor VII, Factor IX, Factor X, and protein C.
  • Occurs in healthy persons as a result of the absence of vitamin K from the diet (except in neonates before they establish their intestinal bacterial flora). However, in persons with gastrointestinal disease, vitamin K deficiency often occurs as a result of poor absorption of fats from the gastrointestinal tract because vitamin K is fat-soluble and is ordinarily absorbed into the blood along with the fats. One of the most prevalent causes of vitamin K deficiency is the failure of the liver to secrete bile into the gastrointestinal tract (which occurs either as a result of obstruction of the bile ducts or as a result of liver disease). so it will depress the clotting system
  • There is no genetic transfer from parents to off springs

questions.text: Which of the following motor events of GIT is integrated entirely within the Enteric Nervous System?
questions.solution:
Option D: Peristaltic reflex

  • Peristalsis is the automatic wave-like movement of the muscles that line your gastrointestinal tract.
  • Peristalsis moves food through your digestive system, beginning in the throat when you swallow and continuing through the oesophagus, stomach and intestines while the patient digest.
  • Peristaltic reflex: When the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen, it initiates a reflex response known as peristalsis, which occurs in all parts of the gastrointestinal tract starting from the oesophagus to the rectum.
  • A very good example is the integrated activity of the enteric nervous system.
  • The gastrocolic reflex is the physiological reflex that controls the motility, or peristalsis, of the gastrointestinal tract.

Option A: Intesto-intestinal reflex

  • Into-intestinal reflex: Contractile activity in the rest of the bowel is inhibited if an area of the bowel is grossly distended. It depends on the extrinsic neural connections with the Enteric Nervous System; sectioning the extrinsic nerve will abolish this reflex.
  • Distension in one area of the intestines slows the motility of proximal segments. The goal is to avoid adding more ingesta to the already distended section.
  • In addition, three overarching reflexes control the movement, digestion, and defecation of food and food waste:
    • The enterogastric reflex.
    • The gastrocolic reflex.
    •  The gastroileal reflex.

Option B: Recto-sphincteric reflex

  • It is a reflex characterized by transient involuntary relaxation of the internal anal sphincter in response to distention of the rectum.
  • The defecation reflex occurs when the internal anal sphincter relaxes and the external anal sphincter contracts.
  • The rectoanal inhibitory reflex (RAIR) is an involuntary internal anal sphincter relaxation in response to rectal distention.
  • After the defecation reflex is triggered, the patient can either delay or defecate.
  • A sufficient increase in faecal material in the rectum causes stretch receptors from the nervous system located in the rectal walls to trigger the contraction of the rectal muscles.

Option C: Gastro-ileal reflex

  • The gastroileal reflex is a third type of gastrointestinal reflex.
  • It works with the gastrocolic reflex to stimulate the urge to defecate.
  • This urge is stimulated by the opening of the ileocecal valve and the movement of the digested contents from the ileum of the small intestine into the colon for compaction.
  • Shortly after eating food, there is relaxation of the ileocecal sphincter and an increase in the contractile activity of the ileum.
  • It promotes the passage of small intestinal contents into the colon. Extrinsic autonomic nerves mediate this reflex to the intestine.

questions.text: Which of the following can cause an increase in cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Option A: Decrease intrathoracic pressure

  • Intrathoracic pressure influences venous return and consequently cardiac output and arterial pressure.
  • A drop in intrathoracic pressure dilates the thoracic vena cava, resulting in increased venous return and atrial filling. This increases cardiac output.

 

  • The opposite mechanism decreases heart rate in case of increased intrathoracic pressure as during Valsalva.
  • Factors maintaining the CO:
    • Heart rate (chronotropic effect)
    • Stroke volume
    • Venous return or EDV or preload
  • Force of contraction (inotropic effect) determines ESV.
  • Afterload is determined by total peripheral resistance (TPR).
  • Changes in intra-thoracic pressure during respiration :

  • Factors affecting cardiac output are explained below:

 

 

Option B: Decreased blood volume

  • A decreased mean systemic filling pressure →decreased venous return.

Option C: Decreased ventricular compliance

  • This will decrease the ability of the ventricle to accumulate blood during diastole → decrease EDV.

Option D: Decreased mean systemic filling

  • Decreased filling results in decreased EDV and hence reduced cardiac output.

questions.text: During which phase of breathing does the respiratory system exhibit the highest level of compliance?
questions.solution:
Option A: Start of an inspiration

  • LUNG COMPLIANCE is the extent to which lungs will expand for each unit increase in trans pulmonary pressure [if enough time is allowed to reach equilibrium].
  • Total lung compliance of both lungs together in normal adults averages about 200 ml of air cm of H20, i.e., every time transpulmonary pressure increases by 1 cm of H2O, the lung volume expands by 200 ml.
  • The compliance of the thoracic cage and lung tissue is 110 ml/ cm of H2O.

COMPLIANCE α 1/ Surface tension

  • One factor affecting compliance is the Surface tension, which is high or low based on how attracted the molecules in a given liquid are to each other. Liquids, like water, have high surface tension because the molecules attract each other very strongly. Surfactant molecules have a weak attraction to one another
  • Surface tension is decreased by surfactant.
  • At the start of inspiration/End of expiration, alveoli are the smallest, and surfactant is concentrated in alveoli. Surface tension is the least, and compliance is the maximum.
  • At the End of inspiration, the alveoli are large, and the surfactant is scattered.
  • Surface tension is high, and compliance is less.

Option B: Mid inspiration

  • This option is incorrect as, during mid-inspiration, compliance is not the greatest.

Option C: End of inspiration

  • This option is incorrect as compliance is not the greatest at the End of inspiration.
  • It is maximum at the start of inspiration.

Option D: Expiration

  • The lung compliance is maximum at the start of inspiration, not at the expiration.

questions.text: A professor explains nephron physiology and the process of secretion and reabsorption. Tubular reabsorption is the process that moves solutes and water out of the filtrate and back into your bloodstream. This process is known as reabsorption because this is the second time they have been absorbed, the first time being when they were absorbed into the bloodstream from the digestive tract after a meal. Maximum absorption of HCO3- occurs in?

choices.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
PCT

  • 80% of bicarbonate reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule.

DCT

  • All the filtered HCO3– in the renal tubules are reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

Collecting duct

  • 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

  • 15% of bicarbonate reabsorption occurs in the thick ascending limb of LOH.

Learning Objective

Bicarbonate Mechanism

  • All the filtered HCO3– in the renal tubules is reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The reabsorption of HCO3– utilizes the H+ secreted into the renal tubules.
  • H+ secreted into the renal tubule, combines with filtered HCO3– forming carbonic acid (H2 CO3 ). Carbonic acid dissociates into carbon dioxide and water in the presence of carbonic anhydrase. Carbon dioxide and water enter the tubular cell.
  • In the tubular cells, carbon dioxide combines with water to form carbonic acid. It immediately dissociates into H+ and HCO3– . HCO3– from the tubular cell enters the interstitium. Simultaneously Na+ is reabsorbed from the renal tubule under the influence of aldosterone. HCO3– combines with Na+ to form sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3). Now, the H+ is secreted into the tubular lumen from the cell in exchange for Na+.
  • Thus, for every hydrogen ion secreted into lumen of tubule, one bicarbonate ion is reabsorbed from the tubule. In this way, kidneys conserve the HCO3–. The reabsorption of filtered HCO3– is an important factor in maintaining pH of the body fluids.
  • Filtered bicarbonate can be reabsorbed only when it combines with H+.

questions.text: A professor explains renal plasma flow (RPF) autoregulation in a seminar on renal physiology. He explains that renal plasma flow (RPF) autoregulation is a vital homeostatic mechanism that protects the kidney from elevations in arterial pressure that would be transmitted to the glomerular capillaries and cause injury. The Myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation is mediated through?
questions.solution:
Option C: Opening of Ca2+ channels

  • According to the myogenic mechanism of autoregulation, the rise in arterial pressure stretches the afferent arteriole.
  • Stretch of vascular smooth muscle causes opening of mechanosensitive membrane Ca2+ channels. This increases intracellular Ca2+, leading to the contraction of the smooth muscle.

Option A: NO release

  • NO release is involved in the (tubuloglomerular)TG feedback. They are released by macula densa in response to changes in NaCl in tubular fluids.

Option B: Noradrenaline release

  • Acting via α1 receptors located mainly in the afferent arteriole causes vasoconstriction.
  • Dehydration and strong emotional stimuli (fear, pain) activate sympathetic nerves and reduce RBF and GFR.

Option D: Adenosine release

  • Adenosine release is involved in the TG feedback. They are released by macula densa in response to changes in NaCl in tubular fluids.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions increase the serum levels of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) in the body?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pregnancy

  • The thyroid cells are typical protein-secreting glandular cells.
  • Thyroglobulin is a glycoprotein made up of two subunits and has a molecular weight of 660 kDa.
  • It contains 10% carbohydrates by weight.
  • It also contains 123 tyrosine residues, but only 4–8 of these are normally incorporated into thyroid hormones.
  • Thyroglobulin is synthesized in the thyroid cells and secreted into the colloid by exocytosis of granules.

TBG concentration increases in (conditions of high estrogen levels) such as:

  • Pregnancy
  • Oral contraceptives.

Option A: Glucocorticoid therapy

  • Serum TBG levels are decreased by glucocorticoid therapy.

Option B: Nephrotic Syndrome

  • Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by protein-losing nephropathy, thus reducing serum levels of different plasma proteins, including TBG.

Choice D: Cancer chemotherapy

  • Cancer chemotherapy also decreases plasma levels of TBG.

questions.text: During REM sleep, the atonia is markedly present in which of the following regions?
questions.solution:
Option A: Neck

  • The tone of most voluntary muscles is reduced temporarily.
  • The tone of the neck muscles is reduced markedly during REM sleep.
  • The loss of tone is due to an active inhibition of motor neurons mediated by a group of neurons in the locus coeruleus in the brain stem.
  • During REM sleep, the neurons of the sub coeruleus (SubC) nucleus get activated.
  • The activation of SubC neurons activates the GABAergic and glycinergic cells in Ventral Medial Medulla. These cells release neurotransmitters known as GABA and glycine, which play the most important role in muscle paralysis during REM sleep.
  • GABA and glycine neurotransmitters inhibit the overall skeletal muscle movements, which are more pronounced in the neck region. The inhibition prevents the person from acting on his dreams and consequently hurting himself.
  • During wakefulness, SubC cells are inactivated, and Red Nucleus brings about the activation of skeletal muscles.
  • In patients with RBD, there is degeneration of SubC cells. This results in no activation of cells in the Ventral Medial Medulla and consequently no REM atonia.
  • Therefore, the person with RBD acts according to his dreams and has a tendency to hurt himself.

Option B: Extraocular muscles

  • The reduction of tone is not observed in extraocular muscles (which contract rhythmically to produce rapid eye movements).

Option C: Muscles of the middle ear

  • The reduction of tone is not observed in the muscles of the middle ear (which protect the inner ear).

Option D: Diaphragm

  • The reduction of tone is not observed in the diaphragm, which comprises the muscles of respiration.

questions.text: For which hormone do Sertoli cells in the testes possess receptors?
questions.solution:
Option A: FSH

  • Sertoli cells secrete inhibin. They have receptors for FSH.
  • LH acts on Leydig cells, which secrete testosterone.

Option B: LH

  • The LH receptors are on the Leydig cells.
  • Sertoli cells have receptors for FSH.

Option C: Inhibin

  • The receptor of inhibin is on the anterior pituitary cells.
  • Inhibin exerts negative feedback on the FSH secretion.

Option D: All of the above

  • Sertoli cells have receptors for FSH only.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and high blood pressure for 4 hours. The general physical examinations of the patient revealed no abnormalities. He has had a history of hypertension for ten years. His blood pressure is recorded as 190/110mmhg; his pulse pressure is 90 mmHg. Which of the following parameters explains this high pulse pressure in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Arterial wall compliance

  • In this case, the patient presents with chest pain and high blood pressure complaints.
  • This is due to a decrease in the complaints of the walls of the arteries.
  • This can also result in left ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Because of wall compliance of the aorta and arteries, the pressure doesn't increase much. Still, if the aorta and arteries cannot distend to accommodate the blood, the pressure rises much.

Cardiac output: CO = SV x HR

  • Factors determining cardiac output: Stroke volume also depends on contraction strength.

Option B: Stroke volume

  • The stroke volume is described as the amount of blood ejected from the ventricle during each cardiac cycle.

Option C: Cardiac output

  • The cardiac output is the output by the left ventricle.
  • It determines the blood pressure exerted on the vessel walls.

Option D: Myocardial contractility

  • Myocardial contractility explains the pressure of the blood; it doesn't explain the arterial pressure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented to the hospital complaining of intractable vomiting and inability to eat or drink for the past 3 days. His blood analysis still shows a normal glucose level. Which of the following processes is mainly responsible for the blood glucose maintenance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Liver gluconeogenesis

  • The patient is in starvation, given that he has not taken any food for the past 3 days.
  • During short-term fasting, the liver produces and releases glucose mainly through glycogenolysis. However, during prolonged fasting, glycogen is depleted, and hepatocytes synthesize glucose through gluconeogenesis using lactate, pyruvate Pyruvate, glycerol, and amino acids.
  • Glucagon released during starvation will cause the activation of gluconeogenic enzymes in the liver, which will maintain the blood glucose needed for the functioning of vital organs such as the brain, heart, and RBCs. Therefore, the answer is liver gluconeogenesis.
  • The Fed state is mainly related to glycogen metabolism, while the fasted state shows a gluconeogenesis process from gluconeogenic substrates.
  • The figure below shows the role of the liver in the fed and fasting state under hormonal control.

Option B: Dietary Glucose

  • Dietary glucose can provide blood glucose up to 2 hours after feeding. The extra glucose consumed in food gets deposited in the liver and muscles as glycogen and fats in adipose tissues.

Option C: Muscle glycogenolysis

  • The glycogenolysis inside the muscles gives glucose-6-phosphate as an end-product, not D-Glucose, due to the absence of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase in muscles. Hence, muscle glycogen cannot contribute to blood glucose directly.

Option D: Liver glycogenolysis

  • Glycogen breakdown in the liver can maintain blood glucose for 12-18 hours. After that period, liver gluconeogenesis is the primary source of blood glucose during fasting/starvation.

questions.text: What color change in Benedict's test during urine evaluation would indicate the absence of sugar in a clinical setting?
questions.solution:
Option A: Blue

  • Benedict's reagent contains Cupric (Cu2+) ions which give blue color to the solution. They are stabilized to cupric form by sodium citrate.
  • Reducing sugars can donate H (e-) to these cupric ions to reduce them to cuprous (Cu1+) which combine with oxygen to form cuprous oxide (CuO) which forms small to large size precipitates.
  • The color of these CuO precipitates depends on the size and is either yellow (small size ppt) or Red (large size ppt).
  • Depending on the amount of red CuO formed, we will see different colors in the tube. But these colors can only tell the approximate amount of sugar. So, it’s a semi-quantitative test.
  • If there is no reducing sugar present in the sample, the original blue color will be retained in a tube after heating.

Option B: Green

  • If the sugar concentration in the sample is 0.5 to 1.0 percent, only a small amount of reagent is reduced to form some CuO ppt.
  • So, the color of the reagent will change to green due to the mixing of yellow and blue color (green)

Option C: Orange

  • If the sugar concentration in the sample is 1.0 to 1.5 percent, both small and large CuO ppt will be formed as more of the original solution is reduced.
  • So, the color of the reagent will change to orange due to the mixing of yellow and red color (orange).

Option D: Brick red

  • If the sugar concentration in the sample is 1.5 to 2.0 percent, only large CuO ppt will be formed as almost all of the original solution is reduced.
  • So, the color of the reagent will change to brick red.

questions.text: All of the following are tightly bound to component enzymes of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, except:
questions.solution:
Option D: Coenzyme A

  • CoA is a loosely bound cofactor of PDH component E2
  • Help enzyme in catalysis by accepting acetyl group from lipoamide
  • Other loosely bound cofactor is NAD which is a cofactor of E3 subunit of enzyme

Option A: Thiamine PyroPhosphate (TPP)

  • Bound covalently to E1
  • Decarboxylates pyruvate

Option B: Lipoic acid

  • Covalently linked to Lys on E2
  • Accepts acetyl group from TPP

Option C: Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)

  • Bound by covalent linkage to E2
  • Reduced by lipoamide

Learning Objective: PDH complex cofactors:

Characteristic Cofactor
Prosthetic groups TPP
Lipoic Acid
FAD
Loosely bound groups NAD+
CoA

questions.text:
A 15-day-old baby is brought to the clinic by his mother with the complaint of frequent vomiting. He has recently started feeding on breast milk. An appropriate diagnosis is made, and the patient is discharged after the resolution of the symptoms. A few days later, the baby presents to the clinic again with jaundice. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Ocular examination shows the following findings:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Galactosemia

  • The cataract shown is an Oil Drop Cataract, which is characteristic of Galactosemia.
  • These clinical manifestations of the liver affected when milk is the diet is typical of Classical Galactosemia.

Option B: Juvenile Diabetes Mellitus

  • In Juvenile Diabetes Mellitus, jaundice and hepatomegaly are observed, but cataract is never there.

Option C: Hereditary Fructose Intolerance

  • Bilateral cataracts rule out the possibility of Hereditary Fructose Intolerance, although other symptoms exist in both these diseases.

Option D: Gaucher's disease

  • Gaucher's disease is a sphingolipidosis due to deficiency of β-Glucosidase or β-Glucocerebrosidase with an accumulation of Glucosylceramide.
  • Clinical features include No mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, and osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient comes to the physician complaining of leg pain and swelling for one day. She has a history of 2 miscarriages. Physical examination shows stiff, swollen finger joints; left calf circumference is larger with a palpable cord in the left popliteal fossa. Labs reveal a PT of 12 seconds and a PTT of 51 seconds. The patient has received warfarin as a part of her therapy and will have decreased γ-carboxyglutamate residues on which of the following coagulation factors?
questions.solution:
Option C: Factor II

  • The diagnosis of the above-given case is antiphospholipid syndrome.
  • Miscarriage and unprovoked DVT are common presentations.
  • The patient has received warfarin as a part of her therapy which interferes with the recycling of vitamin K (see fig).

  • The clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X are activated by vitamin K-assisted carboxylation as a part of the vitamin K cycle.
  • Vitamin K is the cofactor for γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues of the proteins to produce γ- carboxy glutamate.
  • Hence all of the above-mentioned factors will cause decreased carboxy glutamate residues in a patient taking warfarin.

Option A: Factor XI

  • Factor VIII and factor XI are activated by thrombin.

Option B: Factor V

  • Factor V deficiency causes bruising, gums bleeding, prolonged bleeding, and trauma.
  • Activated protein C inactivates factor V.
  • Factor Va cleaves thrombin (factor II) to prothrombin (factor IIa).
  • Inactivation of factor V slows the coagulation process.

Option D: Fibrinogen

  • Thrombin activates fibrinogen (factor I) to fibrin (factor Ia).
  • It stabilizes the platelet plug at the site of injury.
  • Fibrinogen disorder can cause thrombosis.

questions.text: Dideoxynucleotides are used for Sanger DNA sequencing technique. Whenever this nucleotide is added in to growing DNA chain, the chain elongation stops causing termination of DNA synthesis. This form the basis of this sequencing technique. Based on that knowledge we can deduce that a dideoxynucleotide does not contain:
questions.solution:
Dideoxy nucleotide

  • Lacks 3’ OH group also.
  • Stop the chain elongation when they are incorporated.
  • DNA polymerase requires 3’ OH group to begin polymerisation.
  • Use:
    • Sanger chain termination method of DNA sequencing.
    • Didanosine (dideoxyinosine) is a dideoxynucleotide used in the therapy of HIV.

questions.text: The rate-limiting step of triacylglycerol hydrolysis is catalyzed by which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Option D: Glycerol-3-P

  • For making TGs, glycerol-3-P is joined with three fatty acids.
  • There is only one enzyme in adipose tissues for the synthesis of Glycerol-3-P, and that is glycerol-3-P dehydrogenase which synthesizes glycerol-3-P from DHAP.
  • This DHAP is derived from glucose. So, glucose entry is a must in adipose tissues for TG synthesis. This occurs with the help of glucose channel GLUT-4.
  • In diabetics, however, there is a shortage of glucose supply to adipose tissue due to either defective GLUT-4 or insulin deficiency.
  • Hence, glycerol-3-P becomes the limiting factor for TG synthesis.

In the liver, there are two enzymes for glycerol 3-P synthesis:

  1. Glycerol-3-P dehydrogenase
  2. Glycerol kinase

Option A: NADPH

  • It is a molecule that provides electrons for anabolic reactions and for the oxidation-reduction reaction.
  • It is produced by the hexose monophosphate pathway.

Option B: ATP

  • ATP can be produced by converting triglycerides into acetyl CoA by aerobic respiration.
  • This is not the rate-limiting factor for the synthesis of triglycerides in adipose tissue.

Option C: Acetyl CoA

  • Acetyl CoA is used for the synthesis of triglycerides.
  • It increases the production of triglycerides in diabetic patients.

questions.text: A patient presented to casualty with nausea and vomiting. Intravenous glucose was given & the patient recovered. After a few months, the patient presented with the same complaints, along with increased blood glutamine and elevated uracil levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency

  • In the urea cycle, ammonia combines with carbon dioxide and forms carbamoyl phosphate. The carbamoyl phosphate combines with ornithine and forms citrulline. The enzyme responsible for the reaction is carbamoyl phosphate synthase and ornithine carbamoyl transferase, respectively.
  • If the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is deficient, it leads to elevated levels of ammonia in the blood and carbamoyl phosphate from in liver mitochondria .
  • The excess carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria enters the cytoplasm and takes part in pyrimidine synthesis leading to increased uracil synthesis (see fig).
  • Orotic acid, OMP, and UMP are all increased in OTC defect.

  • Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency presents with the symptoms of refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, seizures, etc.
  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder. It is the most common urea cycle disorder.
  • It is characterized by decreased levels of blood urea nitrogen.
  • CPS-II (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-II) is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine synthesis, not in the urea cycle.

Choice A: CPS-I deficiency

  • CPS-I enzyme is involved in the urea cycle. It is present in the mitochondria.
  • It leads to elevated ammonia levels in the blood, which can have toxic effects on the brain.
  • It does not lead to elevated levels of orotic acids in the blood.

Choice B: Arginosuccinate synthetase deficiency

  • Arginosuccinate synthase enzyme is a part of the urea cycle. It is involved in the synthesis of argininosuccinate via the enzyme argininosuccinate synthase.
  • If citrulline is increased, then it means that Arginosuccinate synthetase is the deficient enzyme.

Choice C: CPS-II deficiency

  • CPS-II is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine.
  • It is activated by ATP and is inhibited by UMP.
  • ​​​​​​​Its deficiency is associated with the decreased synthesis of pyrimidine.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is used for changing the enzyme's quantity?
questions.solution:
Option B: Induction

  • Enzyme's quantity, i.e., the amount of enzyme synthesized, can be controlled at the level of gene expression by inducing or repressing the gene or enzyme breakdown by enzyme degradation.
  • Examples are Induction of lac enzymes in lactose operon of E Coli and Induction of fatty acid synthesis and other synthetic enzymes by insulin.

Option A and C: Phosphorylation and Acetylation

  • Phosphorylation and acetylation are covalent methods of regulation of enzyme activity.
  • They do not affect the quantity of enzymes.
  • Most common method of enzyme activity regulation is phosphorylation, for e.g. catabolic enzymes are active in phosphorylated state while anabolic enzymes get activated by their dephosphorylation by phosphatases.

Option D: Glycosylation

  • Enzymes are not regulated by glycosylation.
  • N-glycosylation and O-glycosylation are process of adding the carbohydrates to form glycoproteins.
  • These carbohydrate part of these glycosylated proteins has functions such as cell signaling and recognition as well as structural components

questions.text: Which of the following units is used to denote the Michaelis constant (Km)?
questions.solution:
Option D: Moles Litre-1

  • The Km can be defined as that substrate concentration at which velocity of an enzyme catalyzed reaction is ½ of Vmax (see fig below).
  • As Km is a concentration, unit of Km will be the unit of concentration which is moles/L

  • Km is inversely proportional to the affinity.

Option A: Second-1

  • It is the unit of rate constant for a first order reaction.
  • The enzyme reaction follows first order kinetics when [S] << Km

Option B: Moles second-1

  • It is the unit of velocity which is given by number of molecules of substrate consumed or product produced per unit time.

Option C: Millimoles

  • It is the unit of amount of substance present.
  • 1 mole of any substance is equal to Avogadro number (6.022 × 1023) of its atoms or molecules. So millimoles will be 6.022 x 1020 molecules.

Learning Objectives: Km of an enzyme is a substrate concentration at which velocity is equal to half of Vmax. So, it has same unit as concentration i.e. millimoles L-1

questions.text: A 65-year-old male suffers a heart attack and expires. Lung autopsy on examination reveals numerous pigmented nodules scattered throughout the parenchyma (shown in the image). What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anthracosis

  • Anthracosis is a pneumoconiosis seen in city inhabitants and coal miners due to the chronic inhalation of carbon dust and sooty air.

  • Typically milder than other types of pneumoconiosis and is usually asymptomatic. Primarily affects the upper lobes of the lungs.

Clinical features:

  • Milder than other types of pneumoconiosis, usually asymptomatic

  • The upper lobes of the lungs are primarily affected.

  • Pulmonary fibrosis rarely occurs.

  • Chest x-ray shows Heterogeneous pulmonary infiltrates, with/without mass lesion.

  • In some areas, the subpleural tissue appears white; in others, it appears partly bluish to black.

  • There are many spot-shaped black macules on the lung surface and some larger regions of black discolouration.

  • This is the typical appearance of pneumoconioses, specifically anthracosis.

Option B: Asbestosis

  • Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibres, usually due to occupational exposure.

  • After a long latency period, this condition manifests with nonspecific symptoms, e.g., coughing and dyspnea, which are caused by fibrotic lung changes.

  • The diagnosis is based on a history of occupational exposure (such as working with textiles, cement, ship-building, and insulation) and characteristic changes on chest x-ray (reticular opacities and pleural plaques). 

  • Bilateral pleural plaques (indicated by arrowheads), some densely calcified, appear as curvilinear and irregular opacities.

  • The lung opacities raised concern for lung cancer, but a biopsy established a diagnosis of cryptococcus infection.

  • Partially confluent, white, fibrous plaques with a verrucous appearance are visible. These plaques are pathognomonic for pleuropulmonary Asbestosis.

  • Multiple rod-shaped bodies can be seen throughout the fibrotic tissue. A transparent core is visible in some cases, characteristic of asbestos fibres (unlike other ferruginous bodies). Anthracotic pigment (clusters of small black particles) is also visible in various locations.

Option C: Hemochromatosis

  • Hemochromatosis is characterized by excess iron deposition (or increased risk of excess deposition) in the body due to increased iron absorption. 

  • Increased iron absorption leads to iron overload  as there is no physiologic method for iron excretion (except through menstrual bleeding)

Organ-specific symptoms 

  • Liver

    • Abdominal pain

    • Hepatomegaly.

    • Cirrhosis 

    • Increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (a common cause of death)  [8]

  • Pancreas: signs of diabetes mellitus (polydipsia, polyuria)

  • Skin: hyperpigmentation, bronze skin 

  • Pituitary gland: hypogonadism, erectile dysfunction,testicular atrophy, loss of libido, amenorrhea[9]

  • Joints: arthralgia (typically symmetrical arthropathy of the MCP joints II and III), chondrocalcinosis (accumulation of calcium pyrophosphate)

  • Heart

    • Cardiomyopathy

 Option D: Sarcoidosis

  • Sarcoidosis is an idiopathic, chronic inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of noncaseating granulomas, typically in the lung and, less commonly, in the liver, eyes, and skin.

  • Predominantly occurs in young African American women. Chest x-ray often reveals bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

  • A biopsy is a gold standard for diagnosis.

  • First-line treatment is corticosteroids.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and fever. His blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. On examination, right lower lobe crackles are heard. The parents describe that the boy has had multiple infections over the past few years. The doctor decides to order a Nitroblue tetrazolium test. For which of the immune cell assessment is this test used?
questions.solution:
Option A: Polymorphs

  • The nitroblue testing is done to assess the function of polymorphs

Nitroblue tetrazolium test:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium or NBT test measures ROS generated by spermatozoa and leukocytes.
  • NBT becomes reduced by free oxygen radicals forming a blue-black compound, formazan.
  • The reaction can be monitored spectro-photometrically, or the stained cells can be scored histochemically.
  • The NBT reaction reflects the ROS-generating activity in the cytoplasm of cells. Moreover, results of NBT staining strongly correlate with ROS levels assessed by chemiluminescence.
  • The Source of ROS, i.e. spermatozoa or leukocytes, can be distinguished by scoring the relative density of formazan granules.
  • Different sources of ROS imply and point towards different pathological conditions.
  • The test is readily available and inexpensive.
  • The test's high sensitivity potentially serves as a good preliminary assessment tool for infertile men with suspected high ROS as the underlying aetiology.
  • The NBT test is a diagnostic tool used to evaluate the ability of neutrophils to produce superoxide, an important component of the oxidative burst that helps these immune cells destroy bacteria and other pathogens. In some inherited immunodeficiency disorders like chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), neutrophils lack the ability to generate superoxide effectively, making individuals more susceptible to recurrent bacterial and fungal infections.

Option B: Complement

  • Complement testing is used for the measurement of complement system protein activity.
  • Nitroblue testing is done in the suspected chronic granulomatous disease.
  • The NBT test is not used to assess complement levels. Complement is a group of proteins that play a role in immune responses but is not directly evaluated by the NBT test.

Option C: T cell

  • T cell function is tested by detecting the T cell numbers.
  • This is usually done in HIV.
  • Nitroblue testing is done for the polymorphs function
  • T cell function is not assessed by the NBT test. T cell function can be evaluated using other tests, such as lymphocyte proliferation assays.

Option D: B cell

  • B cell function is important to fight against the encapsulated organism.
  • Nitroblue testing is not done for the B-cells.
  • B cell function is also not assessed by the NBT test. B cell function is typically evaluated through tests that assess antibody production and immunoglobulin levels.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy, while riding a bicycle, was hit by a four-wheeler and suffered generalized abrasions over both lower limbs; he was rushed to a nearby hospital, injection tetanus toxoid was administered, and wound cleaning and dressing were done. Which of the following is the best statement regarding the given pathology?

choices.text: Chemical mediators such as histamine play a role in delayed vascular leakage
Hallmark of the given pathology is increased permeability in the post-capillary venules
Transcytosis is not a contributing factor to vascular leakage
In most cases, vascular leakage starts several hours after injury

questions.solution:
Option B: Hallmark of the given pathology is increased permeability in the post-capillary venules.

  • Several mechanisms are responsible for the increased permeability of post-capillary venules, which is a hallmark of acute inflammation.
  • Chemical mediators, such as histamine, bradykinin, and leukotrienes, produce endothelial cell contraction, which is the immediate transient response.
  • This results in increased inter endothelial spaces - the common mechanism of vascular leakage.
  • In most cases, leakage starts immediately after injury and is sustained for several hours until the damaged vessels are repaired.
  • Increased transport of fluids and proteins through the endothelial cell, called transcytosis, also contributes to vascular leakage.

Option A: Chemical mediators such as histamine play a role in delayed vascular leakage.

  • Histamine plays a vital role in immediate transient response to vascular leakage.
  • The two major vasoactive amines, so named because they have important actions on blood vessels, are histamine and serotonin. 
  • They are stored as preformed molecules in cells and are, therefore, among the first mediators to be released during inflammation. 
  • The richest sources of hista­mine are the mast cells that are normally present in the connective tissue adjacent to blood vessels. 
  • It is also found in blood basophils and platelets. Histamine is stored in mast cell granules and is released by mast cell degranula­tion in response to a variety of stimuli, including (1) physi­cal injury, such as trauma, cold, or heat, by unknown mechanisms (2) binding of antibodies to mast cells, which underlies immediate hypersensitivity (allergic) reactions (3) products of complement called anaphylatoxins (C3a and C5a)

Option C: Transcytosis is not a contributing factor to vascular leakage.

  • Transcytosis is the increased transport of fluids and proteins through endothelial cells.
  • It plays a major role in increased vascular leakage by increased endothelial cell spacing. 

Option D: In most cases, vascular leakage starts several hours after injury.

  • Vascular leakage starts immediately after injury and is sustained for several hours until the damaged vessels are repaired.
  • Increased transport of fluids and proteins through the endothelial cell, called transcytosis, also contributes to vascular leakage

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a burn injury to his hands. He is vitally stable. He does not have any significant medical history. Over a few weeks, the burned skin heals without requiring skin grafting. Which of the following is the most critical factor responsible for rapid healing?
questions.solution:
Option A: Remnant skin appendages

  • The given scenario is a case of secondary intention healing.
  • The Adnexal structures(remnant skin appendages) contain epithelial cells which can proliferate and heal a partial thickness wound by epithelialization.
  • The skin consists of two layers.
    • The epidermis is the most superficial layer of the skin, constantly replaced by the basal layer
    • The dermis is thicker than the epidermis and contains adnexal structures.
  • Healing of a wound can occur in three ways:
    • Primary intention healing: Occurs when there is apposition of the wound edges and minimal surrounding tissue trauma that cause the least inflammation and leaves the best scar.
    • Secondary intention healing: Wounds are left open and allowed to heal by granulation, contraction and epithelialisation.
    • Tertiary intention (also called delayed Primary intention): Wound initially left open and edges later opposed when healing conditions are favourable.

Wound Healing - By Intention

Primary Intention

Clean wound with limited tissue loss Wounds edges easily approximated Classic surgical wound closure Using suture, staples, adhesive tape

Secondary Intention

Large tissue loss / heavy contamination Wound cleaned & left open to granulate Surgeon may pack & place drain Wound care q day promotes granulation

Tertiary Intention

Also called: Delayed primary closure Often used with heavy bacteria counts Wound is cleaned, debrided, left open Typically 4-5 days-then surgical closure

Option B: Underlying connective tissues

  • Underlying connective tissue provides strength to the wound.
  • In primary intention healing, connective tissue deposition is small, while in secondary healing, it is large
  • Moreover, it is not a contributing factor to the complete regeneration ability of the tissue.

Option C: Minimal oedema and erythema

  • Although signs of inflammation if minimum, it would mean that inflammation is not extensive and damage is less.
  • This would allow healing to occur faster.
  • However, complete regeneration depends on preserving the stem cells and not on the presence or absence of signs of inflammation.

Option D: Granulation tissue

  • Granulation tissue helps in the healing of a wound by secondary intention.
  • However, if stem cells are damaged, the wound repair will not be perfect, and granulation tissue will be transformed into a scar.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents with acute chest pain and shortness of breath. He describes the pain as heavy and diffuse. He is vitally stable. His medical history is consistent with hypertension and diabetes. His medications include amlodipine and metformin. Laboratory tests and EKG are consistent with acute myocardial infarction. Which of the following is the most likely pathological finding found in the affected heart muscle 4 weeks later?
questions.solution:
Option B: Collagen-rich scar tissue

  • In 4th week after the myocardial infarction, the tissue is largely replaced by collagen scar.

Morphology of myocardial infarction:

  • Early morphologic recognition of acute MI can be difficult, particularly when death occurs within only a few hours of symptom onset.
  • MIs less than 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination alone; however, if the infarct preceded death by at least 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to highlight the area of necrosis by immersion of tissue slices in a solution of triphenyl tetrazolium chloride.
  • This gross histochemical stain imparts a brick-red colour to intact, noninfarcted myocardium with preserved lactate dehydrogenase activity. Because dehydrogenases leak out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.
  • By 12 to 24 hours after infarction, an MI can usually be identified grossly as a reddish-blue area of discolouration caused by congestion and extravasated blood.
  • By 3 to 7 days, it is rimmed by a hyperemic zone of highly vascularised early wound healing (granulation tissue). After that, the infarct becomes progressively more sharply defined, yellow-tan, and soft. Over the succeeding weeks, the injured region evolves into a fibrous scar.
  • The histopathologic changes also proceed in a fairly predictable sequence.
  • The typical changes of coagulative necrosis become detectable in the first 6 to 12 hours. “Wavy fibres” may be present at the periphery of the infarct, resulting from the contractions of viable myocardium that cause the stretching and buckling of adjacent, noncontractile dead fibres.
  • An additional sublethal ischemic change may be seen in the margins of infarcts. This so-called myocyte vacuolisation reflects intracellular accumulations of salt and water within the sarcoplasmic reticulum, marking viable but poorly contractile myocytes. Necrotic myocardium elicits acute inflammation (typically most prominent 1 to 3 days after MI), followed by a wave of macrophages that remove necrotic myocytes and neutrophil fragments (most pronounced 3 to 7 days after MI).
  • The infarcted zone is progressively replaced by granulation tissue (most prominent 7 to 10 days after MI), which forms the temporary scaffolding on which dense collagenous scar forms; cardiac myocytes are terminally differentiated cells, and no cardiomyocyte proliferation is seen.
  • In most instances, scarring is well advanced by the end of the sixth week, but the efficiency of repair depends on the size of the original lesion and the ability of the host tissues to heal. Healing requires the migration of inflammatory cells and the ingrowth of new vessels from the infarct margins.
  • Thus, an MI heals from its borders toward the centre, and a large infarct may not heal as fast or as completely as a small one.
  • Moreover, malnutrition, poor vasculature, or exogenous anti-inflammatory steroids can impede effective infarct scarring.
  • Once an MI is completely healed, it is impossible to distinguish its age: whether present for 8 weeks or 10 years, fibrous scars look the same.

Option A: Capillary-rich granulation tissue

  • The granulation tissue dominates between 3-7 days of the myocardial infarction.

Option C: Granulomatous inflammation

  • Granulomatous inflammation is not seen in the heart after the myocardial infarction.
  • However, if it involves the myocardium, granuloma formation can be seen in diseases such as tuberculosis.

Option D: Neutrophils and necrotic debris

  • The neutrophils and necrotic tissues dominate in the first 24 hours of the myocardial infarction and are replaced by macrophages after 3 days.

questions.text: A pure protein derivative obtained from Mycobacterium tuberculosis is injected into the skin during the physical examination of a 22-year-old male. The injection site seems elevated and indurated three days later. In this patient's delayed hypersensitive initiation phase, which of the following glycoproteins was directly engaged in antigen presentation?
questions.solution:
Option D: Class II HLA molecules

  • The prototype of T cell-mediated inflammation is delayed-type hypersensitivity.
  • The classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity is the tuberculin reaction, which is produced by the intracutaneous injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. 
  • In previously sensitized individuals, reddening and induration of the site appear in the 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in the 24 to 72 hours, and thereafter slowly subside.
  • Delayed-type hypersensitivity is defined as a tissue reaction involving lymphocytes and mononuclear phagocytes, which occurs in response to a soluble protein antigen and reaches the greatest intensity 24 to 48 hours after the initiation phase.
  • In the initial phase, foreign protein antigens or chemical ligands interact with accessory cells bearing class II HLA molecules.
  • Protein antigens are actively processed into the short peptides within phagolysosomes and are presented on the cell surface in conjunction with the class II HLA molecules.

Option A: Class III HLA molecules

  • HLA/MHC class III genes produce proteins that play a part in inflammatory reactions, such as complement system components and tumor necrosis factors, not HLA proteins. 

Option B: Non-HLA-dependent antigen presentation

  • All exogenous antigens (e.g., bacterial proteins) are presented to CD4+ helper T cells via MHC-II.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Class I HLA molecules

  • Class I MHC molecules display peptides that are derived from proteins, such as viral and tumor antigens, that are located in the cytoplasm and usually produced in the cell, and class I associated peptides are recognized by CD8+ T lymphocytes. 
  • Cytoplasmic proteins are degraded in proteasomes, and peptides are transported into the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) where the peptides bind to newly synthesized class I molecules. 
  • Peptide-loaded MHC molecules associate with β2-microglobulin to form a stable trimer that is transported to the cell surface.

questions.text: The immune system has several specialized cell types to capture antigens and activate the naive T-cells.  Activation of the naive T-cells leads to an immune response.  Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T cells
questions.solution:
Option A: Dendritic cell

  • T cells are stimulated by the interaction of a T-cell receptor (TCR) with MHC-peptide complexes (MHCps) on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (APCs).  The T-cell stimulation is carried by many APCs, including macrophages, B-cells and dendritic cells.  Of these, the dendritic cells are the most potent APCs for stimulating the naive T cells.
  • The reversible antigen-independent binding mechanism allows naive T-cells to survey the dendritic cells for antigens and respond by forming clusters with dendritic cells.
  •   As a result of this contact between the dendritic cells and T-cells, stimulatory signals are delivered that allow the release of cytokines and chemokines.
  • In response to the microbes, the dendritic cells are recruited to the T-cell zones of the lymphoid organs, where they are ideally positioned to present antigens to the T-cells.
  • Dendritic cells (sometimes called interdigitating dendritic cells) are the most important antigen-presenting cells for initiating T-cell responses against protein antigens.  The following contribute to this:
    • First, these cells are located at the ideal site to capture the antigens: under epithelium, i.e. the common site of entry of microbes and foreign antigens) and in the interstitium of all tissues, where antigens may be produced.
    • Second, dendritic cells express high levels of MHC and other molecules needed for presenting antigens to and activating T cells.
    • Also, dendritic cells express many receptors for capturing and responding to microbes (and other antigens), including TLRs and receptors for C-type lectins.

Option B: Plasma cells

  • Plasma cells are the activated form of the B-cells responsible for producing antibodies.
  • However, they cannot act as APCs since they cannot switch antibody class and no longer display MHC-II molecules and therefore do not take up the antigen (as they no longer display a significant quantity of immunoglobulin on the cell surface).

Option C: Macrophages

  • Macrophages ingest the microbes and display peptides for recognition by the T-cells, which activate the macrophages to kill microbes and mediate the central reaction of cell-mediated immunity.
  • However, the dendritic cells actively participate through the rearrangement of their actin cytoskeleton in the stimulation of T-cells and induce an antigen-independent calcium signal and the polarization of signalling molecules.  Therefore, they are superior to the other APCs.

Option D: B-cells

  • B-cells present peptides to helper T-cells and receive signals that stimulate antibody responses to protein antigens, critical steps in humoral immune responses.
  • However, the dendritic cells actively contribute to the activation of T-cells by rearranging their actin cytoskeleton, resulting in an antigen-independent calcium signal and the polarization of signalling molecules.
  • They are, therefore, better than the other APCs.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with motor-dominant sensorimotor polyneuropathy, erectile dysfunction, and urinary incontinence. Transthyretin gene mutation was noted in genetic evaluation. The sural nerve biopsy specimen showed focal oedema and an amyloid deposit in the sub-perineural tissue, associated with moderate loss of myelinated and unmyelinated fibres. Which of the following disease is being described here?
questions.solution:
Option B: Familial amyloidosis polyneuropathy

  • Transthyretin (TTR) is a normal serum protein that binds and transports thyroxine and retinol.
  • Several distinct mutant forms of TTR (and its fragments) are deposited in a group of genetically determined disorders referred to as Familial Amyloid Polyneuropathies.
  • Normal TTR is also deposited (due to overproduction) in the heart of aged individuals (Senile Systemic Amyloidosis).

Option A: Familial Mediterranean fever

  • Familial Mediterranean fever is a genetic disorder that causes recurrent episodes of fever with
    • Abdominal pain
    • Chest discomfort
    • Joint pains.

Option C: Dialysis-associated amyloidosis

  • Age-related amyloidosis is mainly seen in chronic kidney disease and dialysis patients.
  • This patient has no chronic kidney disease, so this option is eliminated.
  • It is the main type of systemic amyloidosis.

Option D: Prion protein-associated amyloidosis

  • Prion diseases are our group of infectious, fatal, sporadic and genetically determined diseases in which prion protein PrP is accumulated in the nervous system of humans and mammals.

questions.text: A 61-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with dyspnea for the past 3 weeks. He also complains of hoarseness of voice and a tingling sensation in his right arm. His vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows temporal wasting, facial puffiness, and prominent chest veins. CT scan reveals a radio-opaque lesion measuring 5 x 4 cm in size over the apex of the right lung. A biopsy is taken for further evaluation under electron microscopy. Which of the following is the most common fixative used in electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
The correct option for the most common fixative used in electron microscopy is 1. Glutaraldehyde.

Explanation of the options:

  1. Glutaraldehyde: Glutaraldehyde is a widely used fixative in electron microscopy. It is a highly effective fixative for preserving cellular ultrastructure, especially for delicate structures like cell membranes and organelles. Glutaraldehyde works by cross-linking proteins and other biomolecules in the cells, preventing their degradation and preserving their structural integrity for electron microscopy analysis.

  2. Formalin: Formalin is a common fixative used in light microscopy, but it is not the primary choice for electron microscopy. It is mainly used for routine histological processing, where preservation of ultrastructural details is not a priority. Formalin fixation is not ideal for electron microscopy because it can cause significant distortion and damage to delicate cellular structures.

  3. Picric acid: Picric acid is a fixative used in histology, especially for tissues with high lipid content, such as the brain. It is not commonly used in electron microscopy because it can interfere with the quality of electron micrographs and cause artifacts.

  4. Absolute alcohol: Absolute alcohol is often used as a dehydrating agent in the tissue preparation process for electron microscopy but is not used as the primary fixative. Dehydration is typically performed after the fixation step to remove water from the tissues before embedding in resin for sectioning and imaging.
