questions.text: A 6-year-old child from a Punjabi family with a history of blood transfusions presents with haemoglobin of 4.5 g/dl, MCV is 70 fl, and RDW is 22. The peripheral smear reveals anisopoikilocytosis with microcytic hypochromic anaemia and target cells. The osmotic fragility is reduced too. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Beta thalassemia major

  • This patient with a history of blood transfusions, haemoglobin 4.5 g/dl, MCV is 70 fl, RDW is 22, anisopoikilocytosis with microcytic hypochromic anaemia and target cells, and reduced osmotic fragility most likely has Beta thalassemia major.
  • It is characterized by the following:
    • Severe hemolytic anaemia requiring repeated transfusions
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Skeletal deformities
    • Transient aplastic crisis
    • Growth retardation
  • The peripheral blood smear findings may include the following:
    • Target cells
    • Anisopoikiolocytosis
    • Inclusion bodies
  • Apart from Punjabis, other ethnic groups with a high prevalence of thalassemia are Sindhis, Gujaratis, Parsis, Bengalis and Lohanas.

Option A: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • This patient's history of repeated transfusion makes this diagnosis unlikely, as the need for such repeated transfusions is highly unlikely in iron deficiency anaemia.

Option C: Sickle cell anaemia

  • Reduced osmotic fragility may be seen in sickle cell anaemia,
  • But the absence of sickle cells on the patient's peripheral smear rules it out.

Option D: G6PD deficiency

  • It results in normocytic anaemia secondary to exposure to oxidizing agents in G6PD-deficient individuals.
  • This patient's reduced MCV effectively rules it out.

questions.text: A 71-year-old male patient presents with decreased appetite and weight loss for the last 8 months. He also complains of occasional fever and night sweats. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly is noted, and petechiae and ecchymosis are present throughout his body. He is diagnosed with a chronic phase of chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML). Which of the following is an expected lab finding in CML?
questions.solution:
Option B: Basophilia

  • Characteristic features of CML in CHRONIC PHASE
    • Massive splenomegaly
    • Hyperleukocytosis
    • Petechiae
    • Weight loss
    • Loss of appetite
  • Characteristic features of CML in ACCELERATED PHASE
    • Bleeding
    • Ecchymosis
    • Opportunistic Infection
  • Characteristic features of CML in BLAST PHASE
    • Fever
    • Bone pain
    • Bone marrow fibrosis

 

 

Option A: Auer rods

  • Auer rods (Auer bodies) are large, crystalline cytoplasmic inclusion bodies sometimes observed in myeloid blast cells during acute myeloid leukaemias, especially acute promyelocytic leukaemia, high-grade myelodysplastic syndromes and myeloproliferative disorders.

Option C: Increased LAP score

  • A high LAP score is seen in patients with leukemoid reactions.
  • Leukemoid reaction is an increase in WBC count, which can mimic leukaemia.

Option D: Bone marrow fibrosis

  • Myelofibrosis is an uncommon type of bone marrow cancer that decreases the production of all blood cells.
  • Bone marrow fibrosis is also seen in the blast phase of CML.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient comes to the emergency department with exertional dyspnea and fatigue. He also has joint pain in over the body. Within a few days, he expires. The myocardial lesions shown in the figure are observed at the autopsy examination of this patient, who had a history of bacterial pharyngitis many years before he died. During life, which of the following manifestations of his illness is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Chorea

  • The figure illustrates an Aschoff body, the characteristic lesion of rheumatic fever.
  • This myocardial lesion is often oval in shape and characterized by swollen, fragmented collagen and fibrinoid material, large mesenchymal cells (Anitschkow myocytes), and multinucleated cells (Aschoff cells).
  • Sydenham chorea is a major manifestation of rheumatic fever.

Option B: Janeway’s lesion

  • Janeway's lesions are non-tender, macular, and erythematous lesions on the palms and soles of the patient, as given in the image.
  • These are mostly present in the hand's thenar and hypothenar surface and the toes' plantar surface.
  • The duration is usually from days to weeks.
  • It is associated with acute infective endocarditis.

Option C: Systemic lupus erythematosus

  • Mitral and tricuspid valvulitis with small, sterile vegetations, called Libman-Sacks endocarditis, is occasionally encountered in systemic lupus erythematosus.
  • The lesions are small (1 to 4 mm in diameter), single or multiple, sterile, pink vegetations with a warty (verrucous) appearance.
  • They may be located on the undersurfaces of the atrioventricular valves, on the valvular endocardium, on the chords, or on the mural endocardium of the atria or ventricles.

Option D: Osler nodes

  • Osler nodes are tender, violaceous nodules typically located in the pulp of fingers and toes seen in the patient, as given in the image.
  • These are usually transient and removed within days.
  • It is associated with acute infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with end-stage renal disease. On examination, right eye lens dislocation is found. His maternal uncle also died of the same illness. On electron microscopy of renal biopsy, a basket-weave appearance of glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is seen. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Alport syndrome

  • Presentation of a male patient with lens dislocation, end-stage renal disease with a family history of renal disease, and a distinctive "basket-weave" appearance of glomerular basement membrane (GBM) s highly suggestive of Alport syndrome.
  • The following are characteristics of Alport syndrome:
  • Clinical signs consist of abnormalities related to the eyes, ears, and kidneys; mutations affecting the gene encoding for the type IV collagen alpha-5 chain.
  • The BM's distinctive basket-weave appearance.

Option A: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

  • AD polycystic kidney disease is ruled out because there is no association of ADPKD with lens dislocation, as is men­tioned in this case.​​​​​​​

Option B: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease

  • AR polycystic kidney disease is ruled out because the age of presentation in ARPKD is childhood, and most affected children do not survive beyond childhood.

Option C: Marfan's syndrome

  • Lens dislocation is also a feature of Marfan's syndrome, but it has no documented association with renal disease or renal disease-related death.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female comes to the outdoor patient department with presenting complaints of dysphagia and bilateral facial swelling. She complains of no weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations or sweating. Her Pulse rate is 74 beats/min. Her blood pressure is 130/90, her temperature is 98 F, and her RR is 19 breaths/min. The anterior neck mass (as shown in the image) is visible on physical examination. The mass is non-tender and nodular on palpation. Proptosis and lid lag is absent in the patient. On Serology, her TSH level is slightly lower than normal, her T3 and T4 levels are slightly raised, and no auto-antibody is seen. Which of the following is most likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Tall columnar cells with scalloped colloid

questions.solution:
Option D: Colloid-rich follicles

  • The given image shows swelling likely to be a Multinodular goitre. In diffuse non-toxic goitre over time, recurrent episodes of hyperplasia and involution combine to produce a more irregular enlargement of the thyroid, termed Multinodular goitre (MNG).
  • Dominant clinical features of multinodular goitre are those caused by mass effects, which may cause airway obstruction, dysphagia, and compression of large vessels in the neck and upper thorax (superior vena cava syndrome).
  • Most patients are euthyroid or have subclinical hyperthyroidism (identified by reduced TSH levels). Still, about 10% of patients over 10 years develop an autonomous nodule within a long-standing goitre that produces hyperthyroidism (toxic MNG), also known as Plummer Syndrome.
  • The microscopic appearance includes colloid-rich follicles lined by flattened, inactive epithelium and areas of follicle hyperplasia, accompanied by degenerative changes related to physical stress.
  • A radioiodine scan demonstrates uneven iodine uptake (including the occasional “hot” autonomous nodule), consistent with an admixture of hyperplastic and involuting nodules.
  • The incidence of malignancy in long-standing multinodular goitres is low (<5%) but not zero.

Option A: Tall columnar cells with scalloped colloid

  • Tall columnar cells with scalloped colloids are seen in Grave's Disease.
  • Graves disease is the most common cause of endogenous hyperthyroidism.
  • It is a type II hypersensitivity caused by the formation of antibodies against TSH receptors primarily.

Option B: Psammoma Bodies

  • Psammoma Bodies are seen in Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma.
  • It is caused mostly by RET/PTC rearrangements and BRAF mutations.
  • Other features are Orphan Annie cells and nuclear grooves.

Option C: Hurthle’s cells

  • Hurthle’s cells are enlarged eosinophilic follicular cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm usually seen in Follicular Carcinoma of the Thyroid and Hashimoto Thyroiditis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency room with progressive atrophy and weakness in his hands. On further examination, he is found to have brisk jaw jerk, fasciculations, spasticity of the lower leg and bulbar palsy. He is diagnosed with a case of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, which is caused by which of the following?

choices.text: Loss of upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.
Loss of dopaminergic neurons from the substantia nigra

questions.solution:
Option A: Loss of upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.

  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis/Lou Gehrig's disease
  • Progressive nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord results in loss of muscle control.
  • Loss of upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.
  • The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria in which there are both Upper and lower motor neuron signs with progressive disease.

Option B: Atrophy of the caudate nucleus

  • Degeneration & atrophy of the caudate nucleus is associated with Huntington's disease. 
  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder
  • It is a fatal, progressive degeneration and atrophy of the Striatum (Caudate nucleus and Putamen).
  • Characterised by an increased number of trinucleotide repeats (CAG) in the Huntington gene on the short arm of chromosome 4.

Option C: Loss of dopaminergic neurons from the substantia nigra

  • Parkinson's disease is characterised by a degenerative loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the basal ganglia.
  • In Parkinson's disease, histology reveals loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra and round, eosinophilic inclusions of an α-synuclein protein (Lewy bodies) in affected neurons.
  • Clinical features are tremors, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia and postural instability.
  • Dementia is a common feature of the late disease.
  • Early onset dementia is suggestive of “Lewy body dementia.”

Option D: Deposition of Tau protein

  • Tau is a microtubule-associated protein
  • Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular aggregates of fibres composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein
  • These are seen in Alzheimer's disease.
  • Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia.
  • Morphological features include cerebral atrophy with narrowing of the gyri, widening of sulci, and dilation of the ventricles.
  • Neuritic plaques are extracellular core comprised of Aβ amyloid with entangled neuritic processes.
  • Aβ amyloid is derived from amyloid precursor protein (APP) which normally undergoes alpha cleavage; beta cleavage results in Aβ amyloid.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular aggregates of fibres composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
  • Loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has had lethargy, headache and muscle weakness for 3 months; his parents notice that he is drinking too much water; his vital functions are normal; a 24-hour urine sample shows polyuria; Fasting blood sugar is normal. A brain x-ray shows suprasellar calcification. An autopsy specimen from a similar case is shown. Which of the following neoplasms is this patient's most likely cause of polyuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Craniopharyngioma

  • Given child is presenting with the features of diabetes insipidus
  • The given section of the brain shows a large cystic tumor mass replacing the midline structure in the hypothalamus region, along with a history point towards Craniopharyngioma.

Central diabetes inspidus:

  • Central diabetes insipidus (CDI) is characterized by decreased release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH; also called arginine vasopressin or AVP), resulting in a variable degree of polyuria.
  • Lack of ADH can be caused by disorders that act at one or more of the sites involved in ADH secretion: the hypothalamic osmoreceptors; the supraoptic or paraventricular nuclei; or the superior portion of the supraoptic ohypophyseal tract.
  • By contrast, damage to the tract below the median eminence or the posterior pituitary generally causes only transient polyuria because ADH produced in the hypothalamus can still be secreted into the systemic circulation via the portal capillaries in the median eminence

Causes:

  • The most common causes of central diabetes insipidus (CDI), accounting for the vast majority of cases, are idiopathic diabetes insipidus (DI), primary or secondary tumours or infiltrative diseases (such as Langerhans cell histiocytosis), neurosurgery, and trauma.
  • In a report of 79 children and young adults, for example, CDI was idiopathic in 52 per cent and resulted from a tumour or infiltrative disease in 38 per cent.
  • In another cohort of 147 children followed from 2000 to 2013 in a single North American centre, the most common single diagnosis was Craniopharyngioma (25.2 per cent)

Other options

Option B: Glioblastoma multiforme

  • Glioblastoma multiforme does not present with the central diabetes insipidus
  • GBM can cause refractory seizures

Option C: Pheochromocytoma

  • Pheochromocytoma presents with episodic hypertension.
  • Other features are hyperglycemia and elevated haemoglobin.

Option D: Pituitary adenoma

  • Pituitary adenoma rarely causes CDI.
  • Rather it presents with the symptoms of hypothyroidism, hypocortisolism and hypogonadism

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman, currently at 22 weeks gestation and with no known health issues, is planning a trip to Mozambique to visit her grandmother. During a prenatal check-up, the doctor prescribed mefloquine, a drug with high protein binding, for prophylaxis. What effects can be anticipated after the ingestion of this drug?
questions.solution:
Option A: Decreased glomerular filtration

  • This is a case of malarial prophylaxis in which a pregnant patient presents to the gynaecologist for a prenatal visit.
  • The abdominal examination of the patient is consistent with a uterus at 22 weeks gestation.
  • The patient wants to visit Mozambique to meet her grandmother. So, in such areas, there is a high chance that the patient will come in contact with a malarial parasite.
  • The doctor advised mefloquine to the patient for prophylaxis against malarial parasites.
  • Mefloquine is an antimalarial drug which acts on the erythrocytic stage and is used as a prophylactic suppressive agent. It is a compound with high plasma protein binding capacity.
  • High plasma protein binding leads to decreased glomerular filtration, as proteins being large in size and negatively charged, are not filtered through the glomerulus.

Option B: High volume of distribution

  • Mefloquine has a low volume of distribution.
  • High protein binding leads to a low volume of distribution into tissues as the protein-bound drug does not cross membranes.

Option C: Lowers duration of action

  • Mefloquine has an increased duration of action.
  • It is because the high protein binding of this drug leads to an increased duration of action, as only free drugs can be metabolised or excreted quickly.

Option D: Less drug interaction

  • Mefloquine has more drug interactions.
  • High plasma protein binding leads to more drug interactions, as there are higher chances of drugs getting displaced.

questions.text: Three days after starting a new drug for malaria prophylaxis, a 19-year-old college student had dark-colored urine and fatigue, scleral icterus, and poikilocytes with bite-shaped irregularities. Which drugs will the patient most likely be taking?
questions.solution:
Option C: Primaquine

  • This patient's hemolytic anaemia and bite cells on the peripheral smear suggest underlying G6PD deficiency. In patients with G6PD deficiency, hemolytic anaemia can be triggered by infections, fava beans, and certain drugs (including sulfa drugs and antimalarials).
  • G6PD deficiency:
    • G6PD is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway (also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt). This pathway yields NADPH, essential for converting oxidised glutathione back to its reduced form. Reduced glutathione can neutralise reactive oxygen species (ROS) and free radicals, protecting RBCs from oxidative damage. 

  • In its reduced form (GSH), glutathione detoxifies free radicals and peroxides (here, hydrogen peroxide, H2O2, on the right). This reaction is catalysed by glutathione peroxidase and oxidised glutathione (GSSG) and water (H2O).
  • To convert the GSSG back to GSH, the catalysing enzyme glutathione reductase requires NADPH (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate hydrogen).
  • One possible pathway that yields NADPH for reductive reactions is the pentose phosphate pathway (hexose monophosphate shunt).
  • The glucose-6-P-dehydrogenase (G6PD) oxidises glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate and reduces NADP to NADPH.
  • Without reduced glutathione (e.g., G6PD deficiency), RBCs become susceptible to oxidative stress that can damage erythrocyte membranes, resulting in intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.
  • Causes of increased oxidative stress are triggers of hemolytic crisis and include:
    • Fava beans
    • Drugs: antimalarial drugs (e.g., chloroquine, primaquine), sulfa drugs (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), nitrofurantoin, isoniazid, dapsone, NSAIDs, ciprofloxacin, chloramphenicol
    • Bacterial and viral infections (most common cause): Severe enzymatic deficiency can inhibit respiratory burst activity due to reduced NADPH production in phagocytes. 
    • Inflammation: During an inflammatory reaction, free radicals are produced and can diffuse into RBCs.
    • Metabolic acidosis
  • Most patients are asymptomatic.
  • Recurring hemolytic crises may occur, especially following triggers
    • Arise within 2–3 days after increased oxidative stress [3]
    • Sudden onset of back or abdominal pain
    • Jaundice
    • Dark urine 
    • Transient splenomegaly
  • Recurrent severe infections causing symptoms of chronic granulomatous disease
  • Primaquine is an antimalarial used for malaria prophylaxis that causes oxidative stress in RBCs and can precipitate hemolytic anaemia in individuals with G6PD deficiency, as seen in this case.
  • Bite cells and Heinz bodies are characteristic blood smear findings. Primaquine is contraindicated in patients with known G6PD deficiency.

Option A: Metronidazole

  • Metronidazole is a bactericidal and antiprotozoal antibiotic that forms toxic free radical metabolites in the bacterial cell that damage DNA.
  • Treats Giardia, Entamoeba, Trichomonas, Gardnerella vaginalis, and Anaerobes (Bacteroides, C difficile). It can be used in place of amoxicillin in H pylori "triple therapy” in case of penicillin allergy.
  • Its adverse effects include:
  • Disulfiram-like reaction (severe flushing, tachycardia, hypotension) with alcohol; headache, metallic taste.
  • G6PD deficiency is not an adverse effect of Metronidazole.

Option B: Albuterol

  • Albuterol is a beta2 agonist that stimulates β2 adrenergic receptors and relaxes bronchial smooth muscles.
  • Its adverse effects include:
  • Cardiac: ventricular arrhythmias, vasoconstriction, angina pectoris, tachycardia, and palpitations; may aggravate cardiomyopathy in patients with cardiovascular disease.
  • Central nervous system/muscular: tremor, headache, anxiety, and sleep disturbances 
  • Hyperglycemia 
  • Hypokalemia 
  • It does not cause hemolysis in G6PD deficiency.

Option D: Erythromycin

  • Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic active against gram-positive and some gram-negative bacteria. Acts by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis after binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome.
  • Used to treat respiratory, gastrointestinal, genital tract, skin, and soft tissue infections.
  • Its adverse effects include:
  • Increased intestinal motility causing GI upset
  • QT-interval prolongation, arrhythmia
  • Acute cholestatic hepatitis
  • Eosinophilia
  • Rash
  • It does not cause hemolysis in G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. For further examination of the eyes, the doctor had to pick cycloplegic drops to ensure that the patient did not develop posterior synechiae; which of the following difference between hyoscine and atropine must the doctor remember well?

choices.text: Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses
Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye
Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

questions.solution:
Option A: Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses

  • This is a case of reactive arthritis in which the patient presents with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • The above-mentioned clinical feature suggests reactive arthritis.
  • The diagnosis of reactive arthritis is usually made clinically.
  • For further examination of the eye, the doctor had to use cycloplegic drops.
  • To ensure the patient doesn't develop posterior synechia, the doctor must know that hyoscine exerts a depressant effect on the CNS at relatively low doses.

Option B: Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye

  • Hyoscine doesn’t exert more potent effects on the heart than on the eye.
  • It has a more potent effect on the eye and the secretory glands.

Option C: Hyoscine is longer acting

  • Hyoscine is a very short-acting drug.
  • Atropine is a long-acting drug.

Option D: Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

  • Hyoscine has a strong anti-motion sickness activity.
  • It is most commonly used to prevent motion sickness.
  • It can also be used for the reduction of saliva in the mouth.

questions.text: Which of the following beta blockers are the most selective towards the beta-1 receptor?
questions.solution:
Option D: Nevibolol

  • The patient is taking an unknown selected Beta blocker, due to which she is experiencing shortness of breath and dry cough as beta receptors are everywhere in the body.
  • Nebivolol is a selective Beta blocker. used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure.
  • Nebivolol is a highly selective beta-blocker with nonadrenergic vasodilating properties.
  • It has been approved to treat essential hypertension and congestive heart failure.
  • Nebivolol (Bystolic) is a cardioselective beta 1 (beta (1))-adrenergic receptor blocker with endothelium-dependent vasodilating properties.
  • The endothelium-dependent relaxation induced by nebivolol is blocked by inhibitors of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) and guanylate cyclase.
  • Selective beta 1 antagonists:
    • New –Nebivolol (Most selective beta 1 antagonist)
    • Beta– Betaxolol
    • Blockers- Bisoprolol
    • Act – Atenolol
    • Exclusively- Esmolol
    • At – Acebutolol
    • Myo – Metoprolol
    • Cardium – Celiprolol

Option A: Acebutolol

  • It is a cardioselective beta blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA).
  • Beta-blockers with ISA mimic the effects of epinephrine and norepinephrine and can cause an increase in blood pressure and heart rate.

Option B: Atenolol

  • Atenolol is a "cardioselective" beta-adrenoceptor antagonist. It selectively inhibits beta-1 receptors with little affinity for the beta-2 receptor subtype.
  • Atenolol does not have membrane-stabilizing or intrinsic sympathomimetic activities.

Option C: Metoprolol

  • Metoprolol is indicated alone or with other medicines to manage high blood pressure.
  • It is a selective beta blocker that acts on the myocardium but has little or no activity against beta-2 adrenergic receptors found on bronchial and vascular smooth muscle.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden shortness of breath for one hour. He gives no history of any other abnormalities or any chronic illness. After further investigation and examinations, the patient is diagnosed with acute congestive heart failure. He is given intravenous digoxin in the emergency. A few minutes later, the patient developed an irregular pulse consistent with ventricular arrhythmia. Which of the following monovalent cation would reverse the effects of toxicity of the drug involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Potassium

  • The patient in the case presented with acute onset of dyspnea and was diagnosed with acute compensated heart failure. He was given digoxin but soon developed toxicity and had ventricular arrhythmia. 
  • Digitalis is a cardiac glycoside that causes positive inotropic effects by acting on Na/K ATPase.
  • A monovalent cation (K+), potassium can undo a digitalis-induced arrhythmia.
  • Potassium and digitalis compete to bind on the same receptor present on Na+/K+ ATPase on the cell membrane.
  • Digitalis toxicity is exacerbated by hypokalemia and hypercalcemia.
  • Hyperkalemia decreases digitalis toxicity.
  • Acceleration of the storage of intracellular calcium appears to be responsible for abnormal automaticity induced by digitalis.
  • Hypercalcemia thus increases the chances of digitalis-induced arrhythmia.

Option A: Digibind antibodies

  • They are used in severe digitalis toxicity, which is characterized by neurological symptoms, nausea and anorexia.

Option B: Lignocaine

  • Lignocaine can be used for digitalis-induced arrhythmia.
  • But this drug has a risk of causing heart block in such cases.

Option C: Magnesium

  • Mg2+ has the opposite effect as Ca2+. Therefore, hypomagnesemia increases the risk of arrhythmias, whereas increased magnesium levels reduce the risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of the calcium channel blockers?
questions.solution:
Option D: Headache

  • In the clinical scenario, the patient has blurred vision, nausea, palpitations, and high blood pressure. She also has a positive family history, suggesting a diagnosis of hypertension.
  • Calcium channel blockers (CCB) form the first line of treatment against hypertension.
  • Nifedipine is the best and most frequently used CCB.
  • Headache is the most common side effect of nifedipine.
  • Some common side effects of CCB:
    • Flushing
    • Constipation
    • Fast heartbeat (palpitations)
    • Dizziness
    • Nausea
    • Fatigue
    • Headache
    • Rash

Option A: Nausea

  • Nausea is a common side-effect of many drugs.
  • However, it is not usually reported with CCBs.

Option B: Constipation

  • Constipation is also seen in patients who are given CCB.
  • It occurs by inhibition of smooth muscles by calcium blockade.
  • However, it is not as common as headaches.

Option C: Postural hypotension

  • Postural hypotension is an episode of hypotension due to venous pooling on a posture change.
  • It is more common with alpha-antagonist drugs such as prazosin.
  • It is not seen with CCBs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient, an already diagnosed case of chronic congestive heart failure, is currently on medication. While reviewing medications, you notice that the patient is taking eplerenone. Which of the following is the clinical indication of eplerenone in this patient?

choices.text: Able to cause hypokalemia in predisposed patients

questions.solution:
Option C: It reduces myocardial perfusion defect

  • Eplerenone has been found to reduce myocardial perfusion defects after myocardial infarction.
  • It reduces the mortality rate by 15% compared to a placebo in patients with mild to moderate heart failure after myocardial infarction.

Option A: It is an aldosterone agonist

  • Eplerenone is an aldosterone antagonist (like spironolactone).

Option B: Able to cause hypokalemia in predisposed patients

  • It is a potassium-sparing diuretic and can cause hyperkalemia in susceptible individuals, particularly in patients on ACE inhibitors.

Option D: It can cause gynecomastia

  • Eplerenone binds less avidly to androgen and progesterone receptors as compared to spironolactone.
  • Therefore, it produces less likely endocrine effects like gynecomastia.

questions.text: What medication is recommended for a 55-year-old female presenting to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of progressive shortness of breath, chest tightness, and a 2-month history of intermittent nonproductive cough? The patient, a former smoker with a history of cardiovascular disease and current propranolol use, is anxious, unable to speak in full sentences, and works at a cattle ranch.
questions.solution:
Option D: Ipratropium bromide

  • Based on her history, this patient most likely has nonallergic asthma. The management of asthma involves the use of bronchodilators and anti-inflammatory drugs.
  • The main classes of drugs are summarised in the following table:

  • Inhaled β2 agonists are the drug of choice to terminate an acute bronchial asthma attack.
  • However, as the patient receives a β-blockers (propranolol), treatment with β2 agonists will be ineffective (receptors are already blocked).
  • Therefore, other bronchodilators like anti-cholinergic agents (ipratropium) or methylxanthines (theophylline) will be useful in such a case.

Option A: Cromolyn sodium

  • Cromolyn inhibits mast cell degranulation and the release of histamine. It is used to prevent future asthma attacks. However, it is not used in acute asthma exacerbation.

Option B: Salbutamol

  • Salbutamol is a short acting beta agonist. This is considered a drug of choice for treating acute asthmatic attacks. However, this the patient is receiving a β-blockers (propranolol), treatment with β2 agonists will be ineffective because the beta receptors are already blocked.

Option C: Beclomethasone

  • Beclomethasone is a steroid commonly used for the treatment of chronic asthma. However, it would not be beneficial to terminate the acute asthmatic attack.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the drugs Quinupristin and Dalfopristin?

choices.text: They are inactive against methicillin-resistant staphylococci
These are highly effective against Enterococcus faecialis
They induce the formation of hepatic drug-metabolizing enzymes
They are used in the management of infections caused by vancomycin-resistant enterococci

questions.solution:
Option D: They are used in the management of infections caused by vancomycin-resistant enterococci

  • Quinupristine binds to the 50th subunit of the ribosome and acts as a macrolide drug, thereby inhibiting translocation and protein synthesis in sensitive bacteria.
  • Dalfopristin also binds to the 50th subunit of the ribosome and induces a conformational change, thereby increasing the activity of quinupristin. Synergistic activity can produce bactericidal effects on sensitive bacteria.
  • Quinpristin and dalfopristin are a combination of Streptogramins.
  • Rapidly Bactericidal for most susceptible organisms except Enterococcus faecium, which is killed slowly.
  • Quinpristin is Streptogramin B, while Dalfopristin is Streptogramin A.
  • They bind to 50S Ribosomal RNA and inhibit protein synthesis.
  • They are active against - Gram-positive cocci, including Multidrug-resistant strains of Streptococci, Penicillin-resistant strains of S. pneumoniae, Methicillin susceptible and resistant strains of Staphylococci, and E.faecium (but not Enterococcus faecalis).
  • Quinupristin-dalfopristin is effective against (MRSA), nosocomial pneumococcal, and vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) infections.
  • Resistance is due to modification of the Quinupristin binding site (MLS-B type resistance), enzymatic inactivation of dalfopristin, or efflux.

Option A: They are inactive against methicillin-resistant staphylococci

  • These are effective against methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

Option B: These are highly effective against Enterococcus faecialis

  • Quinupristin-dalfopristin is approved for treating infections caused by staphylococcus or by vancomycin-resistant strains of E. faecium, not E. faecalis, which is intrinsically resistant, probably because of an efflux-type resistance mechanism.

Option C: They induce the formation of hepatic drug-metabolizing enzymes

  • Streptogramins like quinupristin and dalfopristin possess microsomal enzyme inhibitory property

questions.text: A 47-year-old man who underwent renal transplant 8 months ago comes to the nephrologist complaining of severe pain at the site of operation and is unable to pass urine. He also revealed that he had discontinued the medications which were prescribed to him post-transplant. His blood pressure was 180/110mm Hg and lab investigations showed the creatinine level to be 5.5 mg/dL. Which of the following medications was likely prescribed post-transplant to him?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cyclosporine

  • The patient, in this case, is a renal transplant recipient having symptoms of chronic graft rejection.
  • Chronic graft rejection occurs approximately 6months after an organ transplant.
  • The patient has severe hypertension, renal dysfunction and obstructive uropathy.
  • This may be due to poor HLA matching, previous acute rejections and inadequate immunosuppression.
  • The patient has stopped taking an Immunosuppressant due to graft rejection.
  • For this purpose, cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant used to prevent organ rejection instead of anticancer treatment.
  • Cyclosporine acts by inhibiting the transcription of the IL-2 gene.
  • It has no anticancer properties.
  • It prevents organ rejection in kidney, liver or heart transplant patients.
  • It acts as a calcineurin inhibitor.

Option A: Cyclophosphamide

  • Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent used for anticancer purposes.
  • It can be used alone in susceptible malignancies but is often used in combination with other neoplastic drugs.
  • It is also used as an immunosuppressant.

Option C: Methotrexate

  • All antimetabolites, including methotrexate and 6-MP, are used as anticancer drugs except azathioprine.
  • Methotrexate is used as first-line adjuvant therapy in combination with other drugs.

Option D: 6-Mercaptopurine

  • All antimetabolites, including methotrexate and 6-MP, are used as anticancer drugs except azathioprine.
  • Used in first-line therapy for drug-induced remission in ALL patients.
  • Used for Crohn’s disease.
  • Used in the treatment of ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: Which recently approved drug has shown significant reduction in disease progression in a 53-year-old male with diabetes and hypertension presenting with nausea, vomiting, shortness of breath, altered taste sensation, blurred vision, diarrhea, extreme weakness, and worsening lower extremity edema, along with markedly elevated urea and creatinine levels?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dapagliflozin

  • Dapagliflozin, an SGLT-2 inhibitor, recently got approval for use in CKD patients, as it was found to reduce the progression of CKD in patients with and without diabetes (decline in GFR values lesser, when compared to placebo).
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors are now being used as an additional drug for cases of HFrEF, too.
  • This patient’s long-standing history of hypertension and diabetes and markedly abnormal laboratory findings (BUN, creatinine) and oedema suggest CKD

Option A: Sotagliflozin

  • Sotagliflozin is an orally administered dual SGLT1/2 inhibitor used alongside insulin to improve glycemic control in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • While only SGLT2 inhibitors have emerged as a key disease-modifying therapy to prevent the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD).

Option B: Telmisartan

  • Telmisartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker
  • Telmisartan effectively and safely reduces proteinuria in chronic kidney disease patients
  • But it is not a recently approved drug for CKD

Option D: Valsartan

  • Valsartan is an Angiotensin receptor blocker
  • Suppression of the renin-angiotensin system is known to slow the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
  • But it is not a recently approved drug for CKD

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents to the outdoor patient department with complaints of multiple joint pain and occasional itching in the forearm. The doctor orders a battery of tests and notices that the serum uric acid is around 10 mg/mL. He instructs the patient to consume a purine-free diet and prescribes a uricosuric drug. Which of the following is that drug?
questions.solution:
Option A: Probenecid

  • In comparison to drugs that target urate synthesis, uricosurics are considered to be a secondary therapy option for individuals who have an excessive amount of urate in their bodies or who suffer from tophaceous illness.
  • Probenecid is the uricosuric agent that is utilized most frequently. This is a very effective medication that both concentrates and encourages the excretion of urate through the urinary tract.
  • In individuals who have renal insufficiency, its usefulness is restricted, and probenecid is not advised as an initial treatment for patients who have nephrolithiasis or uric acid overexcretion.
  • The uricosuric drugs are intended to be used to treat hyperuricemia that is caused by "inefficient renal excretion" (IRE) of uric acid. This condition, which is more commonly referred to as "underexcretion" these days, refers to the fact that the renal excretion of uric acid does not correspond to the amount that would be expected based on the levels of serum urate concentration (SUR) and glomerular filtration, or the filtered load.

Option B: Allopurinol

  • Allopurinol is not a uricosuric agent. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor.

Option C: Zyloprim

  • Zyloprim is not a uricosuric agent. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor.

Option D: Febuxostat

  • Febuxostat is not a uricosuric agent. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor.

questions.text: In most prokaryotic cells, glycocalyx forms a protective layer external to the cell wall called the capsule. A capsule is a negatively charged and smooth structure of a prokaryotic cell that prevents the adhesion of phagocytes and the engulfment of invading bacteria by the cells of the host immune system. Which of the following microorganisms lack this protective mechanism?
questions.solution:
Option D: Proteus

  • As mentioned in the question, the capsule provides the protective mechanism against the host immune system, and 'a-capsular' microorganisms lack the capsule and, therefore, the protection it provides.
  • A capsule is a well-organized polysaccharide layer outside the cell envelope.
    • It protects the host immune system and can cause various diseases.
    • It is found both in gram-positive and gram-negative microorganisms.
  • Based on the presence and absence of the capsule, microorganisms are categorized into encapsulated and non-encapsulated.
    • Encapsulated gram-negative bacteria include E. coli, Neisseria meningitides (meningococcus), Klebsiella pneumoniae, H. influenzae, Salmonella, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
    • Encapsulated gram-positive bacteria include Bacillus anthracis, Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus), Streptococcus agalactiae, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Staphylococcus aureus, and Lactococcus garvieae.
    • However, proteus is a non-encapsulated gram-negative microorganism.

Option A: Pneumococcus

  • Pneumococcus (Streptococcus pneumoniae) is an encapsulated gram-positive coccus.

Option B: Cryptococcus

  • Cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast.

Option C: Meningococcus

  • Meningococcus (Neisseria meningitidis) is an encapsulated gram-negative microorganism.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of repeated episodes of diarrhoea and fever for 1 week. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The doctor sent the patient for stool examination and culture in the microbiology laboratory, which revealed a salmonella infection. In the laboratory, what screening procedure is used to differentiate the organism involved in the patient's pathology from other Enterobacteriaceae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option B: Inability to ferment lactose

  • This is a case of infectious diarrhoea, in which the patient presents with a complaint of fever and diarrhoea for 1 week.
  • It is caused by salmonella.
  • The inability to ferment lactose differentiates salmonella and shigella from other Enterobacteriaceae.
  • Enterobacteriaceae properties:
    • Ferments glucose
    • Reduces nitrate to nitrite
    • Oxidase test negative
    • Catalase positive (except Shigella dysenteriae type-1)
    • Motile, except Shigella and Klebsiella.

Other Options

Option A: Inability to ferment glucose

  • Glucose fermenters include:
    • Enterobacteriaceae
    • Salmonella
    • Shigella

Option C: Produce cytochrome oxidase

  • Enterobacteriaceae and salmonella can produce cytochrome oxidase; on this basis, it is not differentiated from salmonella.

Option D: Reduce nitrates

  • The bacteria which can reduce nitrates include:
    • Lactobacillus brevis 
    • Lactobacillus fermentum
    • Lactobacillus acidophilus
    • Lactobacillus plantarum

questions.text: An intern recently posted for laboratory work in the hospital saw a doctor working on different types of agar. While working in the lab, he noticed a nutrient agar showing a peculiar pattern, and he asked the microbiologist about it, and he told him that it was an 'Oil paint appearance' of a particular pathogenic colony. The probable pathogen is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Staphylococcus aureus

  • Staphylococcus is a facultative anaerobe.
  • The optimum pH for growth is 7.4-7.6, and the optimum temperature is 37°C.
  • Staph aureus produces golden yellow pigment, which is maximum at 22°C.
  • Most of the staphylococcus species grow in the presence of 10% NaCl.
  • Staph aureus appearance in different types of agar:
    • The nutrient agar slope shows an " oil paint appearance."
    • Blood Agar shows Beta hemolysis.
    • Mac Conkey's Agar - pink LF colonies.
    • Broth media - Salt- milk broth, Ludam's medium - uniform turbidity

Option A: Streptococcus pyogenes

  • They grow best on blood agar.
  • Pyogenes colonies are dome-shaped with smooth surfaces and clear margins.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option C: Bordetella pertussis

  • It appears smooth, pearly and glistening, convex, greyish-white, and butyrous on charcoal blood agar with cephalexin.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option D: Hemophilus influenza

  • Hemophilus influenza grows best on chocolate agar.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient presents with fever, vomiting, neck rigidity, and rash to the doctor. He has no other medical conditions. The doctor sends the patient lab tests. On sample microscopy, lens-shaped gram-negative cocci are seen. Biochemical tests of this organism show glucose and maltose fermentation. What is the most dreadful complication in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option D: Water House Friderichsen syndrome

  • This clinical scenario and sample microscopy indicate Meningococcal meningitis. Maltose and glucose fermentation is specific for this class of bacteria. Fever, vomiting, headache, neck rigidity, and rash are typical symptoms.
  • Meningococci spreads by droplet infections in which the lungs are involved. Meningitis is the inflammation of the protective membrane covering the brain or spinal cord. Bacterial meningitis is rare but is more deadly.
  • It also has a haematogenous spread. It belongs to the gram-negative encapsulated bacteria that are very dangerous.
  • The Most common severe complication of Meningococcus infection is Water House Friderichsen syndrome causing bilateral adrenal hemorrhagic necrosis. In this syndrome, adrenal glands fail to function normally.

Other Options

Option A: Water-can perineum

  • It is a condition that results in the multiple fistulae extending from the urethra to open inside the perineum.
  • They can result as a result of chronic inflammatory strictures. They are primarily seen in gonorrheal infections.

Option B: Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome

  • It is a syndrome in which inflammation of the liver capsule occurs associated with adhesion formation, resulting in pain in the right upper quadrant.

Option C: Polyarthritis

  • It is used when at least five or more joints are involved with pain and discomfort. Swelling, warmth, and redness are typical physical presentations.
  • This condition is mainly caused by an auto-immune disease such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematous. But it can also be caused due to alphavirus.

questions.text: A patient made a self-diagnosis of an athlete's foot and began using a product advertised on TV. The condition improved but did not clear, and the patient showed himself to a Dermatologist. A skin scraping was sent for culture, including culture for fungi. The fungal culture yielded a slow-growing colony, which produces abundant microconidia. Which of the following dermatophyte is the causative agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Trichophyton  

  • Trichophyton causes superficial mycoses.
  • It mainly affects cutaneous tissues.
  • Humans and animals are natural reservoirs for this fungus.
  • Macroscopic examination of the trichophyton colonies shows powdery, waxy or velvety growths, with pigmentation characteristic of different species of this fungus.
  • Microscopic examination of trichophyton colonies shows microconidia and macroconidia.
  • Microconidia are abundant. They are arranged in clusters along the hyphae or borne on conidiophores.
  • Macroconidia are relatively scant. They are generally thin, elongated with blunt ends and have distinctive shapes in different species.
  •  Trichophyton rubrum is the most common cause of chronic, treatment-resistant lesions in humans.

Microconidia Trichophyton :

 

 

Macroconidia Trichophyton

 

 

 

Option B: Microsporum

  • Microsporum is a superficial dermatophyte.
  • The Microsporum genus has different anthropophilic, zoophilic and geophilic species.
  • Macroscopic examination of Microsporum colonies shows cotton-like, powdery, or velvety growths. Colonies show brown to white pigmentation.
  • Microconidia and macroconidia are seen on microscopic examination of Microsporum growths in a culture media.
  • Microconidia are relatively scanty.
  • Macroconidia of Microsporum fungus are large, multicellular, spindle-shaped structures. They are present singly on the ends of hyphae.

 

Macroconidia Microsporum:

 

Option C: Epidermophyton

  • Epidermophyton causes superficial mycoses of the skin and hair.
  • They are mainly anthropophilic fungi.
  • Epidermophyton colonies are powdery and produce greenish-yellow pigments.
  • This fungus does not produce microconidia.
  • Macroconidia seen on microscopic examination of the cultures are multicellular, pear-shaped, and typically arranged in clusters.

 

Macroconidia Epidermophyton:

Option D: Trichosporon

  • Trichosporon is a genus of anamorphic fungi.
  • This fungus is typically found in the soil.
  • White piedra is a condition caused by the proliferation of trichophyton fungus in the hair.
  • This genus has no sexual states.
  • Microscopically, trichosporon species have characteristic yeast cells germinating to produce hyaline hyphae.
  • Hyaline hyphae disarticulate at the septa. Hyphal compartments act as arthroconidia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with complaints of fever, body aches, and fatigue. He further explains that during his travel, he stayed with immigrants who had recently returned from Africa, where some of whom were sick and had fevers. The patient also added that the living conditions were poor, and many mosquitoes were present. What is the infective stage of malaria injected into the patient by the mosquito?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option A: Sporozoite 

  • In the above-given condition, the fever with chills, body aches, recent travel history, and close contact with malaria-positive people with poor living conditions are suggestive of the diagnosis of malaria.

  • Plasmodium parasite causes malaria, which is transmitted by the female Anopheles mosquito.

  • Anopheles mosquito transmits sporozoites into human blood.

  • Sporozoites reach the liver and invade hepatocytes and divide to form multinucleated schizonts.

    • Female anopheles mosquito: definitive host.

    • Man: intermediate host.

    • In malaria infective stage for humans is sporozoites.

Other Options

Option B: Merozoite

  • It is a motile and infective stage.

  • Merozoites enter erythrocytes, where they mature into trophozoites which is a feeding stage of Plasmodium.

  • The release of merozoites in the blood can cause fever.

Option C: Cryptozoite

  • The nucleus of the schizont asexually multiplies and forms merozoites.

  • Cyptozoites is a developmental stage of Plasmodium which lives in tissue cells.

Option D: Gametocyte

  • Gametocytes are sexual precursor cells.

  • These cells mediate the transmission of Plasmodium from the mammalian host to the mosquito.

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was brought to the clinic by his mother complaining of diarrhoea, runny nose, fever and the appearance of an erythematous rash on the face and pain in the upper limbs. The mother also gives a history of blood transfusion in her antenatal period. On physical examination, there is dehydration and a bright red rash on the cheeks. Which of the following is related to the given condition?

choices.text: Affects erythroid progenitors but individuals who totally lack Blood GroupP. Antigen are resistant to infection

questions.solution:
Option D: Affects erythroid progenitors but individuals who totally lack Blood Group P. Antigen are resistant to infection 

  • Parvovirus affects erythroid progenitor cells but only in those individuals who totally lack blood group P antigen.
  • They are resistant to infection as they infect only individuals with sickle cells, causing an aplastic crisis.
  • Parvoviruses are the smallest viruses. They are DNA viruses.
  • They belong to the family Parvoviridae; they are Icosahedral, non-enveloped viruses.
  • It is single-stranded DNA.
  • Shows tropism for erythroid progenitor cells. → aplastic crises in Sickle cell anemic Patients
  • Tropism for RBCs: It infects RBC precursors by using P blood group Ag as a receptor.
  • Transmission: Most commonly by the respiratory route, followed by blood transfusion and transplacental transmission (occurs in 30% of cases with maximum risk in the second trimester).
  • Associated with: NIHF (non-immune hydrops fetalis).
  • Polyarthralgia syndrome- Pain is more in upper limb joints than lower limb joints.
  • Erythema infectiosum /5th disease- slapped check appearance.

Option A:  <10% spread by transplacental route

  • The most common mode of transmission is the respiratory route.
  • The transplacental transmission occurs in 30% of cases with maximum risk in the second trimester.

Option B: Parvovirus B19 exclusively infects animals

  • Parvovirus only infects humans.
  • It is transmitted from mother to baby via the transplacental route.

Option C: It is an RNA virus

  • It is not a DNA virus.
  • Parvovirus is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever, red and tender skin, and painful lymph nodes. There are swollen lymph nodes on physical examination. There is no history of smoking or drinking. The physician diagnosed the condition as a disease in which cell-mediated immunity is affected by the involvement of T cells. What is the type of receptors present in T cells?
questions.solution:
Option C: CD4

  • The above-given case is a granulomatous disease.
  • It is a disease in which cell-mediated immunity is affected by the involvement of T cells.
  • CD4 receptors are present in T cells.

T cell receptor for antigen:

  • The TCR is the recognition molecule for T cells.
  • The T cell receptor is a transmembrane heterodimeric protein containing two disulfide-linked chains.

Two different classes of TCR:

  • alpha-beta (α and β): the majority of the T cells
  • gamma-delta (γ and δ): a smaller percentage of T cells

The α and β T cells are divided by their surface markers:

  • CD4: bind to MHC II
  • CD8: bind to MHC I
  • They recognize peptide antigens presented by MHC molecules on the surfaces of APCs (antigen-presenting cells).

γ and δ T cells:

  • Primarily present in the epithelial linings of the GI and reproductive tracts.
  • They recognize different types of antigens without the requirement of MHC.

Option A: IgG

  • It is the most common type of antigen.
  • A high level of IgG indicates a recent infection.

Option B: IgD

  • IgD is an immunoglobulin involved in the defense mechanism.

Option D: Prostaglandins

  • Prostaglandins (eicosanoids) are lipid compounds acting as mediators of pain and inflammation.
  • They have diverse actions such as bronchodilation, vasodilatation, etc.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to a physician for a routine examination and evaluation of his genetic testing report. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations show no abnormalities. Reviewing the patient's report, the doctor suspects alteration of genes due to transposon. Which statements are true regarding the element involved in the mechanism mentioned in the patient's pathology?

choices.text: They are also known as "jumping genes."
They are responsible for extracellular transfer
The ends of transposons carry “everted repeat” sequences

questions.solution:
Option A: They are also known as "jumping genes."

 

Transposons:

  • In this case, a cancer patient presents to the physician to evaluate his genetic testing.

  • The patient's genetic testing reveals an alteration of genes due to transposons.

  • The transposon is a process in which genetic information is exchanged via transposons.

  • They are not replicative.

  • They are responsible for the intracellular transfer.

Option B: John Harvey first discovered it

  • Barbara McClintock first discovered transposons.

Option C: They are responsible for extracellular transfer

  • They are responsible for the intracellular transfer.

Option D: The ends of transposons carry “everted repeat” sequences

  • They are hairpin-like - Centre +ve and inverted repeats on both ends.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to OPD with a complaint of abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting for the last two days. She also reports headaches, insomnia and generalised weakness. His examination reveals a high blood pressure of 160/110mmHg with a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute. On examination, hepatomegaly is noticed. Additionally, her vitamin B-12 levels are low. The clinical diagnosis of malignant hydatid disease is made. Which of the following is true about malignant hydatid disease in the patient?

choices.text: Hydatid disease in the immunocompromised host

questions.solution:
Option B: Infection with E. multilocularis

  • The scenario is hydatid disease, in which there is abdominal pain and hepatomegaly. Hydatid disease is an infection with Echinococcus multilocularis.
  • The liver is the most common organ affected (98% of cases).
  • The disease may resemble a slowly growing carcinoma and cause intrahepatic portal hypertension symptoms.
  • Hepatomegaly and hypertension are seen.
  • The cyst appears as a solid, firm mass with an irregular outer layer and can migrate rapidly to other organs to mimic a malignant tumour.
  • Man is an accidental intermediate host.
  • Definitive agent- Foxes and wolves (and also dogs and cats).
  • Intermediate hosts- Small wild rodents like squirrels, voles, mice, etc.
  • This disease is found in Russia, Kazakhstan, China, etc.

Option A: Malignant changes into hydatid cyst

  • There are no malignant changes in hydatid disease.
  • Humans are not included in the parasitic life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus.

Option C: Hydatid disease in the immunocompromised host

  • The scenario mentioned above is hydatid disease.
  • Cystic and alveolar echinococcosis occurs in the immunocompromised host.

Option D: Caused by Echinococcus granulosus

  • Hydatid disease is an infection with Echinococcus multilocularis.
  • Cystic Echinococcosis (C.E.), also known as hydatid disease, is caused by infection with the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman's body has been brought for autopsy. She was allegedly sexually assaulted and strangulated by the suspect when she attempted to free herself. There are marks of a struggle including nail marks and bruises on the forearms, thighs and also around the groin. What are the features that will help the forensic doctor to determine if the bruises were inflicted ante-mortem or post-mortem?

choices.text: Capillary rupture with extravasation of blood

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Capillary rupture with extravasation of blood

  • Extravasation of blood into surrounding tissues is a characteristic feature of an antemortem bruise.

Incorrect choices :

Option A: Well-defined margin

  • Sharply defined margins are seen in postmortem bruising.

Option C: Yellow colour

  • The age of injury can be determined by the colour changes. Colour change starts at the periphery and extends inwards to the centre.
  • Bruises of the same age may show different colour progression, so that variation in colour does not necessarily mean that there have been multiple episodes of injury. Not all bruises pass through a yellow phase before they resolve.

Option D: Gaping

  • Gaping does not distinguish between antemortem or post-mortem bruises.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man was among the 6 people who succumbed to the injuries sustained during a bus stand grenade blast. An autopsy of his body would reveal the characteristic features of the Marshal's triad except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Avulsion laceration

  • Avulsion laceration is seen in run over injuries in roadside accidents.

Option A: Abrasion

  • Marshall’s triad is seen in bomb blast injuries.
  • It is a triad of bruises, abrasions and punctate lacerations.

Option B: Contusion

  • Bruise/contusion, abrasion, and laceration seen in blast injury are known as Marshall's triad.

Option D: Punctate lacerations

  • Marshall’s triad of bruises, abrasions and punctate lacerations with tattooing of the body indicates bomb explosion.

questions.text: Stripping naked a female patient without her consent "by a male doctor" for medical examination is punishable under which section?
questions.solution:
Option B: S.354 IPC

  • Assault or use of criminal force on to a woman with intent to outrage her modesty.
  • A female patient can accuse a male doctor of indecent assault (intimate touching or fondling the breast or private parts etc.) during the consultation.

Option A: S.228 A IPC

  • Disclosure of the identity of the victim of certain offences like 376, section 376A, 376B, 376C or 376D.
  • Printing or publication of a proceeding without prior permission of the court.

Option C: S.354 C IPC

  • Under Sec. 354-C IPC, voyeurism is a punishable offence.
  • It states that ‘any man who watches or captures the images of a woman engaged in a private act (changing clothes, using lavatory or doing a sexual act) in circumstances where it is expected of not being observed or circulate such image is punishable with imprisonment from 1–3 years and fine (cognizable and bailable).

Option D: S.493 IPC

  • A man by deceit causes a woman not lawfully married to him to believe that she is lawfully married to him and to cohabit with him in that belief.

questions.text: What is True regarding the sequence of permanent teeth eruption?

choices.text: Central Incisor, Lateral Incisor, Canine, 1st Premolar, 2nd Premolar, 1st Molar, 2nd Molar & 3rd Molar
1st Premolar, Central Incisor, Lateral Incisor, Canine, 2nd Premolar, 1st Molar, 2nd Molar & 3rd Molar
1st Molar, Central Incisor, Lateral Incisor, Canine, 1st Premolar, 2nd Premolar, 2nd Molar & 3rd Molar
1st Molar, Central Incisor, Lateral Incisor, 1st Premolar, 2nd Premolar, Canine, 2nd Molar & 3rd Molar

questions.solution:
Option D: 1st Molar, Central Incisor, Lateral Incisor, 1st Premolar, 2nd Premolar, Canine, 2nd Molar & 3rd Molar

  • 1st Molar (6 years), Central Incisor (7 years), Lateral Incisor (8 years), 1st Premolar (9 years), 2nd Premolar (10 years), Canine (11 years), 2nd Molar (12-14 years) & 3rd Molar (17-25 years).

questions.text: Excess use of cannabis will cause degeneration of the central nervous system leading to significant symptoms like all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Option D: McEwan's sign

  • McEwan's sign is due to alcohol intoxication.
  • Other options A, B and C are seen in Chronic cannabis Poisoning.

Option A: Hashish insanity

  • Rarely do they become insane (hashish insanity) and may suffer from auditory and visual hallucinations and delusions of persecution.

Option B: Run amok

  • Running amok or run amok: He develops a psychic disturbance marked by a period of depression, followed by violent attempts to kill people (impulse to murder).

Option C: Flashback phenomenon

  • Recurrence of experience of cannabis use i.e., a person experiences the features of cannabis use without actually using it.
  • Flashback phenomenon is also seen in the abuse of hallucinogens LSD and psilocybin, psilocin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of Schizophrenia presented to the emergency after ingesting a large glass of a pesticide diluted with water in response to auditory hallucinations. He was alert and in no apparent distress but had persistent hypotension and tachycardia that was unresponsive to fluid resuscitation. On day 2 a reddish rash appeared on palms, soles, buttocks, and scrotum. It was documented as "Boiled lobster rash". This is seen in cases of poisoning with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Boric acid:

  • Boiled lobster’s rash is seen in poisoning with Boric acid.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sulphuric acid:

  • Sulphuric acid is most commonly used for Vitriolage (Vitriol Throwing).
  • Discoloration and staining of the skin and clothing (brown or black in sulphuric acid, and yellow in nitric acid).
  • Poison having local action: Sulphuric acid.

Option C - Carbolic acid:

  • Poisoning by carbolic acid is known as carbolism.
  • Chronic poisoning (phenol/carbol marasmus): It is characterized by anorexia, progressive weight loss, excess production of saliva, headache, vertigo, dark urine, and pigmentation of skin and sclera (ochronosis). It was a common occupational disorder of physicians and their assistants during the mid 19th century when carbolic acid sprays were commonly used for antisepsis in operating rooms.
  • Gastric lavage can be done in poisoning with Carbolic acid.
  • Fatal dose: 1–2 gms of phenol, or 25–50 ml of household phenol. Fatal period: 3–4 hrs.

Option D - Formic acid:

  • Action: It has a corrosive action on (coagulation necrosis) on G.I. mucosa. It cause hemolysisis leading to acute renal failure. ATP synthesis is diminished.
  • Fatal Dose: 50 to 200 ml.
  • Postmortem Appearances: Corrosion and blackening of gastric mucosa and pulmonary oedema.
  • Poisoning is suicidal or accidental.

questions.text: A study began in 1970 with a group of 5000 adults in Delhi who were asked about their alcohol consumption. The occurrence of cancer was studied in this group between 1990 and 1995. This is an example of which of the following study?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Concurrent cohort study

  • It is exposure (1970 with a group of 5000 adults for alcohol consumption) to outcome (occurrence of cancer was studied in this group between 1990-1995) study.
  • So, it is a Concurrent cohort study also called a Prospective cohort/ Forward study/ Risk factor to disease study in which the study is followed up to calculate the outcome after exposure.
  • It is a time-consuming study and is expensive.
  • From a prospective cohort study, we can calculate RR, AR, and PAR.

Option A: Cross-sectional study

  • A cross-sectional study is done at a particular time and is used to measure prevalence.
  • This study is done at a point of time (neither forward, nor backward).
  • It is based on primary data.
  • It is also known as a snapshot study/ prevalence study (as prevalence is calculated).

Option B: Retrospective cohort study

  • A retrospective cohort study or historic cohort study is a longitudinal cohort study.
  • The combination of a prospective cohort study and case-control study is known as a retrospective cohort study.
  • This study gives Incidence, RR, AR, and PAR.

Option D: Case-control study

  • A case-control study is a retrospective study in which cases and controls are taken (from effect to exposure).
  • It is used to calculate the odds ratio.

questions.text: A 23-year-old sexual worker visited the hospital for getting vaccinated against HPV as she was not vaccinated before. Which of the following is the correct type of HPV vaccine?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option D: Bivalent & Quadrivalent

  • Currently, two Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) vaccines are available in India as a protection against cervical cancer.
  • Gardasil vaccine: HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18 (Quadrivalent).
  • Cervarix vaccine: HPV types 16, 18 (Bivalent).

Other options

Option A: Monovalent

  • There is no monovalent HPV vaccine available.

Option B: Bivalent

  • The HPV vaccine Cervarix is a bivalent vaccine, that gives protection against HPV type-16,18.
  • Bivalent HPV vaccines protect against two HPV types, typically HPV 16 and HPV 18, which are known to be high-risk types associated with cervical cancer. They are designed to provide protection against these two specific HPV types.

Option C: Quadrivalent

  • The HPV vaccine Gardasil is a quadrivalent vaccine.
  • Gardasil vaccine: HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18 (Quadrivalent).
  • Quadrivalent HPV vaccines provide protection against four HPV types: HPV 16, HPV 18 (high-risk types), and HPV 6 and HPV 11 (low-risk types). These vaccines offer broader protection against both cervical cancer and genital warts.

questions.text: A rural PHC is giving vaccination to all the village children's every Saturday of the week. You are posted on this duty as an intern. According to national immunisation schedule all of the following vaccines are given at 16 – 24 months except?
questions.solution:
NIS (National Immunization Schedule, India 2019-20)

→ At Birth : BCG, OPV0, Hep B

→ 6 Weeks : DPT1, OPV1, Hep B1, HiB1, Rota V1, fractionated IPV1, PCV1

→ 10 Weeks : DPT2, OPV2, Hep B2, HiB2, Rota V2

→ 14 Weeks : DPT3, OPV3, Hep B3, HiB3,Rota V3, fractionated IPV2, PCV2

→ 9 months : Measles1/MR1, Vitamin A, PCV Booster, live JE1

→ Every 6 months : Vitamin A (2 Lacs IU) till 5 years

→ 16–24 months : DPTB, OPV Booster, Measles2/MR2, live JE2

→ 5 Years : DPTB

→ 10 Years : TT

→ 16 Years : TT

→ Pregnancy : TT

(In 2020, TT to replaced with Td)

questions.text: A rural PHC has reported many cases where the population is acquiring the disease in spite of being vaccinated for that disease. This condition is due to vaccine failure. Which of the following is the most common cause of Vaccine failure?
questions.solution:
Option D: Maternally derived antibodies

  • Vaccine failure are of 2 types primary and secondary.
  • Primary vaccine failure means failure to serologically respond to vaccine.
  • Too young age where maternal antibody interfere is the most common cause of vaccine failure.

Learning Objective: Vaccine failure

Primary vaccination failure: Failure to serologically respond to vaccine

  • Too young age where Maternal antibodies interfere (MC Cause)
  • Vaccine production problems
  • Cold chain failure
  • Inappropriate administration technique
  • Immunodeficiency
  • Poor health

Secondary vaccination failure: ‘Waning immunity’ where there is loss of vaccine-induced protection in an individual who had previously seroconverted to vaccination. Causes are not well understood.

questions.text: In a rural PHC Asha workers are arranging vaccine carriers. How many fully frozen ice packs should a vaccine carrier contain?
questions.solution:
Option B: 4

  • The vaccine carrier contains 4 fully frozen ice packs.
  • Vaccine carrier can carry 16-20 vaccine vials.
  • The health worker uses it to transport small amounts of vaccinations from the Primary Health Center or Sub-center to the outreach station (i.e., immunization camp).
  • The temperature maintained in the vaccine carrier is +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to explain about mortality indicators. All of the following are mortality indicators except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Disability adjusted life years (DALY)

  • Disability adjusted life years (DALY) is a disability Indicator.
  • DALY is indeed a measure that combines both mortality and morbidity, making it a measure of overall disease burden rather than a pure mortality indicator. It quantifies the years of healthy life lost due to both premature mortality and the years lived with disability or in states of less than full health.

Option B: Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL)

  • YPLL is a measure that calculates the number of years of life lost due to premature death. It assesses the impact of mortality by estimating the years of life that individuals would have lived if they had not died prematurely.

Option D: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate is a mortality indicator that measures the proportion of individuals with a specific disease or condition who die from it. It is calculated as the number of deaths related to the disease divided by the number of diagnosed cases of the disease, often expressed as a percentage.

questions.text: A chronic carrier is a person who harbors and transmits an infectious agent for an indefinite period. Chronic carrier state is seen in all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Option B: Measles

  • Measles does not have chronic carriers.
  • The incubation period of measles is 14-21 days.
  • Measles typically takes 11 to 12 days to incubate after exposure to prodrome.
  • An average of 14 days pass from exposure to the appearance of a rash, with a range of 7 to 21 days.
  • The prodrome lasts 2 to 4 days, with a range of one to seven days.

Option A: Typhoid

  • A chronic carrier state is found in Typhoid.
  • The treatment of choice in cases: Cephalosporins
  • The treatment of choice in carriers: Ampicillin / Amoxycillin + probenecid x 6 weeks.

Option C: Hepatitis B

  • A chronic carrier state is found in Hepatitis B.
  • The incubation period of Hep B is 45-180 days (6 weeks – 6 months).
  • The serological pattern of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication is HbsAg, HBeAg, and IgG Anti-HBc.
  • The serological pattern of chronic hepatitis B, with low viral replication, is HbsAg, IgG Anti-HBc, Anti-HBe.
Option D: Gonorrhoea
  • A chronic carrier state is found in Gonorrhoea.
  • The incubation period of Gonorrhoea is 1-5 days.
  • The causative organism is Neisseria Gonorrhoeae.

questions.text: A researcher wants to evaluate the effect of a new diet regimen on the weight of a group of 10 patients. He records their weight before & after the regimen. Which of the following statistical test will be applicable in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Paired t-test

  • In the given question, the researcher wants to compare mean weight before and after an intervention. So, paired students’ t–tests will be the most appropriate statistical test of significance.
  • Paired student’s t–test: Comparing means (±SD) in paired data. (In the same group of individuals before and after an intervention
  • Example: Mean serum albumin level of dengue patients before treatment was 3.6 g/dL and after treatment was 3.2 g/dL; comparison of mean level can be done by Paired student’s t–test.

Option A: Chi-square test

  • Chi-square test (X2 - test): Comparing percentages, proportions & fractions in two or more different groups of individuals.
  • Example: Three-fourths of students in a class are underweight whereas another class has two-thirds anemic; the test of significance to be used is the Chi-square test.
  • Fischer’s test: It is a variant of the Chi-square test when the sample size is <30.

Option C: Unpaired t-test

  • Unpaired student’s t-test comparing means (±SD) in two different groups of individuals.
  • Example: Mean HB level of anemia patients was 9.6 g/dL and those of hookworm patients was 7.2 g/dL; comparison of mean levels can be done by Unpaired student’s t–test.

Option D: ANOVA

  • ANOVA test (F-test/F-ratio): Comparing means (+ SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.
  • Example: Mean weight of students in class A is 50 kg, those of class B is 44.6 kg and those of class C is 52.7 kg; Comparison of mean weights can be done by ANOVA test.

questions.text: A rural PHC is organizing various health programs for the benefit of the villagers. Specific pre-planned activity in a Health Program is known as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Objective

  • Objective: Is a pre-planned end-point of all activities, and is precise and concerned with the problem itself.

Option B: Target

  • Target: A discrete activity that helps measure the extent of attainment of objectives.

Option C: Goal

  • Goal: Ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are directed.

Option D: Impact

  • Impact: Overall effect of programme/service on health and development.

questions.text: ‘Moron’ is one with an IQ of
questions.solution:
Levels of intelligence IQ range
Idiot 0 – 24
Imbecile 25 – 49
Moron 50 – 69
Borderline 70 – 79
Low normal 80 – 89
Normal 90 – 109
Superior 110 – 119
Very superior 120 – 139
Near genius 140 and over

questions.text: Adisaster is a sudden, calamitous event that seriously disrupts the functioning of a community or society and causes human, material, and economic or environmental losses. Nodal centre for Disaster management in India is created at level of?
questions.solution:
Disaster management:

  • Nodal ministry → Home affairs
  • Nodal center → District level
  • Disaster reduction day → 13th October
  • Worst man-made disaster → Bhopal gas tragedy
  • Maximum mortality → Hydrological disaster like floods.

questions.text: In the Post-disaster phase, all of the following vaccines are mandatory for doctors except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Measles

  • In the Post-disaster phase, Measles vaccines are not mandatory for doctors.
  • The measles vaccine is effective in the post-disaster phase.
  • Incubation period → 10-14 days
  • IP of Vaccine-Induced Measles(VIM) → 7 days, hence immunity is provided before the natural infection.
     

Option A: Cholera

  • The cholera vaccine is mandatory for healthcare professionals in the post-disaster phase.
  • The three types of oral cholera vaccines available are (I) Dukoral (WC-rBS), (ii) mORCVAX, and (iii) CVD103-HgR.
  • CVD-103-HgR is a live attenuated single-dose vaccine for cholera.
  • WC-rBS (Dukoral) is a heat-killed cholera vaccine. It remains stable for 1 month at 37 degrees Celcius. It is not licensed for children <2 years of age.

Option B: Typhoid

 

  • The Typhoid vaccine is mandatory for healthcare professionals in the post-disaster phase.
  • Ty21A is a strain of the typhoid vaccine.
  • It is administered on days 1, 3, and 5.
  • It is given orally. The protective immunity is achieved 1 week after the 3rd dose.

Option D: Tetanus

 

DPT Vaccine

  • The Tetanus vaccine is mandatory for healthcare professionals in the post-disaster phase.
  • It contains components for immunization against three diseases, i.e. toxoid of diphtheria, tetanus, and killed B. pertussis.
  • The pertussis component enhances the potency of diphtheria toxoid.
  • A minimum interval of 4 weeks is given for the immune system to activate & then give the next dose.
  • Hence, 3 doses - DPT1, DPT2, and DPT3 are given at 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 14 weeks respectively.
  • Dosage: 5 ml is given intramuscularly.

questions.text: A 30 year old male known case tuberculosis was given bedaquiline. All of the following are true regarding Bedaquiline uses except?

choices.text: The patient ≥ 18 years with MDR TB is included
Patient with XDR-TB is eligible for its therapy
Patient should be using hormonal based birth control measure throughout the treatment period

questions.solution:
BEDAQUILINE

Patient should be using non- hormonal based birth control measure throughout the treatment period

The basic criteria for patient selection for bedaquiline is :

  • Age of the patient should be ≥18 years having MDR- TB
  • Pregnancy is a contraindication for BDQ therapy and the patient should be using non-hormonal based birth control measure throughout the treatment period or have been postmenopausal for past 2 years; and
  • Cardiac arrhythmia is a contraindication for BDQ treatment

-XDR-TB patient is eligible for therapy

questions.text: A city with 800 deaths per year. In mortuary body is stored for an average duration of 8 days with 80% occupancy in a year. What number of mortuary beds are needed per day?
questions.solution:
Option A: 14
