Total number of beds = no. of deaths X average duration of storage

= 800 X 8

= 6400 beds per year

Bed needed Per day = 6400/365 = 17.5 beds per day

This is true for 100% occupancy.

Since in this question they asked for 80% occupancy,

= 17.5/80 X 100

= 14 beds per day

Learning Objective

  • Total number of beds = no. of deaths X average duration of storage

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida female delivered her baby in the hospital. This morning she visited the physician with concern that her baby is not growing in height. Height of a newborn double at which of the following age?
questions.solution:
Option D: 4 years

  • Normal length at birth is approximately 50 cm.
  • Length is measured in a supine position for 2 years.
  • Length is measured by an infantometer.
  • Height is measured after 2 years, and it is measured by Stadiometer.
  • Height of a newborn double at the age of 4 - 4½ years.
  • Height triples by the age of 12 years.

Other options

Option A: 3 months

  • The length of the baby at 3 months is 60 cm (which is not double of birth length).
  • The normal length at birth in India is 50 cm.

Option B: 9 months

  • The length of the baby at 9 months is 70 cm (which is not double of birth length).
  • The normal length at birth in India is 50 cm.

Option C: 1 year

  • The length of the baby at 1 year is 75 cm (which is not double of birth length).
  • The normal length at birth in India is 50 cm.

questions.text: A 26 year old male from rural village presented to the PHC with some seeds as shown in the image below. Looking at the seeds your senior doctor asked you that the food item is the richest source of?
questions.solution:
- Photography shown in the question is Dried pumpkin seed which is richest source of iron.

- Pistachio nuts & cashew nuts are also rich in iron.

Also remember;

  • EFA - Safflower oil
  • Vit A - HALIBUT liver oil
  • Vit C - Amla
  • Golden rice - Rich source of vit A & Iron
  • Salt - good source of iodine
  • Vit B12 - No plant source
  • Saturated fatty acid - coconut oil
  • MUFA - olive oil
  • PUFA - Safflower oil

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the emergency room complaining of chest pain, palpitations and shortness of breath. ECG shows P wave is tall in lead II and upright in V1 along with right axis deviation. Based on the information provided, what appropriate auscultatory findings will be noted?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above:

  • The first heart sound (S1 ) is usually accentuated in the early stages of the disease and slightly delayed.
  • The pulmonic component of the second heart sound (P2 ) also is often accentuated with elevated PAPs, and the two components of the second heart sound (S2 ) are closely split.
  • The mitral valve's opening snap (OS) is most readily audible in expiration at, or just medial to, the cardiac apex.
  • This sound generally follows the sound of aortic valve closure (A2 ) by 0.05–0.12 s.
  • The time interval between A2 and OS varies inversely with the severity of the MS.
  • The OS is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, diastolic murmur, heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral recumbent position; it is accentuated by mild exercise (e.g., a few rapid sit-ups) carried out just before auscultation.
  • In general, this murmur's duration correlates with the stenosis's severity in patients with preserved CO.
  • The S1 sound is initially narrow split and then heard as a single sound which then progresses to reverse splitting.
  • In patients with sinus rhythm, the murmur often reappears or becomes louder during atrial systole (presystolic accentuation).
  • Soft, grade I or II/VI systolic murmurs may be heard at or medial to the apex and signify mixed mitral valve disease with regurgitation.
  • Hepatomegaly, ankle oedema, ascites, and pleural effusion may occur in patients with MS and RV failure, particularly in the right pleural cavity.

Option A: Narrow split S1

  • In the initial stages of the disease, there is a narrow splitting of S1.

Option B: Single S1

  • In moderate cases, S1 becomes single.

Option C: Reverse split S1

  • In severe MS, there is often the reverse splitting of S1.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with loss of consciousness 20 minutes ago. He regains consciousness in the ER, and GCS on admission is 12/15. CNS examination is normal, and auscultation reveals a narrow split S2 and clear lungs. ECG is shown below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Subarachnoid hemorrhage with T wave inversion

questions.solution:
Option A: Left outflow tract obstruction

  • The ECG shows a heart rate of 60/min with a left axis deviation
  • SV1+RV5> 35 mm is suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy (SV1 = 20mm and RV5= 30mm)
  • Narrow split S2 indicates outflow tract obstruction
  • Considering the age, the patient either suffers from HOCM or valvular aortic stenosis. Low cardiac output can lead to exertional syncope.

Option B: Right outflow tract obstruction

  • Right outflow tract obstruction will lead to RVH → R wave more than 7mm in V1 (R ≥ S wave), usually with right axis deviation

Option C: Atrial fibrillation with cerebral embolism

  • Atrial Fibrillation is characterized by Irregularly irregular heart rate, Absent P waves (replaced by fibrillating f wave), Baseline vibration

Option D: Subarachnoid haemorrhage with T wave inversion

  • T wave inversion in the anterior lead can be due to:
    1. Subarachnoid haemorrhage
    2. Pericarditis
    3. Pulmonary embolism
    4. Electrolyte abnormalities
    5. HOCM
    6. Pancreatitis
    7. Takotsubo CM

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to intermittent chest pain for 3 months. The pain is located substernal, is crushing in nature and radiates to the jaw. It starts with exertion and is relieved with rest. Physical examination is unremarkable. The ECG shows no ischemic changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Angina pectoris

  • The patient presents with clinical features of angina (stable) pectoris.
  • Angina pectoris is characterized by squeezing, tightening, or crushing pain in the chest which radiates to the neck, jaw, and left arm.
  • It is associated with nausea and sweating.
  • Angina can be of three types:
  • Stable angina (Angina pectoris): Pain occurs with exertion and relieves with rest or nitroglycerin.
  • Unstable angina: It is a medical emergency. Pain is worse and occurs with less physical exertion, and lasts longer. It does not go away with rest or nitroglycerin.
  • Prinzmetal angina: It is due to coronary artery spasms. The pain usually occurs at night. It relives with calcium channel blockers and nitrates.
  • ECG and cardiac enzymes are normal in stable angina.
  • The coronary arteries show >70 % blockage.

Option B: Acute pericarditis

  • Acute pericarditis is characterized by sharp chest pain, relieved by sitting up or leaning forward.
  • ECG shows diffuse S-T segment elevations with PR segment depression.

Option C: STEMI

  • ECG findings in STEMI would show S-T segment elevations.
  • This patient's ECG is normal.

Option D: NSTEMI

  • ECG findings in NSTEMI would show S-T segment depression and T wave inversions.
  • This patient's ECG is normal.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain for 1 hour. He has had a history of hypertension and diabetes for the last 5 years and is non-compliant with the medications. He is an active smoker and has smoked for 20 pack years. On examination, the pulse is 150/minute irregularly irregular, blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/minute. An ECG is carried out and shown below:

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anterior STEMI with atrial fibrillation

  • The patient has acute onset chest pain and typical risk factors of cardiovascular disease (hypertension, diabetes, and smoking), so a diagnosis of ACS (Acute coronary syndrome) is likely. In addition, an irregularly irregular pulse is suggestive of atrial fibrillation.
  • The following ECG findings are notable in the ECG shown in the question:
      • The ECG shows variable heart rate with RR interval in the lead II varying between 150-300 bpm.
      • The axis is normal.
      • The p wave is absent.
      • Reduced RR interval and narrow complex QRS
      • Hyperacute T waves are seen in V2 - V5
  • The findings of hyperacute T waves in the chest leads V2-V5 are consistent with anterior wall MI.
  • The absence of P waves and irregularly irregular RR interval in lead II is consistent with atrial fibrillation.

Option A: Anterior STEMI with VT

  • Ventricular tachycardia has a wide complex QRS, but here it shows a narrow QRS complex; hence this option is ruled out.

Option B: Inferior STEMI with VT

  • Inferior wall STEMI typically causes ECG changes (hyperacute T waves or ST elevation) in leads II, III, and aVF. Moreover, the ventricular tachycardia has a wide complex QRS, but here it shows a narrow QRS complex.

Option C. Inferior STEMI with SVT

  • The inferior wall STEMI would cause ECG changes (hyperacute T waves or ST elevation) in leads II, III, and aVF. Moreover, the SVT typically does not cause an irregularly irregular rhythm. An irregularly irregular rhythm with absent P waves is consistent with atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus attends his annual diabetes review. His reports turn out to have an HbA1c of 8.8%. He also has hypertension and currently takes metformin, aspirin and lisinopril. His routine blood tests detect a reduction in his renal function, with his glomerular filtration rate now being less than 30ml/min. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the current status of this patient?

choices.text: Increased risk of developing metabolic alkalosis
Increased risk of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis
Increased risk of developing high anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
Option D: Increased risk of developing high anion gap metabolic acidosis

  • Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a disease of beta cells of the pancreas.
  • It is characterized by polydipsia, polyphagia, polyuria, fatigue, weight loss, blurred vision, fungal infections, numbness and tingling of hands and feet, diabetic ketoacidosis, and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state.
  • Treatment of DM type 1 includes insulin replacement. Insulin injections are administered subcutaneously in the abdomen, buttocks, arms, or legs.
  • For type-2 DM, the mainstay of treatment is oral hypoglycemic drugs after conservative management with diet, exercise, and smoking cessation fails.
  • Other agents such as non-insulin injectables, insulin replacement, and weight loss therapies are particularly helpful in lowering blood glucose levels.
  • Oral hypoglycemic drugs include:
    • Metformin is a biguanide. It inhibits hepatic gluconeogenesis and the action of glucagon. It increases glycolysis and peripheral glucose uptake by increasing insulin sensitivity. Metformin is the first-line agent in treating DM type-2 and can be used as a monotherapy alone.
      • Common side effects of metformin include:
        • Gastrointestinal upset,
        • Vitamin B-12 deficiency.
        • Lactic acidosis(high anion gap metabolic acidosis). Lactic acidosis is particularly severe in patients with renal insufficiency, so it should be used cautiously. It can also cause weight loss. So, a patient taking metformin with decreased glomerular filtration rate has an increased risk of developing high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
    • Sulfonylureas increase insulin release by the pancreatic beta-cells. These are associated with an increased risk of hypoglycemia and weight gain.
    • Thiazolidinediones increase insulin sensitivity and levels of adiponectin. These can cause weight gain, edema, and heart failure.
    • Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors block the absorption of glucose in proximal convoluted tubules. These are associated with glycosuria and an increased risk of urinary tract infections.
    • Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors decrease intestinal absorption of glucose. These can cause gastrointestinal upset.
    • DPP-4 inhibitors block GLP-1 leading to decreased glucagon release.

Option A: Increased risk of developing metabolic alkalosis.

  • Metformin increases the production of lactic acid in the body, leading to metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis.

Option B: Decreased risk of developing retinopathy.

  • A patient who has elevated levels of HbA1c indicates poor glycemic control. So, the risk of diabetic complications such as retinopathy is greater

Option C: Increased risk of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

  • Elevated lactic acid levels in the body due to metformin use cause a high anion-gap metabolic acidosis
  • Normal anion-gap metabolic acidosis is caused by diarrhoea, renal tubular acidosis, acetazolamide use, Addison's disease etc.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man was found unconscious in his house by his neighbour, who took him to the emergency department, and despite multiple attempts at resuscitation, the patient could not survive. The neighbour does not know this patient's medical history, but a device was found in the patient's pocket, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is not a complication of using this device?
questions.solution:
Option D: Minimal weight loss is seen.

  • The object shown in the image is an insulin pen.
  • It is an injector device that allows the self-injection of insulin and has a reservoir or cartridge of insulin.
  • It can help people with diabetes to manage better insulin delivery.
  • A smartphone application is often associated with insulin pens with reminders and alerts to notify people about the doses and timings of injection.
  • Insulin pens are easy to use, time-saving, can be used by all children and older adults, and help with the correct insulin dosage.
  • Insulin is deficient in diabetes mellitus type-1, and reduced insulin sensitivity is seen in diabetes mellitus type-2.
  • Patients with diabetes mellitus type-1 and advanced diabetes mellitus type-2 (refractory to other modes of treatment)are treated with insulin therapy. It is self-administered by subcutaneous injection in the abdomen, buttocks, arms, or legs. In emergencies, intravenous insulin can be given.
  • Diabetic people who are on insulin therapy with insulin pens or insulin pumps can develop the following features:
    • Hypoglycemia and hypokalemia.
    • Neuroglycopenia is a shortage of glucose in the brain due to hypoglycemia caused by inappropriate and excess insulin dosage.
    • Lipohypertrophy occurs when a person injects insulin through the same skin patch too many times.
      • The repeated injections cause a build-up of lipids, proteins, and collagen under the skin. Lipohypertrophy is common in patients using insulin pumps or insulin pens.
    • Morning hyperglycemia can be due to a rebound response to nocturnal hypoglycemia.
      • Counter-regulatory hormones (glucagon, norepinephrine, cortisol) are activated in response to hypoglycemia at night and elevate blood glucose levels in the morning, known as the Somogyi effect. (vs Dawn phenomenon happens due to increased secretion of growth hormone at night. It is independent of the Somogyi effect).
    • Insulin is an anabolic hormone; it decreases lipolysis and increases fat storage in the body. It also increases the synthesis of proteins in the body, leading to weight gain.
    • Localized allergic reaction and formation of antibodies against insulin.

 

Option A: Lipodystrophy

  • Using insulin injections repeatedly over the same skin patch can cause lipodystrophy.

  • Lipodystrophy is a condition in which the amount and/or distribution of adipose tissue in the body is abnormal.

 

 

Option B: Neuroglycopenia.

  • Sometimes patients can self-administer an extra insulin dosage, leading to hypoglycemia and lower brain glucose levels.

Option C: Pre-breakfast hyperglycemia.

  • Using insulin therapy can lead to elevated insulin levels at night, causing hypoglycemia, which increases counterregulatory hormones leading to hyperglycemia in the morning.

questions.text: Eight hours after undergoing a coronary artery bypass graft surgery, a 54-year-old male develops numbness around his lips and fingertips. During the surgery, his internal mammary artery got lacerated, and he received multiple blood transfusions because of the massive bleeding. The patient has had hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 15 years. His family history is remarkable for hyperparathyroidism in his mother. The patient is a chronic smoker and alcoholic. His current medications include metformin, glyburide, and captopril. On physical examination, he appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), his pulse is 100 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination of the extremities shows an adducted thumb, flexion at metacarpophalangeal joints, and extension at wrists and fingers. The remainder of the review of systems shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A: Multiple blood transfusions

  • This patient received multiple blood transfusions while managing haemorrhage, showing signs and symptoms of tetany because of hypocalcemia.
  • The citrate ions in the stored blood chelate the free calcium ions and decrease the concentration of free calcium ions, resulting in hypocalcemia.
  • Moderate to severe hypocalcemia is associated with paresthesias, usually of the fingers, toes, and circumoral regions, and is caused by increased neuromuscular irritability.
  • Trousseau's sign observed in this patient as a carpopedal spasm is a classic sign of latent tetany. It can be induced by inflation of a blood pressure cuff to 20 mmHg above the patient's systolic blood pressure for 3 minutes.
  • The image below shows the trousseau sign/carpopedal spasm in patients with hypocalcemia.

  • Chvostek's sign is another meaningful clinical sign. This sign can be elicited by the gentle tapping of the facial nerve just anterior to the ear and causes twitching of the circumoral muscles.
  • Severe hypocalcemia can induce seizures, carpopedal spasms, bronchospasm, laryngospasm, and prolongation of the QT interval.

Option B: Hypoparathyroidism

  • Hypoparathyroidism can cause tetany and features of hypocalcemia.
  • However, the sudden presentation of this patient just after a massive blood transfusion makes hypoparathyroidism a less likely diagnosis in this clinical vignette.

 

Option C: Vitamin B 12 deficiency

  • This patient is taking metformin which can result in vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to the gradual development of peripheral neuropathy, such as numbness and paresthesia.
  • However, acute presentation of this individual, along with carpopedal spasm, points towards massive blood transfusion as the underlying cause.

 

Option D: Ulnar nerve injury

  • An ulnar nerve injury may manifest with numbness and a finger deformity.
  • However, it would be just localized to the 4th and 5th fingers.
  • Moreover, this manifests as an extension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the interphalangeal joints (which is precisely the opposite of this patient's clinical presentation).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a sudden severe headache. The patient also complains of not seeing very well. Diagnosis of pituitary apoplexy is made. Which is the most common cranial nerve involved in pituitary apoplexy?
questions.solution:
Option B:Occulomotor nerve

  • People with preexisting Pituitary adenomas are at risk of bleeding and undergoing necrosis. So the explanation for this is that adenoma outgrows the blood supply, and there is ischemia and necrosis, or there is a haemorrhage of the adenoma due to fragility of the blood supply
  • Since the pituitary adenomas undergo infarction due to its predisposition due to the large size or fragility of vessels, it causes pituitary apoplexy(infarction of the pituitary gland)
  • The presentation is the acute headache of severe quality, Hypopituatirism and visual defects(bitemporal superior quadrant defect) due to compression of the optic chiasm
  • The ocular paresis is due to the compression of the cranial nerve III, IV and VI in pituitary apoplexy
  • The oculomotor nerve is the main nerve to be affected, and the patient has a characteristic down and out eye
  • MRI is the most sensitive imaging technique that can be used
  • Treatment is surgery

Option A: Optic nerve

  • The optic nerve is affected by optic neuritis or damage to the internal carotid artery

Option C: Abducens nerve

  • Abducens nerve is also affected in pituitary apoplexy, but the oculomotor nerve is the one that is the most affected

Option D: Facial nerve

  • The facial nerve can be affected in vestibular schwannoma but is not involved in pituitary apoplexy

questions.text:
A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. According to her family, she ingested unknown tablets in excess about one hour ago. The lab analysis shows the following findings:
PaCo2 – 65 mmHg

HCO3 – 15 mEq/L 

pH – 7.21

Which of the following can be interpreted from the above ABG analysis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis

  • pH – 7.21 , HCO3 – 15 mEq/L , PaCo2 – 65, HCO3 – 15 mEq/L ⇒ Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis
  • The patient has acidosis. The decreased bicarbonate points to metabolic aetiology.
  • The patient will hyperventilate in compensation for metabolic acidosis, and carbon dioxide washout will occur.
  • There is a linear relationship between PaCO2 and serum HCO3 in metabolic acidosis.
  • Winter’s formula: expected PaCO2 = [1.5 x (serum HCO3)] + [8±2]
  • Expected PaCO2= (1.5X15) +8±2 = 22.5 + 8 ± 2= 28-32

Interpretation of Winter's formula

  1. If PaCO2 is lower than normal, there is a concomitant primary respiratory alkalosis
  2. If PaCO2 is higher than normal, there is a concomitant primary respiratory acidosis

Note: Salicylate poisoning is characterized by Both Metabolic and respiratory acidosis

Option A: Uncompensated metabolic alkalosis

  • Uncompensated metabolic alkalosis presents will have low pH and low bicarbonate ions.
  • Moreover, CO2 will be minimally elevated

​​​​​​​Option C: Fully compensated metabolic acidosis

  • A fully compensated metabolic acidosis would be a falling pCO2 level, not the rising one.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option D: Compensated respiratory acidosis

  • A compensated respiratory acidosis will have bicarbonate of 26.5 mEq/L( Every mmHg increase in pCO2 will increase the bicarbonate ion by 0.1 mEq/L), assuming that normal pCO2 is 40 mmHg and normal bicarbonate is 24 mEq/L.

questions.text: A neonate presents in the pediatric emergency department with the complaint of recurrent episodes of seizures. Parents also give a history of recurrent infections. On general physical examination, the neonate has low-set ears, an underdeveloped chin, and wide eyes. On the serum electrolyte report, the neonate has hypocalcemia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Di-George syndrome

Di George syndrome is a combination of disorders that relates to chromosomal abnormalities along with facial disorders and abnormal serum electrolytes:

  • Mnemonic: CATCH-22 is used to describe Di George syndrome, with the 22 to remind one that the chromosomal abnormality is found on chromosome 22
    • Cardiac abnormality (especially TOF)
    • Abnormal facies
    • Thymic aplasia = explains the recurrent infections
    • Cleft palate
    • Hypocalcemia/Hypoparathyroidism: explains recurrent seizures and tetany

Option B: Bartter syndrome

  • This syndrome is due to mutations in two genes (NKCC2, ROMK) affecting the transport of sodium, potassium and chloride in the thick ascending loop of Henle
  • These patients typically have a history of polyhydramnios and, following birth, have recurrent life-threatening episodes of fever and dehydration,
  • These patients may also present electrolyte and acid-base disturbances, hypercalciuria, and early-onset nephrocalcinosis.

Option C: Gitelman syndrome

  • Gitelman syndrome occurs in older children with episodes of muscle weakness and tetany.
  • Severe hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia is present.
  • These children have hypocalciuria

Option D: Idiopathic hypercalciuria

  • This is the commonest metabolic disorder in those patients that have renal calcium stones
  • Serum calcium levels are normal, but in urine, calcium levels exceed 300 mg/day in males and above 250 mg/day in females.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with loin pain and vague discomfort. On physical examination, there is a mass in the Lumber area. USG and genetic testing are performed, and he has been diagnosed with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. He also has a family history of ADPKD. How should the cysts be present in USG to call ADPKD?
questions.solution:
Option B: 2 Cysts per kidney

  • As the age is 40 Years, so 2 cysts per kidney with family history is correct

 

Diagnostic criteria for ADPKD (Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease)

Age (years) Number of Cysts (USG FINDING)
15-29 2 renal cysts (unilateral or bilateral) + family history of ADPKD
30-59 2 cysts per kidney + family history of ADPKD
>60 4 cysts per kidney + family history of ADPKD
  • Genetic testing (linkage analysis and direct DNA sequencing) is available as a clinical test and can detect PKD1 and PKD2 mutations in approximately 90% of confirmed cases.

Option A: 1 Cyst per kidney

  • The patient's age is 40 Years. At this age, 2 cysts per kidney are the cut-off value, so this option is ruled out

Option C: 3 Cysts per kidney

  • Cut off value for diagnosing ADPKD is a minimum of 2 cysts per kidney
  • This value is above cut off value patient will be suffering from ADPKD, but in question, we are asked about the minimum cut-off value at 40 Years

Option D: 4 Cysts per kidney

  • 4 Cysts per kidney is seen in >60 yrs along with family history of ADPKD

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of decreased urination and muscle cramps. The physician notices that he also has pedal oedema. He also has a history of taking a drug which is nephrotoxic. The doctor diagnoses him with nephrotoxicity. Which of the following drugs is not implicated in causing nephrotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Nephrotoxicity refers to the ability of certain substances, including drugs, to cause damage to the kidneys. Some drugs are more likely to be nephrotoxic than others. Here are four drug options, with an explanation of which one is not implicated in causing nephrotoxicity:

  1. Ibuprofen:

    • Explanation: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used to relieve pain and reduce inflammation. While NSAIDs like ibuprofen can cause kidney problems in some individuals, they are generally considered to have a lower risk of nephrotoxicity compared to other drugs in this list. However, chronic and excessive use of NSAIDs can potentially lead to kidney issues in some cases.

  2. Vancomycin:

    • Explanation: Vancomycin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections. It has a known association with nephrotoxicity, especially when administered at high doses or for extended periods. Kidney function should be carefully monitored when using vancomycin.

  3. Cisplatin:

    • Explanation: Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer. It is notorious for its nephrotoxicity and can cause acute kidney injury, especially when used at high doses. Kidney function should be closely monitored during cisplatin treatment.

  4. Lisinopril:

    • Explanation: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure. Unlike the other options listed, lisinopril is not typically implicated in causing nephrotoxicity. In fact, it is often prescribed to protect the kidneys in certain conditions, such as diabetic nephropathy.

In summary, out of the options listed, lisinopril is not implicated in causing nephrotoxicity. However, it's essential to remember that individual responses to drugs can vary, and any medication should be used under the supervision of a healthcare professional who can monitor and assess its effects on kidney function.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child is brought to the pediatric department with complaints of nausea and vomiting. The child is malnourished, along with mild to moderate dehydration. The child had a previous history of cerebral palsy at the 5th month of age. Serum electrolytes and ABGs are also abnormal. Barter syndrome has been diagnosed in the child. Which of the following are associated with bartter syndrome?

choices.text: Urinary calcium increased, and Mineralocorticoid antagonists can not be used
Metabolic acidosis is present, Mineralocorticoid antagonist cannot be used, and normal to low blood pressure
Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis and normal to low blood pressure
Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis, Mineralocorticoid antagonist can not be used and normal to low blood pressure

questions.solution:
Option C: Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis, and normal to low blood pressure

  • Bartter syndrome is a renal tubular salt-wasting disorder in which the kidneys cannot reabsorb sodium and chloride in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This results in extracellular fluid volume depletion with low/normal blood pressure.
  • The defect in Barter syndrome in the thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle - increase urinary loss of calcium & nephrocalcinosis
  • The salt wasting and polyuria lead to dehydration - stimulating the R.A.A.S. - secondary hyperaldosteronism. This explains hypokalemia.
  • R.O.M.K. receptors in T.A.L. are affected, leading to urinary loss of potassium.
  • Increased intra-renal prostaglandins and hence indomethacin is prescribed.
  • Secondary aldosteronism explains the development of metabolic alkalosis

Option A: Urinary calcium increased, and Mineralocorticoid antagonist can not be used

  • Mineralocorticoid antagonists are used for the treatment
  • Other agents which are used for the treatment are NSAIDs and A.C.E.I.s/A.R.B.s

Option B: Metabolic acidosis is present, Mineralocorticoid antagonist cannot be used, and normal to low blood pressure

  • Mineralocorticoid antagonists are used for the treatment
  • Moreover, there is metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis.

Option D: Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis, Mineralocorticoid antagonist can not be used and normal to low blood pressure

  • Mineralocorticoid antagonists such as spironolactone can be used to manage Barter syndrome.

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of headache, swelling on both ankles and puffiness of the face, and generalised weakness. His blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and his pulse is 80 beats/min. In addition to generalised oedema, cervical lymphadenopathy is also noted on examination. He is a truck driver by occupation. His investigations reveal hypercholesterolemia, raised serum creatinine, hypoalbuminemia and a CD4 count of 150. Rapid HIV test is positive. HBV and HCV are negative by a rapid test kit. Urine analysis reveals nephrotic range proteinuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis

  • The patient in the given scenario has a positive rapid HIV test and CD4 count of 150, suggesting that the patient has an HIV infection.
  • Isolated nephrotic range proteinuria secondary to HIV infection indicates HIV nephropathy.
  • Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in adults associated with an HIV infection.
  • The patient usually presents with signs of nephrotic syndrome along with kidney injury, which is signified by raised creatinine and high blood pressure in this patient.

Option B: Minimal Change Disease

  • Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in children.
  • It is usually idiopathic but may be associated with malignancies (Hodgkin’s lymphoma), not HIV.
  • It usually presents with selective proteinuria and normal kidney function tests initially.
  • The patient’s age, HIV infection and raised creatinine make this diagnosis less likely.

Option C: Membranous Nephropathy

  • Membranous Nephropathy can be associated with infections, autoimmune conditions and solid organ malignancies.
  • The infections this condition is associated with are hepatitis B and C, not HIV.
  • This patient has a positive rapid test for HIV, but they are negative for HBV and HCV, making this diagnosis less likely.​​​​​​​

Option D: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis

  • Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is usually a nephritic syndrome but can present with nephrotic range proteinuria in advanced disease.
  • It is associated with either an autoimmune condition such as SLE or an infection such as HBV or HCV.
  • This patient has HIV nephropathy, which is associated with FSGS, making MPGN a less likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of fever and chills. A blood smear revealed Plasmodium falciparum. Which of the following features is not consistent with his condition?

choices.text: First line treatment is chloroquine therapy

questions.solution:
Option D: Adequately prevented with chloroquine therapy

Falciparum malaria features

  • Severe falciparum malaria can include dysfunction of any organ system
  • Severe anaemia
  • Hypotension and shock
  • Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Acidosis
  • Hemolysis with jaundice; hepatic dysfunction; retinal haemorrhages
  • Chloroquine can be used as prophylaxis for Plasmodium vivax, but it is inadequate for falciparum malaria.

Option A: Haemoglobinuria and renal failure

  • It can also cause acute kidney injury due to acute tubular necrosis or, less commonly, severe Hemolysis, resulting in acute renal failure and hemoglobinuria.

Option B: Hypoglycemia

  • Falciparum malaria commonly results in hypoglycemia, typically attributed to increased glucose consumption and decreased glucose synthesis brought on by the suppression of gluconeogenesis.

Option C: Cerebral malaria

  • There is neurologic involvement, too, manifesting as repeated seizures and coma; therefore, it is also known as cerebral malaria.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to the emergency with complaints of shortness of breath, hypotension, and blueness of the skin. These symptoms developed 6 hours after he had a right hemicolectomy. The hemodynamic data is obtained, and these pressures are noted: RA = 12 mm Hg, RV = 50/12 mm Hg, PA=50/15 mm Hg,PA wedge pressure = 8 mm Hg, Aorta=80/60,Cardiac Index = 1.4, SVR= 1800, PVR=500. Which of the following conditions is most likely to occur in a patient with this hemodynamic data?

choices.text: Acute MI with LVF and cardiogenic shock

questions.solution:
Option A: Acute massive pulmonary embolism

Normal pressure Value given ( in mmHg) Interpretation
RA = 2-6 mmHg 12 Elevated
RV = 25/5 mmHg 50/12 Elevated
Pulmonary artery = 25/10mmHg 50/15 Elevated
PCWP = 8 -12 mmHg 8 Normal
Aorta = < 120/80 80/60 Hypotension
  • Obstruction of the pulmonary arterial tree that exceeds fifty percent of the cross-sectional area is referred to as a massive pulmonary embolism.
  • This condition causes acute and severe cardiopulmonary failure as a result of right ventricular overload.
  • This is a potentially lethal condition.
  • The predominant involvement of the left side of the heart can be excluded because normal PCWP levels are present.
  • It can be concluded that acute MI with LVF is not the cause.
  • Shock due to decreased blood volume that followed; however, despite the patient having elevated pressure values on the right side of the heart and gastroenteritis will lead to the right side of the heart not being adequately filled with blood.
  • However, despite the patient's low blood pressure, the early stages of septic shock will result in an increased cardiac output.
  • When combined with PAH, an increase in RA and PV pressure points to a problem in the RV.
  • A decrease in blood flow to the lungs will result in a drop in systemic blood pressure.
  • As a result, the patient exhibits symptoms consistent with acute cor-pulmonale.

Option B: Acute MI with LVF and cardiogenic shock

  • The predominant involvement of the left side of the heart can be excluded because normal PCWP levels are present. It can be concluded that acute MI with LVF is not the cause.

Option C: Hypovolemic shock following gastroenteritis

  • Hypovolemic shock with gastroenteritis will lead to the right side of the heart not being adequately filled with blood.

Option D: Early septic shock

  • Despite the patient's low blood pressure, the early stages of septic shock will result in an increased cardiac output.

questions.text: A forty-five years old male is brought to the emergency department with complaints of unbearable abdominal pain for the past 24 hours associated with 3 episodes of vomiting. He also states that he has had a fever for the past 2 days and felt nauseous the whole time. Examinations and laboratory investigations were performed. Blood reports show elevated serum lipase. An abdominal ultrasound is performed, which indicates the presence of acute pancreatitis. Which of the following is not a cause of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hypocalcaemia

  • Inflammation of the pancreas over a short period of time is known as acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis commonly presents with fever, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.
  • Elevated levels of serum pancreatic enzymes are used to diagnose acute pancreatitis.
  • The causes of acute pancreatitis are listed below:
Alcohol
Gallstones and Biliary tract disease
Hypertriglyceridemia, Hypercalcemia
Drugs (azathioprine, 6-mercaptopurine, valproic acid, anti-HIV medications)
ERCP, Postoperative, Blunt abdominal trauma
Cystic fibrosis, Periampullary diverticulum
Infections (mumps, coxsackie virus, cytomegalovirus, echovirus, parasites)
  • Hypocalcemia does not cause acute pancreatitis.

Option B: Valproic acid therapy

  • Acute pancreatitis is a potentially fatal complication of valproic acid therapy.

Option C:  Biliary tract disease

  • Biliary tract disease causes inflammation of the pancreas, resulting in pancreatitis.

Option D: Blunt trauma

  • Blunt abdominal trauma is a cause of pancreatitis due to injury against the vertebral column.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the physician with complaints of dysphagia with episodic melena, muscle pain, rash, fatigue, and dyspnea on exertion, and painful swelling of his fingers with occasional discoloration in his fingertips for 1 week. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and the examination of the hands reveals sclerodactyly, digital pits & ulceration. Initial investigations were done. Which of the following test can be for the diagnosis of the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anti-nuclear antibody

  • This is a case of scleroderma in which the patient presents with complaints of dysphagia with frequent regurgitation, chronic Malena, myalgias, pruritus, progressive fatigue and dyspnea on exertion, and painful swelling of his fingers with occasional discoloration in his fingertips.
  • Examination findings of hands in involve sclerodactyly, digital pits &ulceration.
  • Anti-nuclear antibody- ANA is the screening method of choice for systemic rheumatic diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (S.L.E.), mixed connective tissue disease, Sjogren syndrome, scleroderma, CREST syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, polymyositis, and dermatomyositis.
  • These are a group of autoantibodies directed against different nuclear antigens such as D.N.A., R.N.A., histones, etc.
  • ANA can also be found in healthy sometimes.

Option B: U l- Ribonucleoprotein antibody

  • Anti-U1ribonucleo protein antibody is usually known to be a marker of Mixed connective tissue disease.
  • M.C.T.D. is an autoimmune disease with mixed symptoms of polymyositis, S.L.E., and scleroderma.

Option C: Anti- L.K.M antibody

  • The anti-liver-kidney microsomal antibody is found in chronic delta hepatitis.
  • It is sometimes also associated with chronic hepatitis due to the hepatitis C virus.

Option D: Anti- topoisomerase antibody

  • A.T.A. are autoantibodies that are directed against topoisomerase.
  • Mostly associated with scleroderma.
  • A.T.A. is usually not used for screening purposes in scleroderma

questions.text: An elderly female patient occupationally teacher presents to the medicine outpatient department. She was complaining of a severe right-sided throbbing headache. Upon history taking, the patient informed that she has a history of polymyalgia rheumatica. The patient also had a history of undocumented weight loss because she had difficulty eating and was constantly fatigued. On further examination, she also complained of aching of the jaw during chewing. The result of the prescribed lab investigation showed the results of elevated ESR. The symptoms mentioned earlier indicate a vascular disease. Which statement is correct regarding the disease?

choices.text: Large vessel vasculitis is commonly seen in patients aged <50 years
Steroids are contraindicated in this vasculitis
50% of the patient present with ocular symptoms that vary from diplopia to complete vision loss
It is medium-vessel necrotizing vasculitis in young adults

questions.solution:
Option C: 50% of the patient present with ocular symptoms that vary from diplopia to complete vision loss

Giant cell arteritis:

  • Also known as "Temporal Arteritis."
  • GCA is a granulomatous large vessel vasculitis of the aorta and its branches, preferably the temporal artery.
  • GCA affecting cranial branches of the aortic arch :
    • Superficial temporal arteries (most common)
    • Ophthalmic arteries

 

  • Clinical features:
    • A disease of the elderly (age > 50)
    • Female predominance
  • Symptoms - constitutional:
    • fever,
    •  fatigue,
    • weight loss
  • Temporal artery:
    • Ipsilateral headache
    • Tender artery and scalp
    • Absent TA pulse
  • Ophthalmic artery : (optical symptoms)
    • Optic neuritis
    • Diplopia to complete vision loss in 50 % of patients
    • Amaurosis fugax
  • Facial artery:
    • Jaw claudication (pain on chewing due to ischemia of masseter muscles).
  • Diagnosis:
    • Diagnosis is based on clinical features + elevated ESR + prompt response to steroid.
    • Elevated ESR.
    • Elevated CRP
    • Normocytic normochromic anemia
    • Temporal artery biopsy
  • Treatment:
  • Steroids (Prednisone at 40–60 mg daily for 1 month with gradual tapering).
  • Do not await biopsy and pathology reports to start steroids.
  • Monitor clinical status and ESR.

Option A: Large vessel vasculitis is commonly seen in patients aged <50 years.

  • In Asia, Takayasu's Arteritis is the most common vasculitis in young and middle-aged patients (age <50).
  • It is granulomatous large vessel  vasculitis affecting
  • Aortic arch vessels
  • Pulmonary arteries ( half of the cases)
  • Clinical features :
    • Fatigue, malaise, weight loss, arthralgia
    • Anaemia and elevated ESR
    • Visual field defects and retinal haemorrhages
    • Systolic BP <10mm Hg b/w arms
    • Loss of pulse in upper extremities
  • Female predominant
  • Angiography is the most accurate test.
  • It shows occlusions, stenosis and aneurysms.
  • Treatment:
    • Steroids (high dose)
    • Immunosuppressant

Option B: Steroids are contraindicated in this vasculitis

  • Steroids are contraindicated in Kawasaki disease (medium-sized vessel vasculitis) due to the danger of vessel rupture.
  • Kawasaki is treated with Aspirin (NSAID) and IV Immunoglobin.
  • GCA is treated with high and low-dose steroids.
  • Corticosteroids are used in GCA to improve the visual acuity of the patient.
  • There is a severe danger of blindness in untreated patients.

 

Option D: It is medium-vessel necrotizing vasculitis in young adults.

  • Polyarteritis Nodusa is necrotizing vasculitis involving medium-sized vessels in young adults, predominately male.
  • It spares pulmonary arteries.
  • Clinical features:
    • Constitutional:  weight loss, fever, fatigue
    • Musculoskeletal: arthritis, myalgias, arthralgias
    • Renal: hypertension,  renal failure
    • CNS: peripheral neuropathies, mononeuritis multiplex, stroke
    • GI: abdominal pain, cholecystitis
    • Skin: palpable purpura, ulceration
    • Lab findings :
      • Elevated ESR
      • Hepatitis B surface antigen (in 30% of cases)
  • Treatment:
    • Corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide
    • Anti-viral therapy for hepatitis B-related PAN

questions.text: You are a first-year medicine resident rotating in the department of haematology. A group of patients came for follow-up after having allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. Which of the following has the least 5-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Blast crisis in CML

  • Blast crisis in CML has the least five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • The median survival time is <1.5 years.

Option A: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency syndrome

  • Severe Combined Immunodeficiency syndrome has a 90% five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Aplastic Anemia

  • Aplastic anaemia has a 90% five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia has a 50% five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: 33 years male presented to the clinic with the complaint of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. On examination, there is mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation over the lips. Histopathological examination showed arborisation and pseudo invasion. Genetic analysis revealed that the gene responsible for the condition is LKB1/STK11. Colonoscopy revealed multiple polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Peutz – Jeghers syndrome

  • It is an autosomal dominant disease
  • The most com­mon location in the small intestine is the jejunum. Although, it may occur in the stomach or colon & with much lower frequency in the bladder and lungs
  • There is germline loss of function mutations in the LKB1/STK11 gene.
  • There are multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps along with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.
  • Grossly the polyps are large and pedunculated with lobulated contour
  • On histopathology, they are characterised by the proliferation of the muscularis mucosae to form branching configurations covered by hypertrophic but normal mucosa

 

Option A: Familial adenomatous polyposis

  • FAP, also known as familial polyposis coli (FPC), is an autosomal dominant polyposis condition with different degrees of penetrance.
  • If left untreated, patients will grow hundreds to thousands of polyps throughout the colon and rectum.
  • Polyps commonly appear in the early adolescent years and, if left untreated, result in a nearly 100% lifetime risk of colorectal cancer by the age of forty.
  • Colectomy is required to significantly reduce the chance of developing colorectal cancer.
  • FAP is linked to various cancers, including gastric and duodenal cancers, hepatoblastomas, and desmoid tumours.

Option B: Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer

  • Lynch syndrome, commonly known as hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an autosomal dominant trait and the most common cause of inherited colorectal cancer (CRC).
  • It is distinguished by a substantial family history of HNPCC-associated malignancies involving first-degree relatives spanning at least two generations and at least one case identified before age 50.

Option D: Neurofibromatosis

  • Neurofibromatosis is a neurocutaneous condition characterised by nerve system and skin malignancies.
  • Types 1 and 2 neurofibromatoses are the Von Recklinghausen's disease, is an autosomal dominant condition.
  • Type 1 neurofibromatosis is characterised by neurofibromas, cafe-au-lait macules, freckling, and optic gliomas. It is a clinical diagnosis.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is distinguished by bilateral vestibular schwannomas (VS) and meningiomas. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
  • Clinical monitoring and medicinal intervention are the mainstays of treatment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old air-conditioner technician is referred to a psychiatrist because of a change in behavior and deterioration of occupational functioning. When he feels the gush of cold air coming from the air conditioner, he interprets the cold air as poison gas from Mars. It has resulted in severe anxiety and depression for him, leading to financial and emotional disability. What type of psychiatric phenomenon is this person suffering from?
questions.solution:
Option B: Delusional perception

  • In delusional perception, a delusion is attached to normal perception.
  • The patient believes that a normal percept has a special meaning for him.
  • In the above case, feeling a gush of cold air from the air conditioner is a normal perception, while the claim that the cold air is a poison gas from Mars is a delusion linked to this normal perception.
  • It is caused by an imbalance of neurotransmitters in the brain and can be triggered by stress.
  • It is a pathognomonic symptom of schizophrenia.
  • The other example is, misinterpreting the clouds as a sign of help from God to save the world.

Option A: Illusion

  • Illusion is the misapprehension of a real external stimulus.
  • For example, a stick may be taken as a snake.
  • While in delusional perception, a normal perception is linked with a false belief.

Option C: Tactile hallucination

  • Tactile hallucination is a false perception of touch in the absence of a real external stimulus.
  • It is commonly seen in cocaine abusers who report a feeling of parasites running over the skin.

Option D: Primary delusion

  • Primary delusion is a false fixed belief with no preceding ideas or events.
  • For example, a patient believes that his wife is cheating while, in actuality, she is not.
  • When a normal perception is linked with a false belief, such as in the given scenario, it is called delusional perception.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of mania?
questions.solution:
Presence of disorientation or disturbance of consciousness suggests an organic mental disorder like delirium.

Symptoms of Mania: Symptoms of Delirium:
Elevated mood Disturbances of Consciousness
Grandiosity and expansiveness Disorientation to time, place & person
Irritability and impulsivity Perceptional Disturbances like Illusions & Hallucinations
Disinhibition
Assaultiveness
Distractibility
Flight of ideas
Pressured speech
Impaired judgment
Psychotic symptoms

HOW TO REMEMBER: orientation is not affected in mood disorders.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male was referred by his primary care physician after presenting to the Emergency Room with difficulty breathing. His general physician was unable to find a medical explanation for his symptoms, which left the patient feeling confused, angry, or stressed sometimes. Over the last 8 months, the patient has had several episodes where he felt an extreme fear that would reach its maximum within a few hours. During these episodes, he would experience sweating, palpitations, and shortness of breath. As a result, the patient is persistently worried about having another attack. In addition, he avoids unfamiliar places and people where it may be difficult to get help. It is associated with disturbances in all of the following neurotransmitters EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Option C: Glutamate

  • Glutamate is a correct answer as it has very limited role in panic attacks.
  • The suspected diagnosis here is a panic attack.
  • Disturbance in glutamate levels is not associated with panic attacks.
  • Abnormal glutamate levels contribute to specific neurological disorders such as Huntington’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
  • Panic attacks are acute periods of intense fear and discomfort that may include chest pain or chest discomfort, palpitations, sweating, shortness of breath, dizziness, numbness, confusion, or a feeling of losing control. The duration varies from seconds to hours. Although they are extremely distressing, panic attacks are not physically dangerous themselves.

  • Panic attacks occur due to many disorders, including social anxiety disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, medical problems, substance use disorder, and depression.
  • Serotonin, norepinephrine, and GABA are the major neurotransmitters involved in panic attacks. Cholecystokinin and Dopamine are also known to cause panic attacks. While dopamine has limited role in panic attacks.
  • Treatment of panic attacks should be directed at helping with the underlying cause. In patients with frequent episodes, counseling or drugs may be used. Breathing exercises and muscle relaxation techniques are also helpful in some cases. Those affected have a higher risk of suicide.

Option A: Serotonin

  • It is a false statement as it is involved panic attacks.
  • Serotonin is the major neurotransmitter involved in panic attacks.

Option B: GABA

  • It is a false statement as it is involved panic attacks.
  • GABA is one of the major neurotransmitters involved in panic attacks.

Option D: Cholecystokinin and Dopamine

  • It is a false statement as they are involved in panic attacks.
  • Cholecystokinin and Dopamine are also known to cause panic attacks. While dopamine has limited role in panic attacks

questions.text:
Culture Club frontman Boy George described a bad trip in his 1995 autobiography, "Take It Like a Man." George got bored waiting after taking the first tab and took a second dose, so when the drug finally took effect, the trip was very intense.
It can take anywhere from 30 to 90 minutes to start feeling the effects. These effects can last up to 12 hours, depending on how much you've taken.
George and his friends headed to a club. After going through feelings of paranoia about the police presence outside the club, and upsetting another celebrity, George began to feel that he had lost control of his body. The visual hallucinations made it feel like "everything was breathing and coming at me. I started shrinking and feeling scared. We had to leave."
He upset most of his companions, who left him with his pal Marilyn. By then, George had lost control of his bodily functions. "I was tripping so badly I couldn't get myself to the toilet. Marilyn led me to the loo in hysterics and left me staring at the bowl. I caught my melting face in the mirror and started to freak. 'I can't go, I can't' [then] I pissed myself." Bad trips are characteristically associated with the addiction of :
questions.solution:
• Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) & Psilocybin (magic mushroom) are among the MOST COMMONLY used hallucinogens.
    • Perceptual changes occur within 40 minutes of oral ingestion.
    • Vision is affected most often; the subject experiences heightened visual awareness of objects, especially colours.
    • Images may be distorted in shape or size and true hallucinations occur.
    • These may be pleasurable but also terrifying in nature, the experience then being referred to as a ‘bad trip’.
    • There may also be distorted perception, of time, sounds and tactile sensations.

-Flashback experiences can occur several months after the last dose; during these the psychotic experiences of LSD are experienced again with their original intensity.

HOW TO REMEMBER:Trips are incomplete without good music. In LSD abuse, people listen to colours (reflex hallucinations)

questions.text: A 67-year-old female presents in the surgical outpatient department due to the progressively increasing size of her left breast for the last 2 months. She also complains of itching, heaviness, and an increased temperature in her left breast. Physical examination reveals widespread erythema, intense edema, and areolar erosion of the breast, with several enlarged axillary lymph nodes on the left side. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy

questions.solution:
Option A: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy

  • This elderly female with skin thickening, erythema, the warmth of her breast, and palpable axillary lymph nodes most likely has locally invasive inflammatory breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast carcinoma accounts for <3% of breast cancers.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer is a subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma which does not commonly present with a palpable lump.
  • It usually presents with an inflamed, swollen breast with thickening of the overlying skin (peau d’orange appearance) due to blockage of dermal lymphatics.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer can sometimes be misdiagnosed as mastitis due to its presentation.
  • At least 33% of skin over the breast is involved with a history of rapid onset and progression.
  • More than 75% of women have palpable axillary lymphadenopathy and distant metastasis.
  • This patient most likely has stage IIIB breast cancer (tumor spread to the chest wall and axillary lymph nodes with no involvement of other organs).
  • The treatment of inflammatory breast cancer includes neoadjuvant chemotherapy (given before the surgery) to reduce tumor size.
  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is followed by modified radical mastectomy (removal of the entire breast including skin, nipple, areola, and axillary lymph nodes with sparing of the pectoralis major and minor muscles).
  • Modified radical mastectomy is followed by radiotherapy to remove any residual tumor cells.

Option B: Radical mastectomy followed by chemotherapy

  • Radical mastectomy involves the removal of the entire breast, nipple, areola, overlying skin, axillary lymph nodes, and pectoralis major and minor muscles.
  • Patients with inflammatory breast cancer are treated with modified radical mastectomy as it has better outcomes than radical mastectomy.

Option C: Radical mastectomy followed by radiotherapy

  • The treatment of inflammatory breast cancer is initiated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
  • In addition, modified radical mastectomy is preferred over radical mastectomy for treating inflammatory breast cancer.

Option D: Chemotherapy followed by hormone therapy

  • Chemotherapy and hormonal therapy are the mainstays of treatment for metastatic breast cancer (that has spread to other body organs).
  • This patient has locally invasive inflammatory breast cancer that can be treated with chemotherapy, surgery, and radiotherapy.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive treatment for stage III breast cancer to remove residual cancer from the chest wall and axilla.

questions.text: A 13-year-old male presents to the surgery OPD with complaints of soft swelling in front of his neck associated with difficulty swallowing for the last 5 months. He also reports pain in the skin around the swelling. His neck examination reveals a soft midline swelling in front of the neck, which moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following statements is true about the given condition?

choices.text: The most common location is sub-hyoid
Follicular carcinoma is seen in 1% of patients

questions.solution:
Option A: The most common location is subhyoid

  • In the case discussed above, the patient's clinical features of soft midline swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue suggest a thyroglossal cyst. Its most common location is the subhyoid region.
  • The image given in the question above shows a thyroglossal cyst.
  • It is a congenital cystic remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • Most commonly found in the subhyoid region, always close to the midline. Mostly asymptomatic unless infected.
  • It is congenital, but the usual presentation age is 15 to 30.
  • There is an increased risk of malignancy (1%), usually papillary carcinoma (85%). Squamous cells, Hurthle cells, and anaplastic cancers have also been reported.
  • The cyst moves with deglutition, and it is the only swelling that moves up on tongue protrusion.
  • The treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst is surgical removal.
  • Infected thyroglossal duct cysts require immediate antibiotic treatment before surgery.

Option B: Occurs due to Trauma

  • A thyroglossal cyst is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • It is the most commonly encountered congenital cervical anomaly.

Option C: Follicular carcinoma is seen in 1% of patients

  • Follicular cancer is frequently present in the goitrous thyroid.
  • Papillary carcinoma is seen in 1% of patients with thyroglossal cysts.

Option D: Treated by Total Thyroidectomy

  • Total thyroidectomy (thyroid gland removal) is indicated in thyroid cancer, toxic multinodular goitre, toxic adenomas, goitre with compressive symptoms, and Graves’ disease.
  • Treatment of Thyroglossal cyst is done by Sistrunk operation:
    •  En bloc excision of the central part of the hyoid bone along with the cyst to minimize recurrence.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the surgery OPD with complaints of increased swelling in her neck over the previous 2 years. She has had a medical history of severe hearing loss since early childhood. On examination, she has a large goiter extending retrosternally with small irregular nodules, no audible bruit, and a negative Pemberton's sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option D: Pendred syndrome

  • The patient mentioned above has clinical features of sensory neural hearing loss associated with goitre. This presentation is typical of Pendred syndrome.
  • Presentation of Pendred syndrome:
    • Hearing loss or deafness
    • Speech impairment
    • Electrolyte/homeostasis imbalance
    • Goitre
    • Enlarged vestibular aqueduct
    • Hypothyroidism
  • Pendred Syndrome is the combination of sensorineural hearing loss with dyshormonogenetic goitre.
  • It is autosomal recessive. The affected gene is located on chromosome 7q.
  • There is a mutation of the PDS gene, which encodes for pendrin, the protein that transports iodide to the luminal surface of the follicular cell.

Other options

Option A: Werner syndrome

  • Werner syndrome (MEN1) occurs due to germline mutation in the MEN1 gene located in chromosome 11 that encodes menin. It is autosomal dominant hereditary cancer syndrome.
  • Symptoms and signs are shorter than average height, thin arms and legs, voice changes, thinning and greying hair, skin changes, and unusual facial features.

Option B: Turcot syndrome

  • Turcot syndrome is characterized by the following:
    • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).
    • Primary CNS tumors (astrocytoma or medulloblastoma).

Option C: Cowden syndrome

  • Cowden's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder due to mutations in PTEN.
  • Associated cancers include:
    • Breast carcinoma
    • Thyroid carcinoma
    • Endometrial carcinoma

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female underwent parathyroidectomy for parathyroid hyperplasia. On the 2nd postoperative day, the patient developed a carpal spasm when her blood pressure was measured. She developed facial twitching when her face was tapped anteriorly to the ear. Her serum chemistry report:


	
		
			
			Sodium
			
			138 mEq/L
		
		
			
			Potassium
			
			4.5 mEq/L
		
		
			
			Chloride
			
			104 mEq/L
		
		
			
			Calcium 
			
			7 mg/dL
		
		
			
			Bicarbonate
			
			22 mEq/L
		
		
			
			Blood urea nitrogen
			
			20 mg/dL
		
		
			Creatinine
			1.1 mg/dL
		
	


 

Which of the following best explains this patient's lab abnormalities and physical exam findings?
questions.solution:
Option B: Increased Calcium uptake by bones

  • The patient underwent parathyroidectomy, after which he developed signs of hypocalcemia: Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign. This suggests the diagnosis of hungry bone syndrome.
  • Hypocalcemia is due to increased bone uptake in the immediate postoperative period following parathyroidectomy. Hypocalcemia after parathyroidectomy is generally transient when the bone disease is mild. However, postoperative hypocalcemia can be prolonged and severe in patients with end-stage renal disease. This is called the “hungry bone syndrome.”
  • This syndrome is especially common in patients with osteitis fibrosa. In addition to hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperkalemia can also manifest.
  • The underlying pathogenesis is the acute reversal of the PTH effects on bone. In hyperparathyroidism, PTH increases both bone formation and resorption. Sudden reductions of circulating PTH after parathyroidectomy cause an imbalance between osteoblast-mediated bone formation and osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, leading to a marked net increase in bone uptake of calcium, phosphate, and magnesium. Thus, the hungry bone syndrome requires an abrupt decrease in PTH release that upsets the equilibrium between calcium efflux from bone and influx into the skeleton during bone remodeling.
  • The graph shows the course of development of hypocalcemia in hungry bone syndrome.

Option A: Increased urinary loss of calcium

  • Although the urinary loss of calcium can cause hypocalcemia and the resulting Chvostek and Trousseau sign, this is not the case here. This patient has a hungry bone syndrome which is mediated by the abrupt reversal of the PTH, leading to increased calcium uptake by the bones.

 

Option C: Increased calcitonin levels

  • Although increased calcitonin levels can cause hypocalcemia and the resulting Chvostek and Trousseau sign, this is not the case here. This patient has a hungry bone syndrome which is mediated by the abrupt reversal of the PTH, leading to increased calcium uptake by the bones.

 

Option D: Increased calcium binding with phosphorus

  • Although Increased calcium binding with phosphorus can cause hypocalcemia and the resulting Chvostek and Trousseau sign, this is not the case here. This patient has a hungry bone syndrome which is mediated by the abrupt reversal of the PTH, leading to increased calcium uptake by the bones.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with complaints of heartburn, nausea, and bone pain. An x-ray of the hand shows subperiosteal resorption in the middle phalanx of the middle finger. Laboratory studies show elevated PTH levels. Which one of the following is not a feature of the above condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Osteosclerosis

  • The above clinical case is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism (HPT). Osteosclerosis is not a feature of primary HPT.
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism (HPT):
    • Most are asymptomatic; if symptomatic, they have the following symptoms:
    • Pentad of symptoms: Kidney stones, painful bones, abdominal groans, psychic moans, fatigue overtones
    • Diagnosis:

Serum tests

Alteration

Calcium

Increased, except in normocalcemic primary HPT

Intact PTH

Increased

Chloride

Increased or high normal

Phosphate

Decreased or low normal

Chloride to phosphate ratio

Increased ( usually >33)

Magnesium

Unchanged or decreased (osteitis fibrosa cystica)

Uric acid

Normal or increased

Alkaline phosphatase

Normal or increased

Acid-base status

Mild hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis

Calcium to creatinine clearance ratio

>0.02

Urine tests

  

24-hour urinary calcium

Normal or increased

Preoperative localization studies

Preoperative Non-invasive

Preoperative Invasive

Sestamibi-technetium 99m scan 

FNAB (Fine needle aspiration biopsy)

Ultrasound

Angiogram

CT scan

Venous sampling

MRI scan

Intraoperative

Four-dimensional CT scan

PTH assay (to determine the adequacy of parathyroid resection)
  • Sestamibi-technetium 99m scan
    • Investigation of choice: Most widely used and accurate modality with a sensitivity >80%
    • Sestamibi concentrates in mitochondrial-rich tissue
    • Initially was introduced for cardiac imaging
  • Treatment: Proper treatment results in the resolution of osteitis fibrosa cystica and decreased formation of renal stones, improving bone mineral density.
    • Medical
      • Bisphosphonates
      • Hormone replacement therapy
      • Selective estrogen receptor modulators
    • Surgery: parathyroidectomy - Treatment of choice

Option A: Generalized osteoporosis

  • Generalized osteoporosis is common in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Option B: Renal calculi

  • Renal calculi is a common feature in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Option C: Hypercalcemia

  • Hypercalcemia is common in primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: What is the composition of the gallstones given below?

choices.text: Calcium oxalate + calcium phosphate + calcium stearate
Calcium bilirubinate + calcium palmitate + calcium stearate
Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium bicarbonate
Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium carbonate

questions.solution:
Option B: Calcium bilirubinate + calcium palmitate + calcium stearate 

  • The stones shown in the image are brownstones.
  • Gallstones:
    • The major organic solutes in bile are bilirubin, bile salts, phospholipids, and cholesterol.
    • Gallstones are classified by their cholesterol content as either cholesterol stones or pigment stones.
    • Pigment stones can be further classified as either black or brown.
      • Black stones - Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium bicarbonate
      • Brown pigment stones- calcium bilirubinate + calcium palmitate + calcium stearate+ cholesterol
        • Brownstones are brownish-yellow, soft, and mushy. They may form either in the gallbladder or in the bile ducts, secondary to bacterial infection and bile stasis. 

Option A: Calcium oxalate + calcium phosphate + calcium stearate

  • Calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones are more commonly seen in the kidney.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium bicarbonate 

  • This composition is of black pigmented stones.

Option D: Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium carbonate

  • This composition is not correct for the above-given brownstones.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman was admitted for appetite loss, nausea, and back pain. A physical examination revealed right hypochondriac tenderness and obvious jaundice.  MRCP revealed dilated intrahepatic and common hepatic bile ducts, distended gallbladder, and erosion of less than 1/3 of the circumference of common hepatic duct. What is the best next step in the management?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option A: Partial cholecystectomy + T- tube drainage

  • According to the Csendes classification, the best treatment for Mirizzi syndrome type II is partial cholecystectomy + T- tube drainage
  • Mirizzi’s syndrome
    • Obstruction of the bile ducts due to a severe pericholecystic inflammation secondary to the impaction of a stone in the infundibulum of the gallbladder is known as Mirizzi’s syndrome.
    • The prerequisite for this syndrome, characterized by gallbladder disease causing obstructive jaundice, include:
      • A cystic duct that courses parallel to the common hepatic duct
      • An impacted stone in the gallbladder neck or cystic duct
      • Obstruction of the common hepatic duct is caused by the stone or inflammatory response. The resultant inflammation can cause a cholecystocholedochal fistula.
      • It usually presents as jaundice or recurrent cholangitis. The presence of Mirizzi syndrome obliterates the triangle of Calot.

Other Options

Option B: Conservative management

  • The most common complication of Mirizzi syndrome is cholecystobiliary or cholecysto-enteric fistula formation due to prolonged inflammation.
  • Therefore, surgical management is required.

Option C: Partial cholecystectomy alone

  • Partial cholecystectomy alone is the treatment of choice for type I choledochal cysts.

Option D: Partial cholecystectomy + Bilioenteric anastomosis

  • The treatment of choice for type IV and V Partial cholecystectomy + Bilioenteric anastomosis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male patient was brought to the hospital with an altered state of consciousness. He has a history of chronic liver disease. On examination, there are mild ascites and tremors. Laboratory values show:


	Total Bilirubin - 2.5 mg/dL
	Albumin - 3 g/dL
	INR=2.0


Which class of Child Turcotte Pugh score does the patient belong to?
questions.solution:
Option C: Class C

  • The total score for the given patient amounts to 2+2+2+2+3=11 points, and hence he belongs to CTP Class C
  • Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) Scoring System and this patient have Grade 3 encephalopathy.
  • Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) Score:
Variable 1 Point 2 Point 3 Point
Serum albumin (g/dL)    >3.5      2.8-3.5 <2.8
Bilirubin (mg/dL)        <2          2-3       >3
Ascites None         Mild to Moderate   Severe
Encephalopathy  None  Grade I or II    Grade III or IV
Prothrombin time      
Seconds prolonged <4           4-6 >6
INR    <1.7   1.7-2.3  >2.3
  • Class A 5-6 points
  • Class B 7-9 points
  • Class C 10-15 points

Option A: Class A

  • Class A has points 5-6. This patient's point is 11, so the class should be C.

Option B: Class B

  • Class B has points 7-9. This patient's point is 11, so the class should be C.

Option D: Class D

  • There are a total of three classes (Class A, B, and C) in the child Pugh scoring system.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with dysphagia, vomiting, and pallor. Diagnosed with Stage III gastric carcinoma involving the body of the stomach extending into the cardia. which of the following is False about gastric carcinoma?

choices.text: More in the low socioeconomic group
H. pylori infection increases the risks
Vitamin C has a protective effect

questions.solution:
Option B: More common in young females

  • This patient is suffering from stage III gastric carcinoma in the body of the stomach extending into cardia. It is more common in older men rather than young females.

Option A: More in the low socioeconomic group

  • Stage III gastric carcinoma is more common in the low socioeconomic group due to low food quality or a higher risk of infections.

Option C: H. pylori infection increases the risks

  • H. pylori infection increases the risks of stage III gastric carcinoma.
  • Other diseases which increase the risk of gastric carcinoma include:
  • Epstein-Barr virus
  • Gastric atrophy and gastritis
  • Adenomatous polyps

Option D: Vitamin C has a protective effect

  • Vitamin C has a protective effect against stage III gastric carcinoma.
  • The following substances also decrease the risk:
  • Aspirin
  • High fresh fruit and vegetable intake

questions.text: Which of the following best associates with the clinical condition that includes abdominal distension, diffuse abdominal pain, and growth of E. coli on the ascitic fluid culture medium of a patient with cirrhosis?

choices.text: Multiple organisms are isolated from ascitic fluid
3rd Generation cephalosporin is the antibiotic of choice

questions.solution:
Option D: 3rd generation cephalosporin is the antibiotic of choice

  • The given scenario is a classic case of Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) characterized by fever and abdominal pain in ascites.
    • The common culprit microorganisms include  E. coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Antibiotics must be administered just after an ascitic fluid sample has been taken for the culture and sensitivity.
    • Anbibiotics for SBP is indicated only when the patients with ascites have one of the following.
      • Temperature greater than 37.8°C (100°F)
      • Abdominal pain and tenderness
      • Altered mental status
      • Ascitic fluid polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMN) count ≥250 cells/microL
    • Third-generation cephalosporins are the preferred antibiotics for patients having a CLID-SOFA score < 7.
      • For patients with CLIF-SOFA scores equal to or greater than 7, IV Carbepenems are the preferred antibiotics.

 

Option A: Ascitic fluid neutrophil count is > 350 /cumm

  • The diagnostic criterion is an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of > 250/cubic millimetre.

 

Option B: Bowel perforation should be present

  • Bowel perforation is part of the diagnostic criterion of the acute abdomen, and it causes moderate to severe abdominal pain, not a dull one. It is often associated with hemodynamic instability and can cause secondary peritonitis.

Option C: Multiple organisms are isolated from ascitic fluid

  • Multiple enteric organisms are present in peritoneal lavage in the settings of bowel perforation. 
    • SBP is caused by one of many microorganisms, including
      • Escherichia coli
      • Klebsiella pneumoniae
      • Streptococcus pneumoniae
      • Enterobacteriaceae
      • Staphylococcus
      • Pseudomonas
      • Other streptococcal species

questions.text: A 58-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of hematemesis and melena. He has been suffering from abdominal discomfort and vomiting for many months. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and his pulse is 60/min. On physical examination, he is pale and thin. There are also swollen lymph nodes in the left supraclavicular region . On further evaluation with endoscopy and imaging modalities, the patient is diagnosed with a case of locally advanced gastric carcinoma. Which of the following is an investigation of choice to know the depth of cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - EUS:

  • EUS (endoscopic ultrasound) is a minimally invasive procedure to assess the digestive tract and nearby organs.
  • It uses a thin, flexible tube inserted into the gastrointestinal tract and a device that uses sound waves to create images.
  • This endoscopic tube also has a small needle to remove fluid or tissue samples for biopsy.
  • The best way to stage the tumour locally is via EUS, which gives fairly accurate (80%) information about the depth of tumour penetration into the gastric wall and can show enlarged (>5mm) perigastric and celiac lymph nodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CECT:

  • CECT is Contrast-enhanced Computed tomography.
  • It is used for imaging the different structures, and the contrast helps to improve the visualisation.
  • In this procedure, a beam of x-ray moves all around the body and different images are taken to form a dimensional image.
  • During surgeries, it is used to place a needle at a specific point for biopsies or aspiration.
