  • It helps to visualise the tumours or other diseases before or after treatment.

Option B - MRI:

  • MRI (magnetic resonance) is an imaging test that uses powerful magnets and radio waves.
  • These waves create images of the inside of the abdomen and do not use radiation.
  • Single MRI images are called slices stored on a computer and viewed on a monitor.
  • MRI is mainly used for brain and spinal cord injuries (stroke, tumour, aneurysms)
  • MRI of the abdomen is mainly used for the following:
    • Blood flow in the abdomen
    • Blood vessels in the abdomen
    • Lymph nodes
    • Masses in the liver, kidney, pancreas, and spleen.

Option C - Barium:

  • Different types of barium x-ray examinations are used to determine different parts.
  • A barium swallow is used to study the pharynx and esophagus.
  • A mixture of barium is swallowed in the supine position, and images are taken.
  • A barium meal is used to study the lower esophagus and stomach.
  • Barium follow-through is used to study the small intestine.
  • A barium enema is used to study the large intestine and rectum.
  • It is used for the following purposes:
    • Diagnosis of tumour
    • Location of tumour
    • Ulceration
    • Strictures

questions.text: A  38-year-old male presents with complaints of discharge in the perianal region associated with pain. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have multiple fistulae in ano. On colonoscopy, multiple aphthous ulcers are seen in the entire colon with skip areas in between. Which of the following is the true statement regarding the condition that has caused the fistula?

choices.text: Ulceration, fistula and abscess formation is common
Cutting setons are used in management
Sphincterotomy and fissurectomy are procedures of choice for fistulas caused by Crohn’s disease

questions.solution:
Option A: Ulceration, fistula and abscess formation is common

  • Perianal Crohn’s disease may include fissures, fistulas and abscesses
  • Fissures of Crohn’s disease are often multiple, off midline lesions

Option B: Fistulas are painful and indurated

  • Fistulas tend to be chronic, indurated and are often painless.
  • The disease activity is measured by the Perianal Crohn’s Disease Activity Index, a scoring system that uses five categories
    • Discharge
    • Pain
    • Restriction of sexual activity
    • Type of perianal disease
    • Degree of induration

Option C: Cutting setons are used in management

  • Simple, low to mid fistulas may be treated with fistulotomy or staged with seton placement.
  • Complex fistulas with extensive proctitis requires drainage with setons and initiation of immuno-modulator therapy.

Option D: Sphincterotomy and fissurectomy are procedures of choice for fistulas caused by Crohn’s disease

  • Sphincterotomy and fissurectomy should be avoided when Crohn’s disease is present.

questions.text: Which of the following hernia is associated with hydrocele?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gibbon’s hernia

  • The patient mentioned above has features of a soft, non-tender mass that transilluminates and a positive cough impulse, suggesting a diagnosis of hernia with hydrocele, called Gibbon's hernia.
  • Gibbon’s hernia is a hernia with hydrocele.
    • Indirect Inguinal hernia occurs as a failure of the processus vaginalis to close, and it protrudes through the inguinal ring.
    • The opening of processus vaginalis should normally close on its own during development, but it remains open, and parts of the abdomen (bowel and fat) can enter the sac.
    • If the opening is only wide enough to let in fluid, this creates a hydrocele.
    • Presentation of hernia along with hydrocele gives rise to Gibbon's hernia.

Option B: Berger’s hernia

  • It is a hernia in the pouch of Douglas.
  • It does not present with hydrocele.

Option C: Beclard’s hernia

  • It refers to a femoral hernia through the opening of the saphenous vein.
  • It does not lead to the formation of a hydrocele.

Option D: Stammer’s hernia

  • It refers to an internal hernia occurring through a window in the transverse mesocolon after retro colic gastrojejunostomy.
  • Hydrocele is not a feature of Stammer's hernia.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to the surgical clinic by his mother, with a complaint of an absent left testis in the left scrotum. The mother noticed this condition about three days ago. The doctor on duty examined both scrotums and found that one testis was missing from the left side, and a mass was palpable in the left inguinal region. Can you identify which statement is true about the condition?

choices.text: Atrophy of Leydig cells & decrease in tubular diameter can occur by two years of age.
No effect on spermatogenesis in this condition
Histologic and morphologic changes can be seen in the testis as early as two months of age
Surgery should be done before 3yr of age for optimal result

questions.solution:
Cryptorchidism is a condition in which one testis or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum before birth. Upto 30% of preterm infants and 3% of full term infants can present with cryptorchidism. Some undescended testes eventually descend by 1 year of age but they are unlikely to descend after this time.

When the testicle is not present within the scrotum, it is subjected to a higher temperature resulting in decreased spermatogenesis. The undescended testis is associated with histologic and morphologic changes as early as 6 months of age; atrophy of Leydig cells, decrease in tubular diameter and impaired spermatogenesis can occur by 2 years of age

It is now recommended that the undescended testicle can be surgically repositioned by 1 year of age to facilitate spermatogenesis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is posted for reconstruction surgery after being diagnosed and treated with a malignant lesion on her nose. The surgeon takes the tissue from an adjacent area and applies it to the area of the defect, as shown in the image below:



Which of the following types of flaps is used?
questions.solution:
Option A: Bilobed flap

  • The flap shown in the image is a bilobed flap.

Local flaps

  • Flap transferred from an area adjacent to the defect. This is known as a local flap.
  • A local flap is raised next to a tissue defect to reconstruct it.
  • Bilobed flap- For convex surfaces, especially the nose.
  • Bilobed flap is a type of local flap

Distant flaps

  • A flap transferred from a different anatomic site (i.e., from a different part of the body) is referred to as a distant flap.

Option B: Advancement flap

  • They are incised flaps that generate unidirectional movement to cover an existing defect created by trauma.
  • This flap is often used on the scalp to repair small mucosal lining defects adjacent to the nasal rim or for septal perforation repair.

Option C: Rhomboid flap

  • Rhomboid flaps are full-thickness cutaneous local flaps that typically rely on dermal–subdermal plexus blood supply
  • It is rhomboid in shape

Option D: Z-plasty

  • Z-plasty is a plastic surgery technique used to improve the functional and cosmetic appearance of scars.
  • The image shown is not of z-plasty

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl with a history of seizures comes to the emergency department because of headaches and more frequently occurring seizures. Physical examination shows patches of leathery-appearing and hypopigmented skin lesions scattered over her body. A subungual nodule is found on her left thumb. CT scan of the brain shows subependymal nodules, cortical foci with loss of the gray-white matter distinction, and a nodule partially obstructing the cerebral aqueduct. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Giant-cell astrocytoma

  • Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is an autosomal dominant disorder with genetic heterogeneity.
  • The brain tumours that are most commonly found in tuberous sclerosis are cortical tubers, subependymal nodules, or giant cell astrocytomas.
  • Giant-cell astrocytomas are low-grade neoplasms that appear to develop from the hamartomatous nodules in the brain.

Option A: Craniopharyngioma

  • Craniopharyngioma is a type of brain tumour derived from pituitary gland embryonic tissue that occurs most commonly in children but also in adults.
  • Initial symptoms may be bitemporal inferior quadrantanopia leading to bitemporal hemianopsia, as the tumour may compress the optic chiasm.

Option B: Ependymoma

  • Ependymomas are tumours that usually arise in the ventricular system of the brain, including the central canal of the spinal cord. In the first two decades of life, they typically occur near the fourth ventricle.
  • Posterior fossa ependymomas manifest with hydrocephalus secondary to obstruction of the fourth ventricle.

Option D: Medulloblastoma

  • This malignant embryonal tumour occurs most commonly in children.
  • Medulloblastomas are typically located in the midline of the cerebellum. This tumour is often well-circumscribed and rapid growth may occlude the flow of CSF, leading to hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 43-year-old teacher was scheduled for a left parotidectomy to remove a pleomorphic adenoma involving the left parotid gland. The surgery was completed without any complications. Upon awakening after the surgery, paralysis of the left lower lip was observed. Which of the following structures were injured during this patient’s surgery?

choices.text: The buccal branch of the facial nerve
The main trunk of the facial nerve

questions.solution:
Option C: Division of platysma muscle

  • This patient with lower lip weakness after parotidectomy has most likely suffered an injury to the platysma muscle.
  • The treatment for benign parotid tumors such as pleomorphic adenoma is superficial parotidectomy (surgical excision with the margin of normal tissue).
  • The facial nerve must be preserved during the procedure. The facial nerve exits the skull through the stylomastoid foramen. It enters the parotid gland at a distance of about 1 cm or less and then divides into two branches, a larger temporofacial and a smaller cervicofacial branch.
  • The larger temporofacial branch gives off the temporal branch and the zygomatic branch.
  • The smaller cervicofacial branch forms the buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical branches.
  • The temporal branch innervates the frontalis, corrugator supercilii, and orbicularis oculi muscle.
  • The zygomatic branch supplies the orbicularis oculi muscle.
  • Buccal branches supply the buccinator and the orbicularis oris muscle.
  • The marginal mandibular branch supplies the mentalis, depressor labii inferioris and depressor anguli oris.
  • The cervical branch supplies the platysma muscle in the neck. Platysma inserts on the margin of the lower jaw and are susceptible to injury during superficial parotidectomy.
  • The main methods of locating the facial nerve trunk can be divided into antegrade and retrograde methods.
  • Several anatomic landmarks are used to identify the facial nerve. Some landmarks include the stylomastoid foramen, squamotympanic fissure, the upper edge of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle, mastoid process. The Conley pointer is present at the lower part of the cartilage canal. The facial nerve is 1 cm deep and below this point.
  • The retrograde technique is based on identifying one of the nerve branches, which is then proximally followed until the main trunk is identified.

Option A: Parotid duct

  • Parotid gland injury during parotidectomy leads to the formation of a parotid fistula that presents with a continuous outpouring of parotid secretions through a tract that connects the skin with the parotid duct or the parotid gland.

Option B: Buccal branch of the facial nerve

  • The lesion of the buccal branch of the facial nerve leads to paralysis of the buccinator muscle. This causes the inability to clear food from the mouth as the food gets stuck in the cheek on the affected side.

Option D: The main trunk of the facial nerve

  • Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve leads to ipsilateral facial palsy that presents with the inability to close the eye, inability to smile, and difficulty making facial expressions. Both the upper and lower parts of the ipsilateral face are involved.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of injuries after falling off a ladder. He describes falling about 5 feet off the ground and suffering blunt trauma to his perineum and penis, resulting in immediate pain lasting for 5 minutes. Following the injury, the patient experienced burning with urination and noted large amounts of hematuria. He denies pain with ambulation and does not recall any trauma to the pelvis during the fall. Genitourinary examination reveals blood at the urethral meatus. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Observation and admission to the hospital

questions.solution:
Option D: Placement of a suprapubic catheter

  • Suprapubic catheterization is the best initial treatment for patients suffering from urethral injury following blunt pelvic trauma. Surgical intervention is delayed days or weeks after the initial injury.
  • An understanding of the anatomy and physiology of the male reproductive system is important to understand the need for this intervention.
  • Patients who present following urethral trauma should be initially managed in the context of other injuries. The best initial approach involves the placement of a suprapubic catheter for urinary drainage, which does not require urethral manipulation or invasion into the pelvic hematoma if one happens to be present. Ideally, surgical repair of posterior urethral injury is performed 6-12 weeks after injury, after stabilization of injuries an

Option A: Antibiotic therapy

  • Although antibiotic therapy is often required, it is important to first take measures to preserve organ function. It is paramount to establish bladder drainage, so suprapubic catheterization should take precedence.

Option B: Endoscopic transurethral realignment

  • Early endoscopic realignment using a transurethral, percutaneous transvesical, or combined approach may be attempted, but this should be done 5-7 days post-injury. By this time, the patient's overall condition has usually improved, and sepsis is less of a concern.

Option C: Observation and admission to the hospital

  • Observation with admission to the hospital is not adequate for the treatment of urethral injury and places the patient at risk for severe sequelae.

questions.text: A 22-year-old otherwise healthy male presented to the ER following a single gunshot wound to the left groin. On examination, the patient was hemodynamically stable but had no palpable lower extremity pulses on the injured side. The ankle-brachial index confirmed an arterial injury (<0.9). On immediate exploration, a transected superficial left femoral artery was identified. Which of the following is the suture with maximum tensile strength and minimum tissue reaction that can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Polypropylene

  • Polypropylene(Non-absorbable) has maximum tensile strength and minimum tissue reaction.
  • Polypropylene suture:
    • Polypropylene suture is a monofilament (non-absorbable surgical suture). It comprises an isotactic crystalline stereoisomer of polypropylene, a synthetic linear polyolefin. It is pigmented in blue colour to enhance visibility.
    • Polypropylene sutures elicit maximum tensile strength and minimal tissue reaction that does not cause tissue rupture.
    • This suture is indicated for use in general soft tissue approximation and ligation, including use in cardiovascular, plastic, neurological surgeries, ophthalmic, micro procedures, and hernia repair. It is the preferred suture material for vascular anastomosis. It is neither absorbed nor subjected to weakening by tissue enzymes, non-adhering, and biologically inert. Thus, it is used for permanent fixtures.

Option A: Poliglecaprone

  • Poliglecaprone is a synthetic absorbable sterile surgical suture composed of polymers made from 100% homo polymer of polyglycolide and caprolactone.  
  • It has been found non-antigenic and non-pyrogenic and exhibits slight tissue reaction during absorption. It is available in Undyed and Violet colours.  
  • It is an ideal approximation suture for subcuticular closure. It retains 50%-60% of its tensile strength for 7 days, 20%-30% for 14 days, provides wound support for 21-28 days and is absorbed through simple hydrolysis, and completely gets absorbed within 90-120 days which is predictable.

Option C: Polyglactin

  • Polyglactin is a synthetic absorbable sterile surgical suture. It is a co-polymer of 90% glycolide and 10% L-lactide.  
  • It retains tensile strength of about 70% till 14 days after implantation, it completely absorbs within 56-70 days by a simple hydrolytic mechanism, and its absorption is predictable.

Option D: Polydioxanone

  • Polydioxanone is a synthetic absorbable sterile surgical suture composed of polyester, poly (p-dioxanone).  
  • It is suitable for cases where extended wound support and strength are required.
  • It retains about 70% of the initial strength for 2 weeks, 50% for 4 weeks, and 25% for 6 weeks and is absorbed through simple hydrolysis and completely gets absorbed within 180-210 days.
  • The absorption of this suture is reliable and predictable.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain with distension, bilious vomiting, and fever for 3 weeks. He weighed 8 kg with a history of failure to thrive since early infancy. The abdomen was mildly distended with non-tender hepatomegaly. The chest radiograph was normal. USG suggested dilated large bowel loops that were peristaltic with moderate free fluid. The child was kept nil per oral and the fluid and electrolyte imbalance was corrected. Due to persistent bilious aspirates, an upper gastrointestinal (GI) contrast study was performed that suggested malrotation with  sigmoid volvulus. The patient was scheduled for surgery. Which of the following is a component of the procedure ?

choices.text: Reduction of volvulus by clockwise rotation
Ladd's band divided near the medial aspect of the duodenum
Part of the jejunum is resected and anastomosis performed

questions.solution:
Option A: Reduction of volvulus by counterclockwise wise rotation

  • Volvulus usually twists in a clockwise direction, and reduction is accomplished by twisting in a counterclockwise direction.

Volvulus:

  • A volvulus is the twisting of a loop of the intestine around its mesenteric attachment, resulting in closed-loop bowel obstruction. The affected bowel can become ischaemic due to a compromised blood supply, rapidly leading to bowel necrosis and perforation.
  • Most volvuli occur at the sigmoid colon, while the caecum is the second most common site. It is a common cause of large bowel obstruction in many countries (after malignancy and diverticular disease). They can also occur in the stomach, small intestine and transverse colon but are much rarer.
  • It is a rotation of the bowel on its axis.

  • Malrotation can be asymptomatic or may be manifested as chronic, vague abdominal pain, with or without intermittent bilious emesis, and failure to thrive.
  • The acute onset of bilious vomiting in a neonate is considered a sign of malrotation. It demands immediate radiologic evaluation.
  • Clinical features include abdominal distension, pain, tenderness-like feeling over the abdomen and vomiting followed by perforation/gangrene.

 

Upper Gastrointestinal Contrast Study

  • Malrotation is diagnosed by an abnormal position of the ligament of Treitz. The normal location is typical to the left of the vertebral column and posterior to the stomach.

 

Management:

Sigmoid Volvulus:

  • Gangrenous sigmoid volvulus is best managed with Hartmann’s procedure. Non-gangrenous sigmoid volvulus is best managed with resection and anastomosis unless there are risk factors for anastomotic leakage, in which case the surgeon should consider mesosigmoidopexy with a non-absorbable suture.
  • All patients admitted with suspected sigmoid volvulus should be managed initially as per any patient with bowel obstruction. In particular, they should be examined for any signs of ischaemia and given fluid resuscitation.
  • Conservative management: Most patients with sigmoid volvulus are treated conservatively initially with decompression by sigmoidoscope and insertion of a flatus tube. In sigmoidoscope decompression, the patient is placed in the left lateral position and a lubricated sigmoidoscope is gently guided into the rectum. It is manoeuvred to locate the twisted bowel and once the sigmoidoscope is in the correct position, there will be a rush of air and liquid faeces as the obstruction is relieved. A flatus tube is often left in situ for a period (up to 24 hours) after initial decompression to allow for the continued passage of contents and aid recovery of the affected area. In 25-50% of patients, this approach is unsuccessful and a formal decompression with a flexible sigmoidoscope is required.
  • Surgical management:  The indications for surgery (which is usually a laparotomy for a Hartmann’s procedure) are:

           1. Colonic ischaemia or perforation

           2. Repeated failed attempts at decompression

           3. Necrotic bowel noted at endoscopy

  • The decision on which operation to perform will depend on the patient’s nutritional status, adequacy of blood supply, haemodynamic stability, and the presence of any perforation or peritonitis. Patients with recurrent volvulus who are otherwise healthy may choose to have an elective procedure (most common sigmoidectomy with primary anastomosis) to prevent further recurrence.

​​​​​​​

Caecal volvulus:

  • With cecal volvulus, vascular compromise is more common in cecal volvulus compared to sigmoid volvulus. The plain x-rays are usually adequate for diagnosis. The options for treatment include endoscopic decompression, caecopexy or a right hemicolectomy

Option B: Ladd's band is divided near the medial aspect of the duodenum

  • Ladd's band is divided near the lateral aspect of the duodenum. Therefore, it is an incorrect option.

Option C: Cholecystectomy

  • Appendectomy can also be done during the procedure, not cholecystectomy.

Option D: Part of the jejunum is resected and anastomosis is performed

  • Part of the jejunum should not be resected and anastomosed during the procedure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the surgical outpatient department due to pain in her left breast that has persisted for 1 week. It is associated with fever and chills. She delivered a healthy baby boy via simple vaginal delivery (SVD) 3 weeks ago and is currently breastfeeding the baby. Physical examination reveals engorgement and tenderness with mild fluctuance in the left breast. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for managing this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Incision and drainage

  • This lactating female patient presenting with fever, breast pain, and localized fluctuation has likely developed a breast abscess.
  • A breast abscess is a common complication of lactational mastitis if left untreated.
  • Lactational mastitis is commonly seen in first-time mothers mostly because of a faulty technique of breastfeeding leading to nipple injury, providing a route for penetration of Staphylococcus aureus from the overlying skin.
  • Staphylococcus aureus initially causes mastitis presenting with erythema and pain of the affected breast without fever or fluctuance.
  • Mastitis caused by Staphylococcus aureus may often progress to a breast abscess, as seen in this patient
  • Breast abscess presents with:
    • Pain, erythema, and tenderness over the affected breast
    • Fever with chills and rigors
    • Breast is engorged with the presence of localized fluctuance
  • Diagnosis is based on clinical examination and breast ultrasound.
  • Treatment of breast abscess includes:
    • Incision and drainage + antibiotics
    • 1st line antibiotic for breast abscess is cloxacillin/dicloxacillin for 10 -14 days

Option A: Stop Lactation

  • Lactation is generally continued during the treatment of lactational mastitis or breast abscess and is safe for the infant.
  • Discontinuing lactation can further exacerbate breast engorgement and the resulting pain and tenderness.

Option B: Analgesics and continued breastfeeding

  • Although breastfeeding is continued, analgesia alone is insufficient to treat lactational mastitis or breast abscess.
  • The definitive management of breast abscess includes incision and drainage followed by antibiotics.

Option C: Antipyretics

  • Antipyretics are given for fever to patients with breast abscesses.
  • It is not the definitive treatment for breast abscesses as it does not treat the cause.
  • However, they should be given in combination with antibiotics.
  • Incision and drainage are required to remove the infected fluid from the breast.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents with complaints of severe pain and bony spicule discharge from the right lower limb. On examination, multiple sinus tracts and tissue necrosis is found over the underlying bone. Which of the following organism is the most probable cause of this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Staphylococcus aureus

This patient with severe pain, bony spicule discharge, multiple sinus tracts, and tissue necrosis involving the right lower limb most likely has chronic Osteomyelitis.

  • Classification of Osteomyelitis:
  • Acute (<2 weeks): Hematogenous (Most common), Pyogenic
  • Subacute (2-3 weeks) : Non-pyogenic
  • Chronic (> 3 weeks) : Direct

Causative organisms:

The following myriad of incriminating organisms is responsible for its causation:

"S" series organisms ("S" denotes severe Osteomyelitis, and those organisms causing it to start with the letter "S")

S series: S aureus, Salmonella

  • Several bones involved
  • Symmetrical involvement of bones
  • Severe Osteomyelitis
  • Spine may be involved
  • Sickle cell anemia present
  • A stool culture may be positive.

P-series organisms (their mode of entry is through punctured wounds)

  • Pseudomonas
  • Pneumococcus.
  • C-series (C denotes compound fractures)
  • Clostridium welchii
  • Coliforms (E. coli).

T-series

  • Treponema pallidum (syphilitic Osteomyelitis)
  • Tubercle bacillus (Mycobacterium).
  • Fungal Osteomyelitis (ABC)
  • Actinomycosis
  • Blastomycosis
  • Cryptococcosis and coccidioidomycosis

 Staphylococcus aureus

  • Staphylococcus aureus (60-85%): This is the most common organism causing acute Osteomyelitis.

Option A: Haemophilus influenzae

  • Haemophilus influenzae (7 months to 4 years): This is known to cause Osteomyelitis in the age group of 7 months to 4 years.

Option B: Brucella bacillus

  • Brucella bacillus can rarely cause Osteomyelitis.

Option C: Streptococcus hemolyticus

  • 8-10% of infection is caused by S.hemolyticus but is rare.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with the complaint of leg swelling for the past few weeks. He denies any trauma. He also states that the swelling is painful and is slowly enlarging. On examination, swelling at the upper end of the tibia is noted. The margins of the swelling are irregular, and it is warm to the touch. The imaging shows the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Osteogenic sarcoma

This boy with irregular leg swelling, which is warm to the touch along with the characteristic radiologic findings, most likely has osteogenic sarcoma.

The clinical presentation in question can occur both in Ewing’s sarcoma and osteosarcoma.

However, swelling is around the knee joint at the upper end of the tibia, which favors the diagnosis of osteosarcoma (metaphyseal lesion).

  • Definition: malignant, osteoid, and bone-forming tumor arising from mesenchymal stem cells (osteoblasts) located in the periosteum
  • Etiology:
  • Primary osteosarcoma: unknown
  • Secondary osteosarcoma: Paget disease of bone, radiation injury, bone infarction Increased incidence in individuals with retinoblastoma and Li-Fraumeni syndrome
  • Incidence: bimodal distribution:
  • Primary osteosarcoma: in puberty/adolescence (peak incidence age 10-30 years)
  • Secondary osteosarcoma: advanced age.
  • Clinical features:
  • Frequently first manifests with pain (progressive, worsens at night and with activity)
  • Progressive swelling (tissue mass that is tender to palpation and accompanied by erythema)
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Limping, decreased range of motion
  • Possible B symptoms.
  • Radiology:
  • Sunburst appearance of lytic bone lesions and/or Codman triangles
  • Signs of osteolysis adjacent to osteosclerosis (moth-eaten appearance)
  • Treatment:
  • Neo-adjuvant Chemotherapy followed by Surgery with a 3 cm margin followed by Adjuvant Chemotherapy

Option A: Giant cell tumor

  • Giant cell tumor site- Epiphysis (lower end femur).
  • X-ray: multicystic osteolytic lesions (soap-bubble appearance)
  • Usually occurs between 20-40 years of age

Option B: Ewing's sarcoma

  • Ewing’s sarcoma usually occurs in the diaphysis of the bone (middle of the shaft).
  • Origin: Marrow cells (marrow biopsy useful to see the extent of the disease)
  • Localizes in the diaphysis
  • Age: second decade> First decade
  • Pain: universal complaint
  • Present like osteomyelitis

Option D: Secondary metastasis

  • Secondary metastasis occurs in old age usually.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic for the evaluation of his deformities. The mother explains that at the time of birth, his weight was more than normal, and she had delivery complications during that time which she did not remember. A diagnosis of Erb's paralysis is made after a thorough evaluation. Which of the following is likely to be present in this patient?


	Loss of abduction of the arm
	Loss of lateral rotation of the arm
	Loss of sensation in the medial two fingers
	Loss of extension of the elbow
questions.solution:
Options A:  1 and 2

  •  Erb's palsy, in which there is a loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid
  • Loss of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm, and Loss of flexion (not extension) and supination of the forearm.
  • It is caused by injury to C5, C6, and rarely C7. It is seen most commonly in babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery.
  • Also known as Policeman/Waiter/Porter’s tip hand
  • Arm: adducted and medially rotated
  • Forearm: extended and pronated
  • The arm hangs limply by the side
  • Lost movements—All movements opposite to the deformity
  • Actions that would be lost:
    • Loss of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
    • Loss of flexion and supination of the forearm.

Option B: 3 and 4

Option C: All except 4

Option D: All are correct

questions.text: A 55-year-old man was driving the car when his car hit the truck in front of the vehicle due to high speed. He had not fastened the seat belt and sustained the dashboard injury. Which of the following is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior hip dislocation

  • Dashboard Injury is the most common cause (almost 80%), which results in the posterior dislocation of the femur head.
  • The patient usually presents with a shortened, internally rotated, adducted limb in slight flexion.
  • It is related to a fracture of the femoral head or acetabulum.
  • The sciatic nerve lies behind the posterior wall of the acetabulum- may be damaged in a posterior dislocation of the hip resulting in foot drop and related symptoms.
  • The force is transmitted up the femoral shaft, not to the greater trochanter.
  • Other injuries associated with dashboard injury are patellar bone fracture and posterior cruciate ligament rupture.

Option A: Anterior cruciate ligament tear

  • It is usually injured when force is applied on the lateral aspect of the knees with the foot planted.

Option B:  Tibial bone fracture

  • The tibial bone is spared in the dashboard injury because the energy is transferred to the femoral shaft leading to femur bone fracture.

Option D: Anterior hip dislocation

  • It is usually caused by forceful abduction with external rotation of the thigh.

questions.text: Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) is a lifesaving procedure that artificially maintains circulation and ventilation until the cardiac function is hopefully restored. Immediate initiation of high-quality chest compressions is the most important factor for survival after cardiac arrest. Which of the following is the acceptable compression rate during CPR?
questions.solution:
Option A: 100/min

  • Chest compression:
    • Key targets for high-quality chest compressions
    • Compression rate: 100–120 per minute
    • Compression depth for adults: 5–6 cm (2–2.5 inches)
    • Allow full chest recoil between compressions.
  • Provider positioning and technique (adults and children; excluding infants)
    • Kneel or stand next to the patient, depending on whether they are on the ground or in a bed.
    • Centre the hands (one on top of the other, fingers interlaced) over the sternum.
    • Keep the arms straight (do not bend the elbows); the shoulders should be directly above the hands.
    • Use full body weight to deliver rapid, firm compressions.
  • Patient positioning:
    • Supine on a firm surface
  • Minimizing interruptions
    • Restart CPR between rhythm analysis and shock delivery (while the defibrillator is charging).
    • Resume CPR immediately after shock delivery.

Option B: 500/min

  • Excessive compressions per minute should be avoided
  • Compression rate: 100–120 per minute

Option C: 20/min

  • The recommended chest compressions are 100-200 per minute

Option D: 50/min

  • The recommended compression during CPR is 100-200 per minute

questions.text: A 24-year-old boy presents to the surgical outdoor patient department with a complaint of swelling on his forehead, which is about 2x5 cm in size. On examination, it was a sebaceous cyst. The patient wants to remove that for which he was admitted, and the patient is told that it will be removed under local anesthesia. Alkalization of local anesthetic solutions by the addition of sodium bicarbonate has the following benefits:

choices.text: Diminish the depth of the blockade
Decreases the availability of lipid-soluble forms of local anesthetic

questions.solution:
Option A: Speeds the onset

  • The pH of a commercial preparation of local anaesthetic ranges from 3.9 to 6.5.
  • The pKa of local anaesthetics used clinically is near eight, so only a tiny fraction of local anaesthetics exist in the lipid-soluble form.
  • Alkalization increases the percentage of local anaesthetic existing in the lipid-soluble form(uncharged) that is available to diffuse across the lipid-soluble barriers (Nerve sheath).
  • Adding sodium bicarbonate will speed the onset of peripheral nerve and epidural block by 3 to 5 minutes.

Option B: Diminish the depth of the blockade

  • It enhances the depth of sensory and motor blockades.
  • It increases the spread of epidural blockade.

Option C: Decreases systemic toxicity

  • Local anaesthetics are generally safe when limited to the site of therapy.
  • If local anaesthetic reaches the systemic circulation, it causes toxicity.

Option D: Decreases the availability of the lipid-soluble form of local anaesthetic.

  • It increases the availability of lipid-soluble forms of local anaesthetic.
  • Alkalization increases the percentage of local anaesthetic existing in the lipid-soluble form(uncharged) that is available to diffuse across the lipid-soluble barriers (Nerve sheath).

questions.text: The clinical professor of anaesthesia is delivering a lecture on the importance of drug doses in the field of anaesthesia. The effective dose is the potency of the neuromuscular blocking drug required to produce an effect. The clinically relevant dose of neuromuscular blocker required for clinically useful relaxation corresponds to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: ED95

  • The effect of neuromuscular blocking drugs is measured as the depression of adductor pollicis muscle contraction (twitch) following electrical stimulation of the ulnar nerve. The value is compared with a control value obtained before the injection of the drug.
  • According to Miller, the potency of a neuromuscular blocking drug is best described as the effective dose – "The dose of a neuromuscular blocking drug required to produce an effect (e.g., 50%, 90%, or 95% depression of twitch height, commonly expressed as ED50, ED90, and ED95, respectively“.
  • Thus, the ED95 is the amount of neuromuscular blocking drug required to reduce twitch height by 95%, i.e. clinically useful relaxation. The intubating dose is twice the dose of ED95.

Option A: ED50

  • ED50 is the amount of neuromuscular blocking drug required to reduce twitch height by 50%
  • This amount of relaxation is clinically not useful.

Option B: ED75

  • ED75 is the amount of neuromuscular blocking drug required to reduce twitch height by 75%
  • This amount of relaxation is clinically not useful.

Option D: ED25

  • ED25 is the amount of neuromuscular blocking drug required to reduce twitch height by 25%
  • This amount of relaxation is clinically not useful.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male has been admitted to the emergency department with a complaint of abdominal pain and distension for the past 2 hours. He also complains of low-grade fever and weight loss for the past 4 weeks. A diagnosis of intestinal obstruction is made secondary to tuberculosis. The patient is taken to the operating theatre for the laparotomy under general anaesthesia. Which of the following component is least likely essential to provide optimal surgical conditions?
questions.solution:
Option D: Stable hemodynamic status

  • Stable hemodynamic status is not an essential component of the anaesthesia.
  • General anaesthesia:
    • General anaesthesia (GA) is appropriate for most major surgical procedures.
    • A reversible state of Stage III surgical anaesthesia is established, including the following goals: Hypnosis/unconsciousness, Amnesia, and Analgesia.
    • Muscle relaxation or immobility as appropriate for the procedure
    • Autonomic and sensory blockade of responses to noxious surgical stimulation
    • GA has three distinct phases: induction, maintenance, and emergence
  • Stages of anesthetic depth

Stage I

Analgesia state: Patient is conscious and rational, with decreased perception of pain

Stage II

Delirium stage: Patient is unconscious; body responds reflexively; irregular breathing pattern with breath holding.

Stage III

Surgical anesthesia: Increasing degree of muscle relaxation; unable to protect airway.

Stage IV

Medullary depression: There is depression of cardiovascular and respiratory centers

Option A: Analgesia

  • Analgesia is one of the components of anaesthesia.
  • This stage can be initiated in a preoperative anesthesiology holding area, where the patient is given medication and may begin to feel its effects but has not yet become unconscious.
  • This stage is usually described as the "induction stage." Patients are sedated but conversational. Breathing is slow and regular.
  • At this stage, the patient progresses from analgesia free of amnesia to analgesia with concurrent amnesia.
  • This stage comes to an end with the loss of consciousness.

Option B: Muscle relaxation

  • Muscle relaxation is an important component of anaesthesia.
  • This is achieved by administering muscle relaxants.
  • This aids in intubation.

Option C: Amnesia

  • Amnesia is achieved during anaesthesia.
  • Anaesthesia causes unconsciousness by suppressing neural mechanisms mediating arousal and awareness.
  • It also causes amnesia by disrupting mechanisms of memory consolidation.
  • Some patients under general anaesthesia unexpectedly become aware during surgery and form traumatic memories of their experience.

questions.text: A 22-year-old boxer was brought to the Emergency department by an ambulance. He had a boxing match prior to his arrival. The attending physician did a thorough physical checkup and suspected an orbital floor fracture. He immediately ordered an X-ray of the orbital floor. What is the most appropriate view of X-ray for this patient?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Water’s view

  • An angled posteroanterior radiograph of the skull with the patient looking slightly upwards is known as the occipitomental (OM) or Waters view.

  • In addition to acute sinusitis, it can be used to check for facial fractures.

  • It is the view of choice for visualizing fractures of the orbital floor.

Option B: Caldwell’s view


  • Caldwell's view is a caudally angled radiograph, and its posteroanterior projection exposes the orbits to the least amount of radiation possible.

  • The paranasal sinuses, particularly the frontal sinus, are easier to visualize at this angle.

  • Assessing four inflammatory disorders, including sinusitis, secondary osteomyelitis, and sinus polyps or cysts might be helpful.

  • This view also enables the identification of superior orbital fissure fractures.

Option C: Rhese view

  • The optic canal can be visualized by using the Rhese view of the X-ray.

  • In this view, the patient is positioned with the orbit to be studied such that the cassette should be touched by the zygoma, nose, and chin.

Option D: Towne view

  • The Towne view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull that shows the posterior clinoid processes, the dorsum sellae, and the petrous section of the pyramids, which are all visible in the foramen magnum's shadow.

  • This projection is utilized to assess for Paget disease, neoplastic alterations, and medial and lateral displacements of skull fractures.

  • The inferior orbital fissure of the orbit can also be visualized via this view.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presents to the emergency ward complaining of vomiting and epigastric pain radiating to the back for 2 days. He has a history of atopic dermatitis and Hashimoto thyroiditis. His only medication is levothyroxine. He drinks 1–2 beers on the weekends and occasionally smokes marijuana. The patient appears distressed and is diaphoretic. The patient is vitally stable. Physical examination shows abdominal distention with tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. There is no guarding or rebound tenderness. Skin examination shows several clusters of yellow plaques over the trunk and extensor surfaces of the extremities. The CT abdomen of the patient is done, and the structure involved in the patient's pathology is marked with an arrow in the image. Which of the following structure is involved in the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pancreas

  • This is a case of acute pancreatitis in which the patient presents with complaints of vomiting and epigastric pain that radiates to the back for 2 days.

  • In this case, on abdominal examination, the abdomen is distended, and there is tenderness on palpation in the epigastric region.

  • The structure marked with an arrow in this image is the pancreas, which is the structure involved in acute pancreatitis.

  • Acute pancreatitis is the inflammation of the pancreas. It occurs suddenly and can last for weeks to months.

Option A: Spleen

  • The structure marked with an arrow in the CT scan is the pancreas, not the spleen.

Option B: Renal artery

  • The renal artery transport oxygenated blood to the kidney; it is not marked in the image of the CT abdomen given above in this case.

Option C: Bowel loop

  • Small and large intestines loops are called bowel loops; they are not marked in the CT scan in this case.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male, is brought to the neurologist by his wife with complaints of fever, head and neck stiffness, and altered state of consciousness for two weeks. The wife further gives the history that the patient also had two episodes of fits in the last week. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations show no abnormalities. The patient is posted for LP to confirm the diagnosis. But before that CT is advised. In which of the following case, CT should be performed ahead of Lumbar puncture?
questions.solution:
Option B: Immunocompromised state

  • This is a case of meningitis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, headache, neck stiffness, fits and an altered state of consciousness.

  • The lumbar puncture is performed to confirm the diagnosis of meningitis.

  • This investigation also confirms the microorganisms involved in meningitis for its proper treatment and cure.

  • Neuroimaging is done before lumbar puncture in patients at increased risk of potentially fatal cerebellar or tentorial herniation following lumbar puncture.

  • It is not indicated in hypertension or diabetes mellitus.

  • It is also not indicated in alert patients and is orientated to time and space.

  • Neuroimaging should be done before LP in the following patients:

    • Altered level of consciousness

    • Focal neurological deficit

    • New onset seizure

    • Papilledema

    • Immunocompromised state

Option A: Hypertension

  • Hypertension without any stroke doesn't require CT brain before lumbar puncture.

Option C: Diabetes mellitus

  • Some patients with diabetes mellitus are immunocompromised. So just being diabetic is not a clear indication of CT brain before LP. So, in this case, choosing an immunocompromised patient is a better option.

Option D: Normal GCS

  • If the patient has normal GCS and is not immunocompromised, then CT brain is not indicated.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female presents to her family physician complaining of a burning sensation during urination and pain in flank. On physical examination, she has slight fever. She reported that this pain started about a week ago. After evaluation, her doctor suspected the presence of a kidney stone and advised her to do a CT scan to confirm the diagnosis and location of the stone. The doctor also decided it was equally important to detect the chemical composition of the kidney stone. Which of the following investigation should be done in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dual-source CT

  • This is a case of nephrolithiasis in which the patient presents with complaints of a burning sensation during urination.

  • Nephrolithiasis is one of the most common renal diseases in adults.

  • Most renal calculi are made of calcium, ammonium magnesium, uric acid, and cystine.

  • The calcium oxalate stone is the most common type in the kidney, followed by calcium phosphate stones.

  • Dual-source CT uses two different x-ray sources with different Kvp and, based on the interaction with different elements, can characterize the type of kidney stones

  • Clinical dual-energy applications include

    • Characterization of abdominal masses,

    • Chemical composition of renal calculi,

    • Myocardial and pulmonary perfusion imaging.

Option A: Spiral CT

  • Spinal CT is done during arterial portography for preoperative detection and localization of focal liver lesions, renal cell carcinoma staging, or pancreatic disease imaging.

Option B: Multidetector CT

  • Multidetector CT is an accurate and noninvasive method for diagnosing any kind of tracheal pathology.

Option D: HRCT

  • It is usually done in cases of pulmonary tuberculosis and interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with PCOS undergoing fertility treatment with clomiphene citrate and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) injections complained of severe abdominal distension, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty breathing. On examination, she had moderate ascites, tachycardia, and hypotension. What is the likely cause of her current symptoms?

choices.text: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a potential complication.
The symptoms are likely related to ectopic pregnancy.
The patient is at high risk for ovarian torsion.
The findings are consistent with a normal response to fertility treatments.

questions.solution:
Option A: Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome

  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) is a medical complication unique to stimulatory infertility treatment; very rarely, it may present spontaneously.
  • Presents with the symptoms of fluid leakage in the body, such as abdominal distension, pain, nausea, vomiting, increased thirst, and bloating. Severe cases may present with pulmonary oedema, coagulopathy, and acute kidney failure.
  • In the above case scenario, there is a history of infertility and the use of clomiphene with gonadotrophin therapy with multiple follicular development.
  • OHSS may present in pregnancy and can occur with a more severe form in pregnancy, so a positive urine pregnancy test should not create confusion in the diagnosis of OHSS.
  • Early OHSS occurs 3-7 days following the HCG trigger and is associated with the administration of exogenous HCG.
  • The late-onset disease occurs 12-17 days after the HCG trigger. It results from endogenous HCG secretion during the pregnancy and tends to be more severe with multiple gestation.
  • Management is by monitoring the input and output of fluids. And also by intravascular fluid intake to replenish the volume and symptomatic treatment, like the tapping of the ascites and pleural effusion
  • It is normally a self-limiting condition.
  • Management of severe cases of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is done by admitting the patient for monitoring and following strict protocols to prevent secondary life-threatening complications.

Option B: Ruptured ovarian cyst

  • A ruptured ovarian cyst presents with acute abdominal pain and tenderness with abdominal distension; however, here, it is unlikely as there is no history of a pre-existing cyst. Also, the mention of a history of ovulation induction and trigger for follicular rupture makes OHSS more likely.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy requiring β-HCG follow-up

  • Ectopic pregnancy presents with a history of amenorrhea associated with abdominal pain and spotting PV. It is, therefore, an important differential here. However, she has presented on the day of her missed period, and the USG suggests ascites. Thus, the background of the history of infertility treatment makes OHSS more likely here.​​​​​​​

Option D: Ectopic pregnancy requiring immediate surgery

  • Ectopic pregnancy requiring laparotomy implies a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, which presents with acute abdomen with pelvic tenderness on examination, and USG should reveal an adnexal mass, which is not the case here. A laparotomy would have been indicated if the patient was hemodynamically unstable or if USG suggested hemoperitoneum with the same clinical picture.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fertility. She has been unable to conceive for 2 years despite regular intercourse with her husband twice weekly. Menarche occurs at the age of 12 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 to 5 days. She is undergoing evaluation for infertility. She is being monitored for ovulation with serial ultrasounds and LH levels. Ovulation in this patient is expected to occur how many hours after an LH surge is demonstrated?
questions.solution:
Option C : 36 hours

  • The patient in the question has regular cycles, thus are expected to be ovulatory
  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.
  • The midcycle LH surge is responsible for a dramatic increase in the follicle's local concentrations of prostaglandins and proteolytic enzymes. These substances progressively weaken the follicular wall and ultimately allow a perforation to form.

Option A : 12 hours

  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.

Option B : 24 hours

  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.

Option D : 48 hours

  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman has come to OPD with complaints of hot flashes, irritability, joint pains, and lack of sleep. The most appropriate treatment would be:
questions.solution:
Option C : The symptoms that the patient is suffering from are post menopausal symptoms due to deficiency of estrogens. Therefore the alleviation of these shall require hormone replacement therapy. Estrogen is the mainstay of hormone replacement therapy, however it is given along with progesterones to counter its adverse effects on endometrium (hyperplasia and cancer) in non-hysterectomised women.

Symptoms of post menopausal syndrome

  • Vasomotor symptoms : Typically a Hot flushes, occurrence of which coincides with LH rise, there is consequent increase in NA, serotonin, dopaminergic pathways which cause vasodilatation in brain a flash of heat occurs from brain to neck to back. Around 75% menopausal women get hot flushes. This may be seen for up to 1-2 years in most women but can go upto 10 years. The most important pathogenesis is not just estrogen deficiency but "estrogen withdrawal".
  • Mood swings, depression, anxiety, insomnia, decreased anger threshold.
  • Osteoporosis and increased risk of fractures : due to more osteoclastic activity, less osteoblastic activity in the absence of estrogen
  • Vulvovaginal atrophy : vulval and vaginal dryness, increased chances of vaginitis, urethritis
  • Increased risk of coronary artery disease : as estrogen is cardioprotective, however this is NOT an indication for HRT.

Indications of hormone replacement therapy in a menopausal woman

  • Relief of vasomotor symptoms: hot flushes
  • Prevention and treatment of osteoporosis
  • Urogenital atrophy
  • Depression, insomnia
  • Premature Menopause

Drugs used for HRT

  • Estradiol
  • Conjugated equine Estrogen
  • Tibolone
  • Synthetic Estrogen
  • combined estrogen + progesterones
  • SERM(Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator)
    • Raloxifene
      • Estrogenic on bone
      • C/I for Hot flushes
  • Plant Estrogen
  • Bisphosphonates: only for osteoporosis, not for vasomotor symptoms
    • Alendronate
    • Risendronate

Option A : Hysterectomy has no role in management of menopausal symptoms

Option B : Calcium and vitamins only help to some extent, in osteoporosis symptoms, but have no role in vasomotor symptoms and other menopausal symptoms of estrogen deficiency.

Option D : Bisphosphonates are used for osteoporosis only, and not for vasomotor symptoms and other menopausal symptoms of estrogen deficiency. Even in osteoporosis in menopausal women, drug of choice is estrogen.

questions.text: In a 43-year-old woman with heavy and frequent menstrual bleeding, an endometrial biopsy reveals endometrial hyperplasia. Among the among the given histological patterns which one poses the highest risk for developing endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option D: Complex hyperplasia with atypia

  • The risk of endometrial cancer is highest in a case of complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia.
  • The most common risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia is increased circulating estrogen, which is unopposed by progesterone. E.g., obesity, nulliparity, late menopause, exogenous estrogen such as tamoxifen, etc.
  • There is Complex endometrial hyperplasia which has marked glandular complexities and back-to-back overcrowded glands, and simple endometrial hyperplasia, which has a proliferation of endometrial glands more than normal but lacks glandular complexities and back-to-back overcrowded glands
  • The incidence of occurrence of endometrial cancer in the case of endometrial hyperplasia is as follows
Simple hyperplasia with out Atypia is 1%
Complex hyperplasia with out Atypia 3%
Simple hyperplasia with Atypia 8%
Complex hyperplasia with Atypia 29%

Option A: Simple hyperplasia without atypia

  • Simple Endometrial Hyperplasia without atypical cells 1% risk of Ca endometrium

Option B: Simple hyperplasia with atypia

  • Simple Endometrial Hyperplasia with atypical cells has an 8% risk of developing cancer.

Option C: Complex hyperplasia without atypia

  • Complex Endometrial Hyperplasia without atypical cells has a 3% risk of developing cancer.

questions.text: A15-years-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea with an orderly appearance of secondary sexual characteristics like breast and pubic hair. On examination, there is no other abnormality detected, and the patient denied the use of any medication or illicit drugs. On family history, no significant history was established to diagnose the cause. What is the next best step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option : Reassure: This is the correct answer. In many cases, primary amenorrhea in adolescent girls can be a normal variation of puberty. It's not uncommon for girls to have their first menstrual period (menarche) as late as age 16 or even later. If the girl has normal secondary sexual characteristics (such as breast development and pubic hair growth), it indicates that she is going through puberty, and the absence of menstruation may be a temporary delay. In such cases, reassurance and monitoring are often recommended.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: USG: Ultrasonography is a valuable tool for assessing the reproductive organs, but it is typically not the first step in the evaluation of primary amenorrhea in adolescents with normal secondary sexual characteristics. It may be considered if there are specific concerns or findings that warrant further investigation.

Option C: HSG: Hysterosalpingography is a procedure used to evaluate the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. It is typically not indicated as the initial step in evaluating primary amenorrhea without additional specific findings or concerns.

Option D: Hormonal study: Hormonal studies, including measuring hormone levels such as FSH, LH, estradiol, and thyroid function tests, may be considered if the girl's clinical presentation raises concerns about hormonal imbalances. However, these tests are often reserved for cases where there are specific indications, such as delayed puberty or abnormal physical findings.

questions.text: A 40-years-old woman presented to the gynaecologist with complaints of profuse vaginal discharge. The diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis was based upon the microscopic findings, except which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Abundance of polymorphs

Bacterial vaginosis:

  • Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an abnormal symbiotic relationship leading to abnormal vaginal flora. As a result, there is an overgrowth of anaerobes such as Gardnerella vaginalis and other organisms (Ureaplasma urealyticum, Mycoplasma hominis, and Mobiluncus species).
  • The normal pH of the vagina is 3.8 to 4.5. The pH in Bacterial vaginosis is alkaline, and hence there is a lesser estrogenic environment and consequently lesser lactobacilli.
  • It is diagnosed based on the following findings:
  1. A fishy vaginal odour
  2. Vaginal secretions are grey and thinly coat the vaginal walls.
  3. pH higher than 4.5 (usually 4.7 to 5.7).
  4. An increased number of clue cells and leukocytes are conspicuously absent.
  • Adding KOH to the vaginal secretions (the "whiff" test) releases an amine-like odour.
  • Alternative diagnostic tests include a pH and amines test card, G. vaginalis ribosomal RNA detection, or Gram stain.

Option A: Abundance of gram variable coccobacilli

  • Gardnerella vaginalis is a gram variable coccobacillus, facultative anaerobic bacteria.

Option B: Absence of Lactobacilli

  • The Gardnerella vaginalis is caused due to an abnormal vaginal flora leading to overgrowth of anaerobes in the absence of Doderlein's lactobacilli.

Option D: Presence of clue cells

  • The Clue cells are the epithelial cell having a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. The image above shows a clue cell.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female accompanied by her husband presents to Gynaecology OPD for contraceptive counselling. She has been married for 6 years, and her last childbirth was 1 year ago. She has 4 live children with one abortion. Also, she was concerned about limiting her family from having no contraindications for oral contraceptive pills. It has been explained that the failure rate of contraceptive pills is less than 1 per Hundred Woman Years. How can the failure rate be calculated?

choices.text: Total accidental pregnancies × 1200 / number of women observed x Total months of contraceptive use.
Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies.
Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies.
Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy.

questions.solution:
Option A : The use-effectiveness of contraceptive method is expressed as Pearl rate . Pearl rate or pearl index was introduced by Raymond Pearl in 1932 The rate is expressed as pregnancy rate per 100 women years (HWY) & calculated as

Pregnancy rate per HWY = Total accidental pregnancies × 1200/ Number of women observed x Total months of use of contraceptive

(1200 is the number of months in 100 years).

Another technique is the life-table method. It calculates the probability of pregnancy in successive months, which are then added over in a given interval.

Option B, C, D : These are all incorrect formulas.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complained of urine leakage for the last 5 months. She has been married for 8 years and is multiparous with 6 children. She is a known case of diabetes mellitus type-2. She is overweight and does not exercise regularly. Other than genuine stress urinary incontinence, the most common cause of urinary leakage is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Urge incontinence

  • Urinary incontinence is of two main types:
    • Stress incontinence
    • Urge incontinence
  • Stress and urge urinary incontinence occur in isolation or as mixed urinary incontinence. Stress incontinence is an involuntary loss of urine when intravesical pressure exceeds the maximum urethral pressure with an increase in the abdominal pressure, i.e., coughing or sneezing.
  • Although stress incontinence is the most common type of urinary continence in all women, urge incontinence is the more common in older women.
  • Urge urinary incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine accompanied by or immediately preceded by urgency. This is a symptom-based diagnosis, which cause may or may not be detrusor overactivity based on the urodynamic observation.
  • Anticholinergic agents and tolterodine (Detrol) are used for treating urge incontinence. 
  • However, more effective behavioural therapies should be the first-line treatment for urge incontinence.

Option A: Detrusor dyssynergia

  • Detrusor dyssynergia is a urodynamic term for several lower urinary tract symptoms due to detrusor muscle contraction with inappropriate involuntary urethral sphincter contraction. It can be a cause of urge incontinence.

Option C: Vesico vaginal fistula

  • The vesicovaginal fistula is an abnormal opening between the bladder and the wall of the vagina, resulting in urine leakage out of the vagina. 
  • It is not a common form of incontinence as it is always associated with some trauma due to surgery, childbirth or rarely after radiation

Option D: Overflow incontinence

  • Overflow incontinence occurs when urine is dribbled as the bladder is too full. There could be various causes, such as blockages of the urethra due to tumours, urinary stones, scar tissue or swelling from infection.
  • It is less common than stress incontinence and urge incontinence.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl with irregular menstrual bleeding for 3 months. Menarche at 13 years old. Cycle length varies between 35 to 45 days. Bleeding lasts for 7 to 12 days and sometimes involves heavy bleeding. Negative pregnancy test. Multiple normal ultrasounds and normal coagulation profile. Which of the following is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: Bleeding is likely to be associated with a missed pelvic pathology and an MRI should be advised
Bleeding is most likely due to estrogen breakthrough
Cycle length increases due to a longer secretory phase

questions.solution:
Option B: Bleeding is most likely due to estrogen breakthrough

  • The patient appears to have anovulatory bleeding, which is more common at the start and end of the reproductive age group, post-menarchal and premenopausal age groups.

Anovulation:

  • Absence of ovulation due to immature HPO axis (hypothalamic pituitary ovarian axis).
  • Bleeding is a type of estrogen breakthrough instead of progesterone withdrawal.
  • The absence of ovulation leads to a lack of progesterone.
  • Endometrium keeps building up in response to estrogen and finally due to ischemia, it breaks down resulting in irregular prolonged bleeding.
  • Causes of anovulation include eating disorders, stress, excessive exercise, endocrine disorders like thyroid and diabetes and PCOD.
  • The length of the luteal phase is always fixed at 14 days. The prolonged cycle length is due to a longer follicular phase, as ovulation is delayed or absent.
  • Hormonal therapy with combined or progesterone-only therapy is the first line of management.

 

Option A: Bleeding is likely associated with a missed pelvic pathology, and an MRI should be advised.

  • MRI is not required here as the most likely cause here is an immature HPO axis leading to anovulation, which will not be picked up on MRI. Multiple USG scan have already ruled out any major pelvic pathology.

 

Option C: Oral contraceptives provide no benefit

  • Oral contraceptive pills given in cyclical fashion, will regularize the patient's cycle.

 

Option D: Cycle length increases due to a longer secretory phase

  • The length of luteal phase is always fixed at 14 days, the prolonged cycle length is due to a longer follicular phase as ovulation is delayed or absent.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to Gynaecology OPD for a regular check-up. On an ultrasound, she is incidentally found to have an anterior wall cervical fibroid. She is otherwise asymptomatic. She is advised to regular follow-ups. Which of the following could be the most common complaint she is most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Option B: Urinary Frequency

  • Anterior wall cervical fibroid can cause bladder or bladder neck compression, causing urinary symptoms like urinary frequency or retention.
  • Cervical Fibroid is
    • Rare ( 1- 2 % ) in the supramarginal part of the cervix.
    • It may be interstitial or subperitoneal variety and rarely polypoidal.
    • Depending upon the position, it may be anterior, posterior, lateral or central interstitial growths.
  • Anterior wall uterine fibroid is shown below:

  • The above diagram is showing the anterior wall fibroid is compressing the bladder.
  • This compression causes urinary frequency.
  • Management
    • Vaginal polypectomy or myomectomy
    • Myomectomy
    • Lap myomectomy
    • MRI-guided Myolysis
    • Vaginal hysterectomy
    • Total abdominal hysterectomy
  • Please note that although posterior cervical fibroids are associated more commonly with urine retention than anterior cervical fibroids, anterior fibroids can be associated with urgency, frequency and retention due to their position. Urinary symptoms in anterior cervical fibroids are their most common presentation.

Option A: Abdominal lump

  • A cervical fibroid usually does not present as an abdominal lump as the cervix is placed deep in the pelvis, unless it is very large.

Option C: Per vaginal bleeding

  • Bleeding is more commonly associated with uterine fibroids than cervical fibroids

Option D: Constipation

  • Constipation occurs more commonly in posterior wall fibroids.

questions.text: Four women were admitted to the labor room for delivery with histories as below. The senior doctor on her rounds instructs her residents to keep uterotonic drugs ready and keep blood arranged for all of the following except?

choices.text: 36-year-old G2P1L1 with previous preterm delivery, now at 39 weeks
G3P2L2 with previous normal deliveries with a current EFW (Estimated fetal weight) of 4.2 kg
Primigravida with twin pregnancy via IVF.

questions.solution:
Option A: 36-year-old G2P1L1 with previous preterm delivery, now at 39 weeks

Uterine atony:

  • Atonicity of the uterus causes about 80% of PPH. Other causes can be traumatic PPH (injury to genital tract) or coagulopathies

The causes of atonicity can be :

  1. Large uterus- macrosomia, twins, polyhydramnios
  2. Infections- PROM, Chorio amnionitis
  3. Prolonged Labour
  4. Among the given options, advanced age and previous history of preterm labour are not risk factors for PPH.
  5. While macrosomia, twin pregnancy and polyhydramnios are all factors causing uterine overdistension and are thus at increased risk of atonic PPH.

Option B: G3P2L2 with previous normal deliveries with current EFW (Estimated fetal weight) of 4.2 kg

  • The weight of the baby indicates macrosomia.
  • Macrosomia is a risk factor for uterine atony.
  • Oxytocin should be arranged for such patients.

Option C: Primigravida with IVF conception with twin pregnancy

  • A twin pregnancy is a risk factor for uterine atony.

Option D: Primigravida with AFI of 28 cms

  • With AFI more than 25, it likely indicates polyhydramnios.
  • Polyhydramnios carries a risk of Uterine atony.

questions.text: An Rh negative woman with a positive ICT presents for ultrasound evaluation. It reveals a hydropic fetus with placentomegaly. The size of placenta required for such diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Option D: 40 mm

Normal placenta Placentomegaly
  • Size - 22 cm in diameter
  • Thickness - 2.0 to 2.5 cm
  • Weight - 470 g.
  • Thickness > 40 mm.
  • Weight - >750 g.

Placentomegaly is associated with:

  1. Fetal hydrops
  2. Maternal diabetes
  3. Chronic infections (e.g. syphilis, cytomegalovirus),
  4. Maternal anaemia

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic for the evaluation of her pregnancy. She currently has no complaints but is concerned about the Rh-incompatibilty after reading from the internet. She is Rh- negative. She inquires about the anti-D injection. Prophylactic anti-D injection in non-immunized Rh-negative women should be given at what timings during the antenatal and postnatal period?

choices.text: 28 weeks, 32 weeks, within 72 hours after delivery
28 weeks, 36 weeks, within 72 hours after delivery
28 weeks, and within 24 hours after delivery
28 weeks and then within 72 hours after delivery

questions.solution:
Option D: 28 weeks and then within 72 hours after delivery

 

American college recommendations:

  • Anti-D immune globulin is given prophylactically to all D-negative, un-sensitized women at approximately 28 weeks gestation, and a second dose is given after delivery if the newborn is D-positive
  • Before the 28-week dose of anti-D immune globulin, repeat antibody screening is recommended to identify individuals who have become alloimmunized
  • Following delivery, anti-D immune globulin should be given within 72 hours.

 

British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH) Guidelines:

  • All D-negative pregnant women who have not been previously sensitized should be offered routine antenatal prophylaxis with anti-D Ig (RAADP) either with a single dose regimen at around 28 weeks or a two-dose regimen given at 28 and 34 weeks.

 

Option A: 28 weeks, 36 weeks, within 72 hours after delivery

  • The anti-D is indicated in the 28th week and immediately after the delivery, preferably within 72 hours.

 

Option B: 28 weeks, 36 weeks, within 72 hours after delivery

  • At the 36th week, no anti-D is recommended.

 

Option C: 28 weeks, and within 24 hours after delivery

  • Anti-D can be given within 72 hours after the delivery, not within 24 hours.

questions.text: Hypertension, proteinuria, and pitting edema are noted in the second month of the first pregnancy in a 25-year-old woman. The pathogenesis of her presenting complains is most closely associated with:-
questions.solution:
Option A : Features of pre-eclampsia (hypertension, proteinuria, pitting edema) in the first trimester is most often secondary to a hydatidiform mole, which is a benign neoplasm of the chorionic villi.

Features of complete mole

  • Features of excessive HCG
    • Thyrotoxicosis
    • Hyperemesis
  • Passage of grape like vesicles (Rare)
  • Bleeding PV (MC Presentation)
  • Uterine size > POG
  • Patient may present with Trophoblastic Embolization (respiratory distress)
  • Patient may have Theca Lutein cysts (due to high HCG, resolve by themselves after evacuation)
  • Early onset HTN (d/t abnormal Trophoblastic proliferation)

Choriocarcinomas are malignant trophoblastic tumors that most commonly develop from a preexisting complete mole, in 50% of cases although they can also be seen following a Normal pregnancy and abortion in 25% cases each.

Option B : Gestational diabetes is not associated with early onset hypertension.

Option C : Endometrial cancer is not associated with early onset hypertension.

Option D : Choriocarcinomas are malignant trophoblastic tumors that most commonly develop from a preexisting complete mole, in 50% of cases although they can also be seen following a Normal pregnancy and abortion in 25% cases each. This may lead to hypertension and proteinuria but choriocarcinoma follows pregnancy but here the patient is pregnant hence molar pregnancy is more likely.

questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic primigravida, at 36 weeks of gestation, comes to the obstetric department for a routine antenatal check-up. She is completely well, and her pregnancy was uneventful except for a history of fewer fetal activities 2 days ago. Her diabetes is well-controlled, and she takes the multivitamins, iron, and calcium pills as prescribed. Upon physical examination, her vitals were normal, and the physician ordered an NST (Non-Stress test) to assess fetal well-being. The patient may be sent back home and asked to return after 1 week if the NST shows any of the following findings:

choices.text: At least two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with a baseline variability of 5-25 bpm
One fetal heart rate acceleration is noted in 20 mins with a baseline variability of 5- 25 bpm
Two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm
Three fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 30 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm

questions.solution:
Option A: At least two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with baseline variability of 5-25 bpm

  • The Non-Stress test is primarily a test of sympathetic and parasympathetic fetal well-being.
  • In normal conditions, fetal heart rate raises at least 15 beats whenever it moves.
  • If the baby shows two accelerations in heart rate lasting at least 15 seconds during the 20-minute test, it is read as normal or reactive.
  • A reactive non-stress test (NST) is a reassuring sign of fetal well-being.
  • If the heart rate does not accelerate with movement or another 20 minutes of observation fails to meet the criteria, the NST is considered non-reactive.

Criteria for reactive NST:

  • Baseline fetal heart rate: 110-160 bpm.
  • Baseline variability: 5-25 bpm.
  • Accelerations ≥ 2, in 20 mins.
  • No decelerations.

Option B: One fetal heart rate acceleration is noted in 20 mins with baseline variability of 5- 25 bpm

  • It is not a criterion for reactive NST; Therefore, it is non-reactive.

Option C: Two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm

  • It does not meet the criteria for reactive NST, so it is non-reactive.

Option D: Three fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 30 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm

  • It will be considered a non-reactive NST as it does not meet the criteria for a reactive test.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman, G2P0A1, is at 30 weeks gestation. Her fundal height measures 25cm. An obstetrical ultrasound examination reveals a 4 quadrant amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4cm. Which of the following fetal conditions is associated with the finding?
questions.solution:
Option D : AFI <4 cm is suggestive of Oligohydramnios

  • The only option of the provided that leads to oligohydramnios is Renal agenesis.

Oligohydramnios can be caused by -

  1. Renal anomalies
  2. Uteroplacental insufficiency: IUGR
  3. ACE inhibitors
  4. Premature rupture of membranes
  5. Amniocentesis (leak)
  6. Pre-eclampsia
  7. Amnion nodosum
  8. NSAIDs
  9. Post term pregnancy
  10. over estimated gestational age

Option A, B, C : Duodenal atresia, open spina bifida, tracheo-esophageal fistula are all causes of polyhydramnios as they are all associated with open meninges or mucosal surfaces which exude fluid and cause polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks of pregnancy presents with abdominal pain and bleeding per vaginum. BP is 118/74 mm Hg & On speculum examination, bleeding is observed from the cervical os. Abdominal examination reveals the uterus to be 10 weeks in size, and upon vaginal examination, the uterus is found to be soft with an open os measuring 1.5 cm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C : The history of abdominal pain and bleeding per vaginum in a pregnant female is suggestive of Abortion

O/E - size of Uterus = POG = 10weeks and Os is open.

All these points indicate towards Inevitable abortion

Management involves either waiting for spontaneous expulsion or hastening the process by uterotonics.

Option A, B, D :

  presentation P/V examination USG
Threatened abortion pain, bleeding os closed normal intrauterine pregnancy
Inevitable abortion pain, bleeding os open intrauterine pregnancy with dilated cervix
Incomplete abortion pain, bleeding, passage of mass os open/ closed retained products of conception
Complete abortion passage of mass os closed empty uterus
Missed abortion no complaints os closed absent cardiac activity

questions.text: A 37-year-old multipara construction laborer presents to the emergency department with fatigue and generalized body weakness. Upon enquiringabout her nutritional status, she revealed that she has not eaten well well-balanced diet lately. Her blood picture shows hypochromic microcytosis. This is most likely indicative of which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option D: Combined iron and folic acid deficiency

  • There is a presence of Iron deficiency anaemia in almost 70-75% of Indian women, but usually in malnourished women, along with iron, there is a deficiency of essential vitamins and proteins as well.
  • The commonest anaemia thus seen in our women is Dimorphic anaemia rather than isolated iron deficiency anaemia.
  • In dimorphic anaemia, along with iron, there is a deficiency of folic acid as well. Iron is crucial to the structure of haemoglobin in RBCs. It is needed to transport oxygen to the tissues for their oxygenation.
