  • Folic acid is crucial for RBC formation and healthy cell growth. The deficiency of folic acid in pregnancy can result in birth defects.
  • The deficiency of iron can result in microcytic RBCs with low haemoglobin, and that of folic acid can result in the improper shape of RBCs, making them macrocytic.
  • Here anisocytosis means a combination of microcytes and macrocytes. Microcytes are seen in iron deficiency, and macrocytes are seen in folic acid and B12 deficiency, hence a dimorphic picture.

Option A: Iron deficiency

  • Only iron deficiency leads to microcytic anaemia.

Option B: Folic acid deficiency

  • Folic acid deficiency leads to macrocytic RBCs.
  • There is no anisocytosis.

Option C: Physiological anemia

  • Physiological anemia is due to hemodilution and shows a normocytic normochromic picture

questions.text: Which of the following is not an absolute risk factor for ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option B : Ectopic pregnancy results from various factors that interrupt the successful migration of the conceptus to the endometrium.

The most important risk factors for ectopic pregnancy are

  • History of tubal surgery, including tubal ligation, for prior ectopic pregnancy, infertility
  • History of prior ectopic: increases risk 5 folds
  • In utero diethylstilbestrol (DES) exposure: causes congenital fallopian tube anomalies
  • History of pelvic inflammatory disease, sexually transmitted disease
  • Peritubal adhesions: secondary to salpingitis, endometriosis, appendicitis
  • SIN: salpingitis isthmica nodosa
  • Infertility: use of ART: increases risk of atypical/ non tubal ectopic
  • Failed contraception: IUCD, sterilisation, progesterone only contraceptives. PLEASE NOTE IT IS FAILURE OF THESE CONTRACEPTIVE PRACTICES, AND NOT THE CONTRACEPTIVE PRACTICE IN ITSELF

 

Intrauterine device (IUD) use are associated with reduce pregnancies and reduced ectopic rates, however, if there is a failure of the IUD and a pregnancy results, ectopic gestation is more likely as compared to normal population conceiving These are not very clear relations. Many other risk factors, including smoking and multiple lifetime sexual partners, are weakly associated with ectopic pregnancy .

Option A, C , D : All the given options are risk factors for ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old P2L2 woman with previous 2 vaginal deliveries presents for a routine pap smear. She complains of occasional mucoid vaginal discharge and no other significant complaints. On per speculum examination, the cervical os is expected to appear:
questions.solution:
Option B : Transverse

  • Before childbirth, the external cervical os is a small, regular, oval opening.
  • After childbirth, the orifice is converted into a transverse slit that is divided such that there are the so-called anterior and posterior lips of the cervix.
  • The cervical os is small and round, typical for a nulliparous woman.
  • The os will have a fish-mouth shape after one or more pregnancies.

Option A: Regular, oval

  1. A regular oval cervical os is seen prior to childbirth.

Option C: longitudinal

  • Cervical os is not longitudinal.

Option D: Irregular, pinpoint

  •  An irregular cervix may be abnormal and may require evaluation by colposcopy. Pinpoint os is usually not seen in parous women.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with short stature and some abnormalities of the hand and pelvis. His hands are like a trident, and his pelvis is no more than champagne glass pelvis. On examination, his vision is normal, and there is no history of bleeding diathesis. He has not been taking any medicine for any disease. Based on laboratory investigation, his serum cortisol and calcium levels are in the normal range. His father is 50 years old, his mother is 35, and both have proportionate short stature. The physician suspects a genetic disorder. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Achondroplasia

  • The patient with achondroplasia presents with three characteristic features:
  • Short limb
  • Trident hand
  • Champagne glass pelvis

  •  

Option A: Osteogenesis imperfecta

  • Osteogenesis imperfect is a genetic disorder characterized by soft bones that fracture easily.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is one of the causes of disproportionate short stature, where the limbs are mainly involved, as compared to the trunk.
  • Most commonly caused by mutation of the COL1A1 and COL1A2 genes.
  • There are 12 types of osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • Both types I and IV are further divided into A and B subtypes depending on the absence (A) or presence (B) of dentigerous imperfecta.
  • M/C mode of inheritance in osteogenesis imperfecta-TYPE I to IV is autosomal dominant.
  • It is also known as brittle bone disease.
  • The characteristics of this disease include:
    • Blue sclera
    • Premature deafness
    • Bony deformities
    • Short limb dwarfism
    • Connective tissue disorder

Option B: Rickets

  • It is softening and weakening of bones in children due to prolonged and extreme vitamin D deficiency.
  • It usually occurs at the age of 6-24 months.
  • Its characteristics include:
    • Frontal bossing
    • Rachitic rosary
    • Harrison sulcus
    • Potbelly
    • Wrist widening
    • Short limb dwarfism

Option C: Cushing syndrome

  • It occurs due to the overproduction of the cortisol hormone.
  • The characteristics of this disease include:
    • Proportionate short stature
    • Central obesity, diabetes
    • Moon-like facies
    • Striae
    • Hypertension,
    • Delayed puberty
    • Hirsutism
    • Muscle weakness

questions.text: At what age will  a child achieve the milestone shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Option C: 15 months

  • This is a case of a well-child examination in which a 12-month-old child is brought to the physician by his mother for examination.

  • The child is able to crawl easily and is also able to walk with support.

  • He is also able to copy horizontal and vertical lines. The child doesn’t have any abnormalities.

  • He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.

  • The given picture shows a child creeping upstairs, that comes at around 15 months of age.

  • So, the child, in this case, still has 3 more months to achieve the milestone shown in the image.

  • Another important milestone that appears at around 15 months of age is Jargon speech.

Option A: 6 months

  • At the age of 6 months, the baby starts to roll from tummy to back.

  • Also, pushes up with straight arms when on the tummy

  • Leans on their hands to support him while sitting.

Option B:  12 months

  • At the age of 12 months, the baby can walk, holding onto objects.

  • Walks like a bear.

  • Picks up a pellet with finger and thumb

Option D: 24 months

  • At the age of 24 months, the child is able to make a tower of 6 cubes, turn the doorknob, and use pronouns like I, me, and you.

  • A child can make a tower of 6 cubes in 2 years.

  • Baby can hold a pencil in mid-shaft with a tripod grasp.

  •  Can sit on a small chair.

questions.text: A pre-term baby, born at 30 weeks of gestation, has been admitted to the nursery. On examination, he has a low body weight, chest pain due to respiratory distress syndrome, and a distended abdomen with absent bowel sounds. He is being nursed in an incubator. The consultant has advised keeping the environmental temperature in a range at which the baby's basal metabolic rate (BMR) is at a minimum, oxygen consumption is at least, and the baby maintains its normal body temperature. What is this environment called?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thermoneutral environment

  • The baby is pre-term with full-blown complications like respiratory distress syndrome and necrotising enterocolitis. He is being managed and nursed in the incubator.
  • Incubators provide a controlled and enclosed warm environment which enables the baby to be nursed effectively.
  • Frequent access to the baby is required, and the baby is nursed uncovered, so thermoregulation is challenging and one of the most important concerns in this case.
  • A thermoneutral environment should be provided to the baby to minimise oxygen demand and energy expenditure. This is a stable metabolic state where there is no net loss.
  • It can also be provided by blocking the heat loss and applying adequate warmer in the incubator.

 

Option B: Normothermic environment

  • A temperature that does not cause increased or decreased function of body cells and is suitable for normal routine functioning is called normothermic.

Option C: Catabolic Environment

  • An environment which causes the breaking down of more mass, both fat and muscle, as compared to normal is termed catabolic.
  • For example, stress burns and in the postoperative state.

Option D: Anabolic environment

  • An environment encompasses anabolic processes like protein synthesis, glucose breakdown, hormonal balance and muscle growth.
  • Bodybuilders maintain an anabolic inner state.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus delivers a term baby weighing 3980 grams. She has used her insulin regularly throughout the pregnancy. The image of the physical examination of the newborn is shown. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in further investigations of this baby?

choices.text: Increased risk of congenital heart diseases

questions.solution:
Option A: Increased risk of congenital heart diseases

  • Hairy pinna (excess hair on ear pinna) points to the diagnosis of an infant of a diabetic mother.
  • Infants of diabetic mothers (IDM) have a higher incidence of congenital malformations, estimated to be between 2.5 and 12%, with an excess of cardiac genetic problems.
  • The group whose moms were using insulin at the time of conception has the highest prevalence of abnormalities
  • Problems in an infant of a diabetic mother:
    • Macrosomia- Difficult/ prolonged labour, ↑ chances of birth trauma.
    • Metabolic- Hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, polycythemia, hyperbilirubinemia.
    • Congenital heart defects- VSD, TGA.
    • CNS- neural tube defects, caudal regression syndrome.

Option B: Anaemia

  • Infants of diabetic mothers had polycythemia, not anaemia (venous hematocrit greater than or equal to 65%), with a rate of 29.4%, compared to 5.9% control subjects (P less than 03).
  • Infants of diabetes moms had considerably higher mean nucleated red blood cell counts than controls.

 

Option C: Hypercalcemia

  • Hypercalcemia is irrelevant to the infant of a diabetic mother.
  • The maximum tolerated total serum calcium in term newborns during the first three months of life is 11.3 mg/dL. More than 5.4 mg/dL of ionised calcium is the diagnostic threshold for hypercalcemia.

 

Option D: Hyperglycemia

  • An IDM is more likely to experience episodes of low blood sugar (Hypoglycemia) in the hours and days following birth.
  • This results in the baby becoming accustomed to receiving more sugar from the mother than is necessary.
  • They have more insulin in their system than is required after birth. Insulin reduces blood sugar levels

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-year-old boy to the primary care provider complaining that the child has become irritable, looks dull and weak, and has also lost weight. On examination, edema is absent, his appetite is good, and there is no liver enlargement, but his skin and hair are thin. He also has bradycardia and hypothermia. His mid-upper arm circumference is low, and his body mass index is low. The socio-economic status of the family is also poor. What is the child probably suffering from?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute malnutrition

  • In this clinical setting, the patient has a history of irritability, weight loss, and decreased mid-upper arm circumference and body mass index. All the mentioned examination findings are also suggestive of Marasmus, a subtype of acute malnutrition.
  • In acute malnutrition, children appear wasted. There is a decrease in mid-upper arm circumference, weight-for-length or body mass index.
  • Subtypes include malnutrition with oedema, i.e., Kwashiorkor and malnutrition without oedema, i.e., Marasmus.
  • In acute malnutrition, cardiac output and stroke volume are reduced in proportion to the loss of lean body mass, and hepatic gluconeogenesis is reduced, resulting in hypoglycemia, glomerular filtration is reduced, and marked pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.
  • Their immune system is also dysfunctional, and their basal metabolic rate decreases by approximately 30%.

Option B: Chronic malnutrition

  • A decrease in height for age (stunting) indicates chronic malnutrition.
  • Other features include reduced physical activity, apathy and retarded psychomotor development.

Option C: Both acute and chronic malnutrition

  • If stunting is accompanied by features of acute malnutrition, such as poor weight gain and deficits in lean body mass and adipose tissue, the presentation can be categorized as both acute and chronic.

Option D: Dehydration

  • There is no previous history of diarrhoea or poor fluid intake, so dehydration is unlikely.
  • Depending upon the history and examination findings, it is further categorized as some or severe dehydration.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with type-1 diabetes and congenital right renal agenesis comes to the ER with palpitations and chest pain. Despite OTC meds, the pain persists, preceded by muscle weakness and cramps for two days. An ECG shows signs of hyperkalemia, leading to cardiac arrest. After resuscitation, he was admitted for hyperkalemia management. Nursing is instructed to monitor potassium and ECGs daily. Potassium levels over four days are 9.1, 7.7, 6.6, and 5.5 mmol/L. What ECG changes should be expected on these days?

choices.text: Prolonged PR interval → Peaked T waves → Sine wave pattern → Absent P waves
Sine wave pattern → Absent P waves → Prolonged PR interval → Peaked T waves
Absent P waves → Prolonged PR interval → Sine wave pattern → Peaked T waves
Peaked T waves → Prolonged PR interval → Absent P waves → Sine wave pattern

questions.solution:
Option B: Sine wave pattern → Absent P waves → Prolonged PR interval → Peaked T waves

  • ECG changes are of great significance for the early identification of specific electrolyte imbalances. Measurement of serum electrolytes is an ideal but time taking procedure for the identification of these imbalances.
    • The commonly described ECG changes in the settings of hyperkalemia are tall-tented T waves, but as the serum potassium levels rise, ECG changes vary progressively, as described below.

Potassium level (mmol/L)

Mechanism

ECG changes

5.5-6.5

Repolarisation abnormalities

Peaked T waves

6.5-7.0

Progressive atrial paralysis

P wave widening/flattening

PR prolongation

P wave eventually disappear

7.0-9.0

Conduction abnormalities

Bradyarrhythmias: Sinus bradycardia; high-grade AV block with slow junctional and ventricular escape rhythms; slow AF Conduction blocks (bundle branch block, fascicular blocks) Prolonged QRS interval with bizarre QRS morphology

>9.0

All of above

Development of sine wave appearance (pre-terminal rhythm)

Asystole

Ventricular fibrillation

PEA with bizarre, wide complex rhythm

 

Option A:  Prolonged PR interval → Peaked T waves → Sine wave pattern → Absent P waves

  • It is not the correct sequence of ECG changes from days 1 to 4. ECG changes start from the sine wave pattern on day 1 and progress to peaked T waves on day 4.

Option C: Absent P waves → Prolonged PR interval → Sine wave pattern → Peaked T waves

  • It is not the correct sequence of ECG changes from days 1 to 4. ECG changes start from the sine wave pattern on day 1 and progress to peaked T waves on day 4.

Option D: Peaked T waves → Prolonged PR interval → Absent P waves → Sine wave pattern

  • It is the reverse of the sequence of ECG changes from days 1 to 4 and stands true in the settings of progressively rising serum potassium levels

questions.text: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother due to diarrhea and irritability for several weeks. The mother tells the pediatrician that the child develops these symptoms only after drinking milk and eating a meal with yogurt. Which of the following is not a feature of this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Alkaline urine

  • The scenario mentioned above is the case of lactose intolerance.

  • Lactose intolerance is a clinical disease characterised by distinct signs and symptoms after taking lactose, a disaccharide.
  • Clinical signs result from lactase deficiency caused by main or secondary sources.
  • Dairy, milk products, and mammalian milk all include lactose.
  • The symptoms of lactose intolerance include bloating and soreness in the abdomen, loose and explosive stools, nausea, gas, and borborygmi.
  • In primary lactase insufficiency, biopsy shows normal-appearing mucosa.
  • Medical evaluation includes history taking, examination, and laboratory investigation such as hydrogen breath test, stool acidity test, lactose intolerance test and small bowel biopsy.
  • Dietary changes, lactase supplementation, and the treatment of underlying conditions are the mainstays of lactose intolerance management for those with secondary lactase insufficiency.
  • The disease does not usually affect the kidneys to produce alkaline urine.

Option A: Reducing substances present in stools

  • A positive test result indicates reducing sugars in the faeces that the body has not absorbed. The presence of diseases with carbohydrate malabsorption, like lactase insufficiency, is suggested by a high amount of reducing material in the stool.

Option C: Acidic stool

  • A stool acidity test in one investigation was used to evaluate patients with lactose intolerance.

  • Lactose that is not absorbed is converted into lactic acid by colonic bacteria, lowering the stool's pH.

Option D: Lactase enzyme deficiency

  • The most frequent cause of lactase deficiency, also known as lactase non-persistence, is primary lactase insufficiency.

  • With advancing age, lactase enzyme activity gradually decreases.
  • Infancy marks the beginning of the loss in enzyme function, while adolescence or early adulthood marks the onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A neonate presented with generalised cicatrizing skin lesions all over the body and hypoplasia of all limbs. An MRI of the brain revealed diffuse cerebral atrophy. An ophthalmologic evaluation reveals chorioretinitis. Which of these tests is most likely to show a positive result in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Anti Varicella Zoster virus antibody

  • Cicatrizing skin lesions, hypoplasia of all limbs, and chorioretinitis are all features of Congenital Varicella Syndrome.
  • Therefore, Anti VZV antibody would be positive in this baby.

Option A: Anti-cytomegalovirus antibody

  • Cytomegalovirus infection is associated with intrauterine growth retardation, microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, prolonged neonatal jaundice, and generalized blue–purple macules at birth.
  • It is not associated with hypoplasia of limbs.
  • Therefore, anti-CMV is unlikely to be positive.

Option B: Anti-toxoplasma antibody

  • Congenital toxoplasmosis is associated with hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and diffuse cerebral calcifications.
  • It is not associated with diffuse cerebral atrophy.

Option D: Anti-rubella antibody

  • Rubella is associated with cataracts, deafness (Sensorineural hearing loss), congenital heart disease (Patent ductus arteriosus)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of ringing and pulsating sensation in his left ear. The patient also has a history of progressive hearing loss for 1 year. Endoscopic examination reveals a normal tympanic membrane. Further examination reveals conductive hearing loss. Which of the following is correct about the muscle involved in patient's pathology?

choices.text: Tensor tympani is derived from 1st branchial arch
Stapedius muscle is derived from 1st branchial arch
The facial nerve supplies the tensor tympani muscle
The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies stapedius muscle

questions.solution:
Option A: Tensor tympani is derived from 1st branchial arch

  • It is a case of tensor tympani syndrome, caused by a conductive defect resulting from a structural abnormality of the middle ear muscles.
  • Tensor tympani muscle:
    • A skeletal muscle that attaches to the malleus.
    • Origin: Cartilaginous and bony margins of the eustachian tube.
    • Insertion: Handle the malleus.
    • Action: Contraction of the muscle pulls the malleus medially. This action tenses the tympanic membrane and damps vibration in the ear ossicles, reducing the perceived amplitude of the sound.
    • Innervation: Medial pterygoid nerve, a branch from the mandibular nerve (V3).
  • Stapedius muscle:
    • The smallest skeletal muscle in the human body; attaches to the stapes.
    • Origin: Pyramidal eminence (hollow protrusion from the posterior wall of the tympanic membrane).
    • Insertion: Neck of the stapes.
    • Action: Contraction of the muscle pulls the neck of the stapes laterally, thereby dampening the vibrations of the stapes and allowing it to control the amplitude of sound waves transmitted to the inner ear.
    • Innervation: The nerve to the stapedius, a branch from the facial nerve.

Option B: Stapedius muscle is derived from 1st branchial arch

  • Stapedius muscle is derived from 2nd branchial arch.
  • The smallest skeletal muscle in the human body; attaches to the stapes.
  • Origin: Pyramidal eminence (hollow protrusion from the posterior wall of the tympanic membrane).

Option C: The facial nerve supplies the tensor tympani muscle

  • The 5th cranial nerve supplies the tensor tympani. It is innervated by the medial pterygoid nerve, a branch from the mandibular nerve (V3). So, it is a false statement.

Option D: The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies stapedius muscle

  • The tensor tympani is innervated by a branch of the fifth cranial nerve, whereas the stapedius is innervated by a branch of the 7th cranial nerve. So, it is a false statement.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient ward with complaints of hearing loss, facial weakness, reduced facial sensations, fever, headache, and double vision for 2 weeks. The patient has diabetes mellitus and uses insulin. On physical examination, the patient is hypertensive. A suspected diagnosis of Gradenigo’s syndrome was made. Which of the following cranial nerve is involved in the discussed case:
questions.solution:
Option B: 6thCN

  • The person presented with the suspected diagnosis of Gradenigo’s syndrome.
  • It is the classical presentation of petrositis.
  • It consists of a triad of
    • Lateral rectus palsy (VIth nerve palsy in Dorello’s canal).
    • Deep-seated ear or retro-orbital pain (Vth nerve involvement).
    • Persistent ear discharge.
  • The spread of infection from the middle ear and mastoid to the petrous part of the temporal bone is called petrositis.
  • It may be associated with acute coalescent mastoiditis, latent mastoiditis, or chronic middle ear infections.
  • Persistent ear discharge with or without deep-seated pain despite an adequate cortical or modified radical mastoidectomy also points to petrositis.
  • Fever, headache, vomiting, and sometimes neck rigidity may also be associated.
  • Some patients may get facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo due to the involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves.
  • Diagnosis of petrous apicitis requires both a CT scan and MRI.
  • CT scan of temporal bone will show bony details of the petrous apex and the air cells, while MRI helps to differentiate diploic marrow-containing apex from the fluid or pus.

Option A: 4th

  • This is a wrong option as it says the involvement of the 4th crania nerve (trochlear nerve), which is not involved in Gradenigo’s syndrome.
  • In trochlear nerve palsy, there is no hearing loss or facial weakness.
  • Only eye symptoms are present such as double vision.

Option C: 8th

  • This option is also wrong because the 8th nerve (vestibulocochlear nerve) is not involved in Gradenigo’s syndrome.
  • Vestibulocochlear nerve is involved in sound transmission and equilibrium information between the inner ear and brain.

Option D: 11th

  • This option is also wrong because it says the 11th nerve, also known as the accessory nerve, supplies the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • Accessory nerve is not involved in Gradenigo’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to the ENT department with complaints of recurrent bony fractures and reduced hearing for one year. The patient is vitally stable. On further investigation, tympanometry showed the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Van der Hoeve syndrome

  • This is a case of van der Hoeve syndrome.
  • Van der Hoeve syndrome is the all-around variant of Lobstein's disease (late osteogenesis imperfecta) and is characterized by the simultaneous presence of osteoporosis, blue sclerae, and deafness.
  • The histological findings in the stapes of a patient suffering from this disease demonstrated that the actual stapes were abnormal, its crura being fragile and incomplete. In contrast, the footplate and its surroundings were expected compared to the observations in otosclerosis.

Type Implications
Type A Normal tympanogram/sensorineural hearing loss where conductive mechanism is normal.
Type B Flat curve, no change in compliance with pressure changes. Seen in fluid in the middle ear.
Type C Maximum compliance in negative pressure. Seen in eustachian tube obstruction.
Type As Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure. Seen in otosclerosis or malleus fixation.
Type Ad High compliance at or near ambient pressure. Seen in ossicular discontinuity.

Treatment:

  • Treatment of this disease consists of I.V. clodronate disodium at a dose of 300 mg daily in 250 ml saline solution for seven consecutive days.

Option A: Wardenburg syndrome

  • Wardenburg syndrome is characterized by the following:
    • Autosomal Dominant.
    • White forelock, heterochromia iridis, and depigmentation of the skin.
    • Dystopia Cantorum.
    • SNHL (unilateral or bilateral).

Option C: Usher’s syndrome

  • Usher's syndrome is characterized by the following:
    • Retinitis pigmentosa.
    • Night blindness.
    • SNHL.
    • Delayed onset.

Option D: Pendred syndrome

  • Pendred syndrome is characterized by the following:
    • The perchlorate discharge test shows a defect in the organic binding of iodine. Goitre (nontoxic) is usually evident before puberty.
    • SNHL.
    • Congenital onset.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the ENT outpatient department with a whistling sound while breathing for the past 3 months. He reports that a large crust develops over his septum. Due to irritation, he tried to peel it off, leading to nose bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • The clinical findings of this patient most likely suggest septal perforation.

Clinical Features

  • Small anterior perforations cause a whistling sound during inspiration or expiration. Larger perforations develop crusts that obstruct the nose or cause severe epistaxis when removed.

Etiology of Septal Perforation

  • Traumatic perforations: Trauma is the most common cause. Injury to mucosal flaps during submucosal resection (SMR), cauterization of the septum with chemicals or galvanocautery for epistaxis, and habitual nose picking are common forms of trauma. Occasionally, the septum is deliberately perforated to put ornaments.
  • Septal abscess.
  • Nasal myiasis.
  • Rhinolith or neglected foreign body causing pressure necrosis.
  • Chronic granulomatous conditions like lupus, tuberculosis, and leprosy cause perforation in the cartilaginous part, while syphilis involves the bony part. Wegener's granuloma can cause total septal destruction.
  • Drugs: Prolonged use of steroid sprays in nasal allergy, cocaine addicts, workers in certain occupations, e.g., chromium plating, dichromate or soda ash (sodium carbonate) manufacture, or those exposed to arsenic or its compounds.
  • Idiopathic: In many cases, there is no history of trauma or previous disease, and the patient may even be unaware of the existence of a perforation.

Option A: SMR

  • Injury to mucosal flaps can lead to SMR, but option D is the best choice because it encompasses all the other reasons also, which are aetiologies of nasal septal perforation, making option A the incorrect choice as compared to Option D.

Option B: Cocaine

  • Cocaine is one of the etiologies leading to nasal septal perforation. Option D mentions all the other etiologies, making it the best choice in this question. Hence this is the wrong choice.

Option C: Tuberculosis

  • Tuberculosis is one of the etiologies leading to nasal septal perforation. Option D mentions all the other etiologies, making it the best choice in this question. Hence this is the wrong choice.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents to the physician's office with a complaint of hoarseness of voice and neck swelling for the past few months. He mentions that the neck swelling increases on playing an instrument. Which of the following statement is incorrect ?

1) Gradual onset of stridor

2) Neck swelling that is soft and compressible

3) On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound

4) Seen in professional trumpet players, glass blowers
questions.solution:
The correct diagnosis is laryngocele.

Option D: Gradual onset of stridor

Laryngocele:

  • It is an air-filled cavity that forms as dilation of the laryngeal saccule and extends between the thyroid cartilage and the ventricle.
  • The patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible, hoarseness of voice, and Sudden onset of stridor occurs due to compression of glottic airway space by the internal laryngocele.
  • It arises from raised transglottic pressure, as seen in professional trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight-lifters.
  • Swelling in the neck reduces pressure and increases on Valsalva maneuver.
  • If large, it leads to airway obstruction, compression of the pharynx leading to dysphagia, with bad breath.
  • Bryce sign: On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound.
  • Surgical treatment is advised only if the patient is symptomatic or if the laryngocoele is infected. Surgery aims at excising the saccule, thereby reducing the recurrence rate.

Option A: All are incorrect

  • The laryngocele neck swelling is soft and compressible; it is seen in trumpet players and glass blowers, and on compressing the swelling, there appears to be a gurgling/hissing sound.
  • There is a sudden onset of stridor when the neck swelling causes airway obstruction.

Option B: Only 1, 2, and 3 are incorrect

  • The laryngocele neck swellings are soft and compressible; they are seen in trumpet players and glass blowers, and on compressing the swelling, there appears to be a gurgling/hissing sound.

Option C: Only 1 & 2 are incorrect

  • The laryngocele neck swellings are soft and compressible; the onset of stridor is not gradual but sudden.

questions.text: A 3-year-old, well-immunized boy was brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of sore throat, high-grade fever, and noisy breathing with an inability to swallow for the past four hours. The physical examination showed a toxic, tachypnoeic child with inspiratory stridor. There is suprasternal, supraclavicular, and intercostal recession during inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acute Epiglottitis

  • It is a case of Acute epiglottitis. The child is well immunized; however, he presents with a high-grade fever, sore throat, and inability to swallow (dysphagia). The examination findings, such as inspiratory stridor and toxic look with respiratory difficulties, support the diagnosis of acute epiglottitis.
  • Epiglottitis is an acute infection of the supraglottis characterized by inflammation of the supraglottic structures.
  • Historically the most common causative organism was Haemophilus influenza type b.
  • TREATMENT:

 

  1. Systemic Antibiotics
  2. Systemic corticosteroids
  3. Nebulization with Adrenaline

Option A: Acute Laryngo-tracheobronchitis

  • It has a similar presentation, but odynophagia and dysphagia are usually absent.
  • The patient presents a croupy cough (barking seal-like cough) and hoarseness.
  • The fever is usually low-grade or absent.

Option C: Diphtheria

  • Diphtheria is ruled out as the child is well immunized, even though he has the symptoms.
  • The presence of a tough pseudomembrane over the larynx and trachea is a differentiating factor not seen in this patient.

Option D: Bronchopneumonia

  • Bronchopneumonia will not have inspiratory stridor. In addition, the patient will not show an inability to swallow and stridor due to involvement of the lower respiratory tract only.

questions.text: A 9-year-old male presents to the clinic due to a sore throat and fever for 4 days. It is associated with right earache and headache. He denies cough or nasal discharge. On physical examination, the tonsils are congested and swollen. Which of the following nerve is involved in referring the pain to the right ear?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glossopharyngeal (CN IX)

Symptoms of tonsillitis:

  • Sore throat
  • Difficulty in swallowing: The child refuses food due to pain locally.
  • Fever: Associated with rigours and chills
  • Earache: Referred pain from the tonsil. It can also be due to otitis media which results in a complication of tonsillitis.
  • Constitutional symptoms (headache, body aches, malaise, and constipation)
  • Fetid breath

  • Referred pain to the ear is from:
    • Nose and sinuses via CN V.
    • Oesophagus via CN X.
    • Cervical spine via CN II and CN III.
    • Larynx and hypopharynx via CN X.
    • Oropharynx via CN IX.
    • Tongue, temporomandibular joint, parotid gland, and teeth via CN V.

Option B: Facial (CN VII)

  • The facial nerve supplies facial expression muscles and taste sensation to the anterior 2/3 of the tongue and the stapedius muscle in the middle ear.
  • However, it does not carry the pain fibres from the tonsils to the ear.

Option C:  Trigeminal (CN V)

  • CN V refers to pain from the tongue, temporomandibular joint, parotid gland, and teeth to the ear.
  • It does not refer to pain from the tonsils to the ear.

Option D: Vagus (CN X)

  • CN X refers to pain from the larynx and the hypopharynx to the ear.
  • It does not refer to pain from the tonsils to the ear.

questions.text: A final year medical student is studying the nerve supply of the larynx before assisting a surgeon in thyroidectomy. He notes that the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent laryngeal are mainly responsible for the nerve supply of the larynx. Which of the following statements regarding the nerve supply of the larynx is not true?

choices.text: External laryngeal nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle.
Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all the muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid.
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve takes part in Galen’s anastomosis.
Internal laryngeal nerve gives sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords.

questions.solution:
Option D: Internal laryngeal nerve gives sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords.

  • The internal laryngeal nerve gives sensory supply to the larynx above the vocal cords, while the recurrent laryngeal nerve gives sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords.
  • Nerve supply of the larynx:

  • The superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerve are the vagus nerve branches.
  • The superior laryngeal nerve divides into the external and internal laryngeal nerve at the level of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone.
  • The external laryngeal nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle responsible for tensing the vocal cord.
  • The internal laryngeal nerve pierces the thyrohyoid membrane and gives sensory supply to the larynx above the vocal cord level.
  • The internal laryngeal nerve terminates by piecing the inferior constrictor muscle and joining with an ascending branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve to form an anastomosis known as Galen’s anastomosis.
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
    • Innervates all the muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid.
    • Gives sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords.
Muscles of the larynx  
  Innervation Action
Cricothyroid External laryngeal nerve Tenses vocal cords and increases the pitch of the voice.
Thyroarytenoid Inferior laryngeal nerve (the terminal part of the recurrent laryngeal nerve) Relaxes vocal cords and lowers the pitch of the voice.
Posterior cricoarytenoid Abducts the vocal cords.
Lateral cricoarytenoid Adducts the vocal cords.
Transverse and oblique arytenoids Adducts the vocal cords.
Vocalis Adjust the tension of the vocal cords during phonation.

Option A: External laryngeal nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle.

  • The external laryngeal nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle responsible for tensing the vocal cord and increasing the pitch of the voice.

Option B: Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all the muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid.

  • All the muscles which move the vocal cord are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve except the cricothyroid muscle.

Option C: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve takes part in Galen’s anastomosis.

  • The internal laryngeal nerve terminates by piecing the inferior constrictor muscle and joining with an ascending branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve to form an anastomosis known as Galen’s anastomosis.

questions.text: When light rays travel through various mediums, they undergo a physical phenomenon known as refraction. The same thing happens when light travels through the eye. Which of the following structures in the human eye has the highest refractive power?
questions.solution:
The correct option is:

  1. Cornea

Refraction is the bending of light rays as they pass from one medium to another of different optical density. In the human eye, light undergoes refraction as it passes through various structures to focus on the retina, where visual information is processed. Among the given options, the cornea has the highest refractive index.

The cornea is the transparent, dome-shaped front surface of the eye. It is the first structure that light encounters when entering the eye. The curvature and refractive index of the cornea play a significant role in focusing light onto the retina. Because the cornea is the primary refractive surface of the eye, it contributes the most to the overall refraction of light.

The other options explained:

2. Lens: The lens of the eye is located just behind the iris and is responsible for fine-tuning the focus of light onto the retina. While the lens does have a high refractive index, it is situated deeper within the eye compared to the cornea, and its primary role is to adjust the focus rather than being the initial surface where light enters.

3.Aqueous Humour: The aqueous humor is the clear fluid that fills the space between the cornea and the lens. While it does have a refractive index, it is lower than that of the cornea and the lens. Its main function is to provide nutrients to the cornea and the lens.

4.Vitreous Humour: The vitreous humor is a gel-like substance that fills the larger space within the eye, behind the lens and ciliary body. It helps maintain the shape of the eyeball. Like the aqueous humor, the vitreous humor also has a refractive index, but it is not the primary structure responsible for initial light refraction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with the complaint of blurry vision, photophobia, and watering eyes for one week. He has no history of smoking or drinking. The vitals are in the normal range. The eyes are red, and there is epiphora on physical examination. Which of the following is the best treatment for this given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Elschnig’s operation:

  • In the above-given case, the symptoms of blurry vision, photophobia and epiphora suggest the disease ectropion.
  • Paralytic ectropion usually resolves spontaneously with a resolution of the palsy that caused it.

Ectropion:

  • Outward misdirection of the lid margin.
  • Causes: Cicatricial, senile, aponeurotic.

Type of ectropion

Surgeries

Congenital ectropion

For moderate to severe cases -horizontal lid tightening

Involutional ectropion (the most common type of ectropion)
  • Medial conjunctivoplasty
  • Horizontal lid shortening
  • Byron Smith’s modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski Operation
  • Lateral tarsal strip procedure

Paralytic ectropion

Often resolves spontaneously;

For non-resolving cases-

  • Horizontal lid tightening

Cicatricial ectropion
  • V-Y operation
  • Z-plasty (Elschnig’s operation).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oral antibiotics:

  • Oral antibiotics are not useful in the treatment of ectropion.
  • Antibiotics can be used in case of bacterial infection of the eye.

Option C - Steroids:

  • Artificial tears and lubricating ointment can be used in the treatment of ectropion.
  • Steroids are not effective in ectropion.

Option D - Palpebral sling surgery:

  • The most effective and permanent treatment of ectropion is surgical.
  • Palpebral sling surgery is done for ptosis, not ectropion.

questions.text: A sixty-five-year-old presents to your clinic with the complaint of decreased vision in both eyes. The loss of vision was gradual, and he has not experienced any pain in his eyes. Examination findings reveal a bilateral cataract. Cataract surgery is scheduled. The patient is informed that the left eye will be operated on first, and the right eye will be done 1 week after that. An intraocular lens (IOL) is placed in the eye during the surgery. Which type of lens is shown below?
questions.solution:
Option D: Multifocal Posterior chamber IOL

  • Image in the question shows a multifocal posterior chamber IOL.
  • An intraocular lens (IOL) is implanted in the eye in place of the crystalline lens that gets opacified in a cataract.
  • An IOL consists of an optic and haptics.
  • Posterior chamber IOL is the most commonly used IOL after cataract surgery.
  • Multifocal IOLs may be refractive or diffractive.
  • Refractive IOLs mainly provide intermediate and distance vision.
  • Diffractive IOLs provide brilliant reading vision and a decent distant vision.
  • There are various rings in the optic zone of a multifocal IOL.
  • This allows the patient to see at various distances according to the multiple focal lengths.
  • Side effects include:
    • Unavoidable halos
    • Glare.

Option A: Crystalens

  • Crystalens is a type of accommodative IOL that is also placed in the posterior chamber.
  • Elastic haptics are present that change the position of the optic when a person tries to accommodate.
  • No rings are present in the optics, helping reduce glare and halos.

Option B: Anterior Chamber IOL

  • A Complicated surgery, with a rupture of the posterior capsule, may necessitate alternative positioning of the IOL.
  • In this scenario, anterior chamber IOLs are used.
  • In the anterior chamber, IOL the haptics supported in the angle.
  • The position of the anterior chamber requires a specific type of lens.
  • Complications include:
    • Uveitis
    • Glaucoma
    • Hyphema

Option C: ICL

  • An Implantable Collamer Lens (ICL) is a Posterior chamber phakic intraocular lens.
  • Posterior chamber phakic intraocular lenses are used as refractive surgery in patients unsuitable for corneal refractive surgery.
  • Has communication ports to allow passage of aqueous from the posterior chamber to the anterior chamber and posterior vault (the gap between ICL and the anterior surface of the crystalline lens).

questions.text: A 27-year-old male carpenter presents to the emergency department with complaints of redness in the left eye after being hit by a flying iron chip while working on an iron statue 2 hours ago. He has no history of any chronic illness. He is vitally stable. On examination, there was a puncture in the anterior capsule with focal anterior subcapsular opacity, and a temporal intraventricular metallic foreign body was found. Which of the following investigation is contraindicated in the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option D: MRI

  • This is a case of intraocular foreign body in which the patient complains of redness in the left eye after being hit by a flying iron chip while working on an iron statue 2 hours ago.

Investigation in case of intraocular foreign body (IOFB):

  • Clinical Examination
    • The most important part of the examination in a suspected case of IOFB is direct visualisation of the IOFB using a slit lamp, gonioscopy and indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Radiological examination
    • X-ray orbit - can help to confirm the presence of IOFB.
    • Details of radio-lucent IOFB may not be very clearly made out.
    • MRI Scan -MRI is contraindicated in Metallic intraocular foreign body due to its magnetic field.
  • Electrophysiology is done in patients with unexplained visual loss and trauma history.

Option A: CT scan

  • Metal locators - replaced largely due to advances in CT scans.
  • CT Scan - can help accurately localise the IOFB (radio-opaque).

Option B: ERG

  • Electroretinogram (ERG) - very sensitive in diagnosing metallosis bulbi, which may be characterised by a decrease in b wave amplitude and complete flattening of ERG in advanced cases.

Option C: B mode ultrasound

  • Ultrasound - gives a general idea of the presence and relative position of IOFB, especially in patients with hazy media.
  • B mode ultrasonography.
  • UBM (Ultrasound biomicroscopy) - for obscured IOFB hidden in the anterior chamber or angle.

questions.text: Keratitis is an inflammation of the cornea — the clear, dome-shaped tissue on the front of your eye that covers the pupil and iris. Keratitis may or may not be associated with an infection. The following image shows which disease?
questions.solution:
Option C: Viral keratitis

  • Viral keratitis showing dendritic ulcer.
  • Herpetic keratitis can be unilateral or, more rarely, bilateral. The latter is more common in patients with atopy due to proposed immune dysregulation increasing susceptibility to viral infections. Age, geographic location, and socioeconomic status appear to affect the prevalence of the disease. HSV can affect all layers of the cornea and may be accompanied by blepharoconjunctivitis, which may result in lesions of the eyelids and a follicular response of the conjunctiva. Characteristically, HSV epithelial keratitis presents with classic dendritic lesions with terminal bulbs. Recurrent activations within the sensory ganglion can result in corneal scarring, necrosis, and decreased sensation (neurotrophic cornea).

Option A: Bacterial keratitis

  • Bacterial keratitis is also often referred to as a 'corneal ulcer'. In practice, these terms are not directly interchangeable because a cornea may harbour a bacterial infection (i.e. bacterial keratitis) without having a loss of tissue (an ulcer), and a cornea may have an ulcer without a bacterial infection.
  • Bacterial keratitis is a serious bacterial infection of the cornea which can cause vision loss in severe cases.

Option B: Fungal keratitis

  • Fungal keratitis is a serious ocular infection with potentially catastrophic visual results. Caused by any of the many species of fungi capable of colonizing human tissue, it occurs worldwide, and its incidence is increasing in frequency.
  • The list covers many fungi including but not limited to yeasts of Candida spp., filamentous with septae such as Aspergillus spp., Fusarium spp., Cladosporium,spp., Curvularia, and non-septated such as Rhizopus. Bare in mind that any agent capable of infecting humans is a potentially infectious agent, especially if the host has a debilitating disease.

Option D: Syphilitic keratitis

  • Syphilitic keratitis is non-ulcerative interstitial keratitis typically manifests as a late sequela of congenital or acquired syphilis. Syphilitic keratitis is seen more commonly in patients with congenital syphilis than in those who acquire syphilis later in life.
  • In congenital syphilis, keratitis is typically bilateral in up to 80% of cases and presents as late congenital syphilis in children or adolescents, most often between ages 5 and 15.
  • Involvement of the second eye is typically seen within a few weeks following the onset of disease in the first eye but may also occur simultaneously.
  • Syphilitic keratitis can be the only manifestation of late congenital syphilis, but oral pathology (misshapen teeth) is also seen in 50% of cases.
  • The deep stroma of the cornea is primarily involved in syphilitic keratitis and manifests clinically as a stromal haze, or focal infiltrates. The inflammation appears most commonly in the superior cornea and can lead to corneal thickening. ​​​​​​​
  • Neovascularization of the cornea often occurs after the onset of stromal haze and edema.
  • Neovascularization occurs as extensions of the limbal and anterior ciliary vessels, often coinciding with increased lymphatic extension into the peripheral cornea. The combination of neovascularization and lymphatic extension leads to the classic salmon-coloured patch seen in the disease.
  • Treatment is important in the active stage of the disease to limit neovascularization and lymphatic extension by inhibiting the inflammatory response. After appropriate treatment, recurrence occurs in 5-15% of patients.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the clinic for the evaluation of his eyes. Two weeks ago, he was diagnosed with Xerophthalmia secondary to vitamin A deficiency. Which of the following is the first primary sign, first secondary sign and characteristic finding, respectively, seen in patients of Xeropthalmia?

choices.text: Night blindness, Conjunctival xerosis & Bitots spots
Corneal xerosis, Night blindness & Bitots spots
Night blindness, Corneal xerosis & Bitots spots
Conjunctival xerosis, Night blindness & Bitots spots

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Night blindness, Conjunctival xerosis & Bitots spots:

Then the correct arrangement of signs in a 7-year-old patient with xerophthalmia would be:

  1. First Primary Sign: Night blindness
  2. First Secondary Sign: Conjunctival xerosis
  3. Characteristic Finding: Bitot's spots

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Corneal xerosis, Night blindness & Bitots spots:

Option C - Night blindness, Corneal xerosis & Bitots spots:

Option D - Conjunctival xerosis, Night blindness & Bitots spots:

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to an outdoor ophthalmology department with a history of severe dull pain and redness of both eyes for the last two days. She also complains of discomfort in both eyes while driving at night. A typical butterfly rash on the face spares nasolabial folds on physical examination. Upon further inquiry, the ophthalmologist knows she is a known case of SLE and taking Hydroxychloroquine. The ophthalmologist counsels her that she is suffering from scleritis, which is the inflammation of the white of the eye. Concerning the anatomy, the sclera is the thinnest and thickest, respectively, at which part of the eyeball?

choices.text: Under insertion of recti & Posterior pole of the eye
At the limbus & Posterior pole of the eye
Anterior to attachment of rectus & at the limbus
At the equator & Anterior to attachment of the rectus

questions.solution:
Option A: Under insertion of the recti & Posterior pole of the eye

  • The above given is a case of scleritis.
  • Dull pain, redness in eyes and difficulty driving at night are suggestive.
  • The sclera is thinnest at posterior to rectus muscle insertions (0.3 mm), and the posterior pole is the thickest area (1 mm).
  • Scleritis is a condition characterized by inflammation of the sclera.
  • Causes piercing eye pain (typically worse at night and with eye movement) and diffuse, bright red injection. Complications include keratitis, uveitis, cataract formation, and glaucoma.

Option B: At the limbus & Posterior pole of the eye

  • At the corneal scleral limbus, the mean scleral thickness is approximately 0.5 mm decreasing to 0.4 mm near the equator and 1 mm near the optic head.

Option C: Anterior to attachment of rectus & at the limbus

  • Its thickness is 0.6 mm anterior to rectus attachment.
  • The rectus arises from a fibrous ring that encircles the optic nerve at the optic foramen, the opening through which the nerve passes, and is attached to the sclera, the opaque portion of the eyeball, in front of the equator, or widest part, of the eye.

Option D: At the equator & Anterior to attachment of the rectus

  • The thickness of the sclera decreases to a minimum at the equator.

questions.text: A 5-month-old girl baby is brought in by her parents to the ophthalmology outdoor clinic for the evaluation of esotropia. Her parents noted that the baby's eyes started to turn inwards shortly after birth and that her condition worsened. They also pointed out that this worsens when she is tired, and she alternates between the right eye and the left eye. She is suspected to be a case of essential infantile esotropia. Which of the following is the feature of this condition?

choices.text: Surgery can be done anytime, irrespective of the time passed

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Amblyopia:

  • Amblyopia is a condition in which one of the eyes experiences a poor vision. This is because of a dissociation between the eye and brain connection due to lack of or improper use of the eyes.
  • Infantile Essential Esotropia (Congenital Esotropia):
    • Onset usually after birth
    • Occurs during the first six months of life
    • Large angle squint (greater than 30 degrees)
    • From Birth
    • Surgery should be done as soon as possible
    • High Accommodative Convergence /Accommodation ratio
    • DVD (dissociated vertical deviation) is a common association
  • Esotropia is shown below:

  • About 40% of children with essential infantile esotropia develop amblyopia.
  • If this develops, we must patch the eye to correct the affected eye.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Small angle squint:

  • The squint angle is the difference between the fixating eye's visual axis and the deviating eye's visual axis.
  • The squint angle for essential infantile esotropia is usually large, greater than 30 degrees.

Option C - Surgery can be done anytime, irrespective of the time passed:

  • According to the latest data, it is essential to make surgical corrections as soon as the condition is diagnosed.
  • This is essential to prevent the development of amblyopia.
  • The surgery aims to keep the eyes aligned and ensure the best sensory development.

Option D - Low Accommodative convergence /Accommodation ratio:

  • Accommodative convergence/ accommodative ratio is a ratio between the amount of convergence generated by the given strength of accommodation by the lens.
  • People with essential infantile esotropia have a high AC/A ratio.
  • It manifests with the affected eye being turned inwards as the work of focusing is increasingly high, especially when the eye has to focus through significant hypermetropia.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old male presents to the dermatologic clinic with the complaint of hair loss for the past few weeks. He states that his hair loss is painless. On examination, patchy hair loss is observed on the scalp as shown below: 



The exclamation mark sign is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Alopecia areata

  • This patient with painless, patchy hair loss most likely has alopecia areata.
  • Alopecia areata is a chronic, immune-mediated disorder that targets anagen hair follicles and causes non-scarring hair loss. The condition most commonly presents with discrete, smooth patches of alopecia on the scalp but may also occur in other hair-bearing areas, such as the eyebrows, eyelashes, beard, and extremities.
  • In severe alopecia areata, patients may experience loss of all scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or all hair (alopecia Universalis)

Following are the important points regarding alopecia areata:

  1. Alopecia areata is an autoimmune disease that involves the hair follicle.
  2. Alopecia areata affects all age groups and different ethnicities.
  3. Alopecia areata can occur on virtually any hair-bearing area.
  4. It affects the scalp in approximately 90% of cases.
  5. The characteristic initial lesion of alopecia areata is a circumscribed, hairless, smooth patch. The skin within the bald patch appears normal or slightly reddened.
  6. Exclamation point hairs, short, broken hairs for which the proximal end of the hair is narrower than the distal end, are a common and pathognomonic finding in alopecia areata. Exclamation point hairs are typically found at the edges of expanding patches and can be extracted with minimal traction.

Option B: Anagen effluvium

  • It is the loss of hair after chemotherapy. It is diffuse shedding of Anagen hair follicles (85% of hair follicles). Chemotherapy causes the arrest of the hair follicles in the Anagen phase, resulting in the shedding of these follicles. The exclamation sign is not present.

Option C: Telogen effluvium

  • It is loss of hair following stress and infection. Increased Telogen hair loss is seen in 3 months after Pregnancy / Typhoid fever / any chronic illness. The exclamation sign is negative.

Option D: In androgenic alopecia

  • There is frontotemporal recession. The exclamation sign is not seen.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male child presents to the clinic accompanied by his mother with a rash, as shown in the picture below. The rash started appearing on his trunk this morning, and the mother believes it is spreading to his arms and legs. He has a history of high-grade fever and a seizure three days back. At that time, his work-up was normal, and he was sent home with acetaminophen and fluids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Roseola

  • Lack of symptoms during the febrile phase and the appearance of the eruption as the fever subsides are suggestive of Roseola.
  • The organism involved in the pathogenesis is the Human herpes virus 6 (HHV-6).
  • Manifests as a rosy rash on the trunk & neck after three days of high fevers; it may later spread to the arms, face, and legs.
  • The rash usually fades within two days.
  • It is a self-limited disease requiring no treatment.

Option A: Fixed Drug Eruption

  • Fixed: As lesions always occur at the same site.
  • Drug: As it Occurs after consumption of drugs like:
    • NSAIDS
    • Tetracycline
    • Cotrimoxazole
  • Eruptions
    • Initially, the patient develops erythematous lesions.
    • Later, these heal with Hyperpigmentation.

Option B: Erythema infectiosum/5th Disease

  • Caused by Human Parvovirus B19.
  • SLAPPED CHEEK APPEARANCE.

Option C: Measles (RUBEOLA)

  • The maculopapular rash begins at the hairline, then involves the face and upper neck. Later involves extremities.
  • Fever, running nose, and congested eyes.
  • Infectivity period → 4 days Before ←RASH → 5 Days after.
  • Most characteristic Feature → Koplik Spots

questions.text: A 39-year-old patient presents in the clinic with the complaint of rash for the past 1 week. Examination shows multiple, well-demarcated, oval, finely scaling hypopigmented patches over the trunk. 10% KOH mount shows spaghetti and meatball appearance. Which of the following signs is commonly seen in association with this disease?
questions.solution:
Option C: Coup D’ongle sign

Pitryiasis versicolor:

  • Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by well-demarcated hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches with fine scaling.
  • Diagnosis is made by KOH mount, which shows round yeasts with filaments, also referred to as "spaghetti and meatball" appearance.
  • An important diagnostic clue in the identification of Pityriasis Versicolor is the loosening of the barely perceptible scale of the lesion with a fingernail.
  • This is called a scratch sign or coup d’ongle sign, which means a stroke of the nail.

Option A: Iris Sign 

  • The typical Iris lesions or target signs are seen in Erythema multiforme.
  • They are characterized by regular round-shaped macules or papules with a central dusky region, a paler edematous zone, and a peripheral red ring.

Option B: Auspitz Sign

  • Auspitz Sign is seen in psoriasis and is characterized by the appearance of minute pinpoint bleeding points when scaly scabs are peeled off.

Option D: Darier’s Sign

  • Darier’s Sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa and is characterized by the appearance of a wheal and flare reaction after rubbing a skin lesion.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy visits the clinic with a complaint of discolored patches on his cheek for the last four months. He has a history of allergic rhinitis. On examination, small hypopigmented scaly macules with intact sensations are found on the cheek. The rest of the body is spared. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pityriasis alba

This patient, with small hypopigmented scaly macules on the cheek having intact sensations and a history of atopy (allergic rhinitis), most likely suffers from pityriasis alba.

  • It is a type of dermatitis.
  • Occurs predominantly in children (3-16 years). Both sexes are equally susceptible.
  • The typical Lesion is rounded, oval, or irregular plaque, red, pink, or skin in color, and has fine lamellar or branny scaling.
  • Initially, there is erythema with minimal crusting
  • Later, erythema subsides, and persistent fine scaling with hypopigmentation develops
  • History of atopy is mostly present

Option A: Pityriasis Rosea

  • Flu-like symptoms occur 1-2 weeks before the appearance of a rash
  • Herald patch, initial Lesion that is characterized by a single ovoid macule with a slightly raised border and a central salmon-colored clearing zone
  • Collarette scaling is seen
  • Secondary eruptions with a Christmas tree pattern on the back

Option B: Pityriasis Versicolor

  • Superficial fungal infection
  • Scaly macule shows both hyper- and hypopigmentation
  • Seen on the upper trunk and shoulders commonly
  • Most cases are seen in summers or after significantly prolonged sunlight exposure.

Option C: Indeterminate leprosy

  • A very early form of leprosy usually progresses to one of the major types
  • Non-scaly
  • Epidermal atrophy, wrinkling
  • Slight hypoesthesia is found
